Text

CHAPTER I. [Sir Walter Elliot]86-sir walter , of [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall , in [Somersetshire]2-somersetshire , was [a man who , for [his]86-sir walter own amusement , never took up any book but the Baronetage]223-a man who , for his own amusement , never took up any book but the baronetage ; there [he]86-sir walter found occupation for an idle hour , and consolation in a distressed one ; there [his]86-sir walter faculties were roused into admiration and respect , by contemplating the limited remnant of the earliest patents ; there any unwelcome sensations , arising from domestic affairs changed naturally into pity and contempt as [he]86-sir walter turned over the almost endless creations of the last century ; and there , if every other leaf were powerless , [he]86-sir walter could read [his]86-sir walter own history with an interest which never failed . This was the page at which the favourite volume always opened : “ ELLIOT OF [KELLYNCH HALL]1-kellynch hall . “[86-sir walter] [Walter Elliot]86-sir walter , born March 1 , 1760 , married , July 15 , 1784 , [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth , daughter of [James Stevenson]88-james stevenson , Esq . of [South Park]224-south park , in [the county of Gloucester]225-the county of gloucester , by which [lady ( who died 1800]226-lady ( who died 1800 ) [he]86-sir walter has issue [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth , born June 1 , 1785 ; [Anne]89-anne , born August 9 , 1787 ; [a still - born son , November 5 , 1789]227-a still - born son , november 5 , 1789 ; [Mary]90-mary , born November 20 , 1791 . ” Precisely such had the paragraph originally stood from [the printer]1697-the printer ’s hands ; but [Sir Walter]86-sir walter had improved it by adding , for the information of [himself]86-sir walter and [[his]86-sir walter family]1698-his family , these words , after the date of [Mary]90-mary ’s birth—“Married[91-charles] , December 16 , 1810 , [Charles]91-charles , son and heir of [Charles Musgrove]92-charles , Esq . of [Uppercross]3-uppercross , in [the county of Somerset]228-the county of somerset , ” and by inserting most accurately the day of the month on which [he]86-sir walter had lost [[his]86-sir walter wife]1699-his wife . Then followed the history and rise of [the ancient and respectable family]1700-the ancient and respectable family , in the usual terms ; how it had been first settled in [Cheshire]4-cheshire ; how mentioned in [Dugdale]93-dugdale , serving the office of high sheriff , representing [a borough]1701-a borough in three successive parliaments , exertions of loyalty , and dignity of [baronet]1702-baronet , in the first year of [Charles II]94-charles ii , with all [the Marys and Elizabeths]1703-the marys and elizabeths [they]1703-the marys and elizabeths had married ; forming altogether [two handsome duodecimo pages]1704-two handsome duodecimo pages , and concluding with the arms and motto:—“Principal[230-heir presumptive] seat , [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall , in [the county of Somerset]228-the county of somerset , ” and [Sir Walter]86-sir walter ’s handwriting again in this finale : — “[230-heir presumptive] [Heir presumptive]230-heir presumptive , [William Walter Elliot]95-william walter elliot , Esq . , [great grandson of [the second Sir Walter]232-the second sir walter]231-great grandson of the second sir walter . ” Vanity was the beginning and the end of [Sir Walter Elliot]86-sir walter ’s character ; vanity of person and of situation . [He]86-sir walter had been remarkably handsome in [his]86-sir walter youth ; and , at fifty - four , was still [a very fine man]1705-a very fine man . [Few women]1706-few women could think more of [their]1706-few women personal appearance than [he]86-sir walter did , nor could [the valet of [any new made lord]1708-any new made lord]1707-the valet of any new made lord be more delighted with the place [he]86-sir walter held in society . [He]86-sir walter considered the blessing of beauty as inferior only to the blessing of a baronetcy ; and [the Sir Walter Elliot]86-sir walter , who united these gifts , was the constant object of [his]86-sir walter warmest respect and devotion . [His]86-sir walter good looks and [his]86-sir walter rank had one fair claim on [his]86-sir walter attachment ; since to [them]1706-few women [he]86-sir walter must have owed [a wife of very superior character]1709-a wife of very superior character to any thing deserved by [his]86-sir walter own . [Lady Elliot]96-lady elliot had been [an excellent woman]1710-an excellent woman , sensible and amiable ; whose judgement and conduct , if [they]1706-few women might be pardoned the youthful infatuation which made [her]96-lady elliot [Lady Elliot]96-lady elliot , had never required indulgence afterwards . [She]96-lady elliot had humoured , or softened , or concealed [his]86-sir walter failings , and promoted [his]86-sir walter real respectability for seventeen years ; and though not the very happiest being in [the world]1711-the world [herself]96-lady elliot , had found enough in [her]96-lady elliot duties , [[her]96-lady elliot friends]1712-her friends , and [[her]96-lady elliot children]1713-her children , to attach [her]96-lady elliot to life , and make it no matter of indifference to [her]96-lady elliot when [she]96-lady elliot was called on to quit [them]1706-few women . [Three girls]1714-three girls , [the two eldest sixteen and fourteen]1715-the two eldest sixteen and fourteen , was an awful legacy for [a mother]1716-a mother to bequeath , an awful charge rather , to confide to the authority and guidance of [a conceited , silly father]1717-a conceited , silly father . [She]96-lady elliot had , however , [one very intimate friend]1718-one very intimate friend , [a sensible , deserving woman , who had been brought , by strong attachment to [herself]96-lady elliot , to settle close by [her]96-lady elliot , in [the village of]1720-the village of [Kellynch]5-kellynch]1719-a sensible , deserving woman , who had been brought , by strong attachment to herself , to settle close by her , in the village of kellynch ; and on [her]96-lady elliot kindness and advice , [Lady Elliot]96-lady elliot mainly relied for the best help and maintenance of the good principles and instruction which [she]96-lady elliot had been anxiously giving [[her]96-lady elliot daughters]1721-her daughters . [This friend]1722-this friend , and [Sir Walter]86-sir walter , did not marry , whatever might have been anticipated on that head by [their]1723-their acquaintance . Thirteen years had passed away since [Lady Elliot]96-lady elliot ’s death , and [they]1723-their were still near [neighbours]1724-neighbours and [intimate friends]1725-intimate friends , and [one]1726-one remained [a widower]1727-a widower , [the other a widow]1728-the other a widow . That [Lady Russell , of steady age and character , and extremely well provided for]1729-lady russell , of steady age and character , and extremely well provided for , should have no thought of a second marriage , needs no apology to the public , which is rather apt to be unreasonably discontented when [a woman]1730-a woman does marry again , than when [she]1730-a woman does not ; but [Sir Walter]86-sir walter ’s continuing in singleness requires explanation . Be it known then , that [Sir Walter]86-sir walter , like [a good father]1731-a good father , ( having met with one or two private disappointments in very unreasonable applications ) , prided [himself]86-sir walter on remaining single for [[his]86-sir walter dear daughters]1732-his dear daughters ’ sake . For [one daughter]1733-one daughter , [[his]86-sir walter eldest]1734-his eldest , [he]86-sir walter would really have given up any thing , which [he]86-sir walter had not been very much tempted to do . [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth had succeeded , at sixteen , to all that was possible , of [[her]87-elizabeth mother]1735-her mother ’s rights and consequence ; and being very handsome , and very like [himself]86-sir walter , [her]87-elizabeth influence had always been great , and [they]1736-they had gone on together most happily . [[His]86-sir walter two other children]1737-his two other children were of very inferior value . [Mary]90-mary had acquired a little artificial importance , by becoming [Mrs Charles Musgrove]92-charles ; but [Anne]89-anne , with an elegance of mind and sweetness of character , which must have placed [her]89-anne high with [any people of real understanding]1738-any people of real understanding , was nobody with either [father]1739-father or [sister]1740-sister ; [her]89-anne word had no weight , [her]89-anne convenience was always to give way — [she]89-anne was only [Anne]89-anne . To [Lady Russell]97-lady russell , indeed , [she]97-lady russell was [a most dear and highly valued god - daughter , favourite]1741-a most dear and highly valued god - daughter , favourite , and [friend]1742-friend . [Lady Russell]97-lady russell loved [them]1736-they all ; but it was only in [Anne]89-anne that [she]97-lady russell could fancy [the mother]1743-the mother to revive again . A few years before , [Anne Elliot]89-anne had been [a very pretty girl]1744-a very pretty girl , but [her]89-anne bloom had vanished early ; and as even in its height , [[her]89-anne father]1745-her father had found little to admire in [her]89-anne , ( so totally different were [her]89-anne delicate features and mild dark eyes from [his]1745-her father own ) , there could be nothing in them , now that [she]89-anne was faded and thin , to excite [his]1745-her father esteem . [He]1745-her father had never indulged much hope , [he]1745-her father had now none , of ever reading [her]89-anne name in any other page of [his]1745-her father favourite work . All equality of alliance must rest with [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth , for [Mary]90-mary had merely connected [herself]90-mary with [an old country family of respectability and large fortune]1746-an old country family of respectability and large fortune , and had therefore given all the honour and received none : [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth would , one day or other , marry suitably . It sometimes happens that [a woman]1730-a woman is handsomer at twenty - nine than [she]1730-a woman was ten years before ; and , generally speaking , if there has been neither ill health nor anxiety , it is a time of life at which scarcely any charm is lost . It was so with [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth , still the same handsome [Miss Elliot]89-anne that [she]89-anne had begun to be thirteen years ago , and [Sir Walter]86-sir walter might be excused , therefore , in forgetting [her]89-anne age , or , at least , be deemed [only half a fool]1748-only half a fool , for thinking [himself]1745-her father and [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth as blooming as ever , amidst the wreck of the good looks of [everybody else]1749-everybody else ; for [he]1745-her father could plainly see how old [all the rest of [[his]1745-her father family]1698-his family]1750-all the rest of his family and acquaintance were growing . [Anne]89-anne haggard , [Mary]90-mary coarse , every face in [the neighbourhood]1752-the neighbourhood worsting , and the rapid increase of the crow ’s foot about [[Lady Russell]97-lady russell ’s temples]1753-lady russell ’s temples had long been a distress to [him]1745-her father . [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth did not quite equal [[her]87-elizabeth father]1745-her father in personal contentment . Thirteen years had seen [[her]87-elizabeth mistress of [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall]1755-her mistress of kellynch hall , presiding and directing with a self - possession and decision which could never have given the idea of [her]87-elizabeth being younger than [she]87-elizabeth was . For thirteen years had [she]87-elizabeth been doing the honours , and laying down the domestic law at [home]1756-home , and leading the way to the chaise and four , and walking immediately after [Lady Russell]97-lady russell out of [all the drawing - rooms and dining - rooms in [the country]1758-the country]1757-all the drawing - rooms and dining - rooms in the country . Thirteen winters ’ revolving frosts had seen [her]87-elizabeth opening every ball of credit which [a scanty neighbourhood]1759-a scanty neighbourhood afforded , and thirteen springs shewn [their]1759-a scanty neighbourhood blossoms , as [she]87-elizabeth travelled up to [London]6-london with [[her]87-elizabeth father]1745-her father , for a few weeks ’ annual enjoyment of [the great world]1761-the great world . [She]87-elizabeth had the remembrance of all this , [she]87-elizabeth had the consciousness of being nine - and - twenty to give [her]87-elizabeth some regrets and some apprehensions ; [she]87-elizabeth was fully satisfied of being still quite as handsome as ever , but [she]87-elizabeth felt [her]87-elizabeth approach to the years of danger , and would have rejoiced to be certain of being properly solicited by [baronet - blood]1762-baronet - blood within the next twelvemonth or two . Then might [she]87-elizabeth again take up the book of books with as much enjoyment as in [her]87-elizabeth early youth , but now [she]87-elizabeth liked it not . Always to be presented with the date of [her]87-elizabeth own birth and see no marriage follow but that of [a youngest sister]1763-a youngest sister , made the book an evil ; and more than once , when [[her]87-elizabeth father]1745-her father had left it open on the table near [her]87-elizabeth , had [she]87-elizabeth closed it , with averted eyes , and pushed it away . [She]87-elizabeth had had a disappointment , moreover , which that book , and especially the history of [[her]87-elizabeth own family]1765-her own family , must ever present the remembrance of . [The heir presumptive]1766-the heir presumptive , [the very William Walter Elliot , Esq .]1767-the very william walter elliot , esq . , whose rights had been so generously supported by [[her]87-elizabeth father]1745-her father , had disappointed [her]87-elizabeth . [She]87-elizabeth had , while [a very young girl]1769-a very young girl , as soon as [she]87-elizabeth had known [him]1745-her father to be , in the event of [her]87-elizabeth having [no brother]1770-no brother , [the future baronet]1771-the future baronet , meant to marry [him]1745-her father , and [[her]87-elizabeth father]1745-her father had always meant that [she]87-elizabeth should . [He]1745-her father had not been known to [them]1773-them as [a boy]1774-a boy ; but soon after [Lady Elliot]96-lady elliot ’s death , [Sir Walter]86-sir walter had sought the acquaintance , and though [his]1745-her father overtures had not been met with any warmth , [he]1745-her father had persevered in seeking it , making allowance for the modest drawing - back of youth ; and , in one of [their]1773-them spring excursions to [London]6-london , when [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth was in [her]87-elizabeth first bloom , [Mr Elliot]98-mr elliot had been forced into the introduction . [He]98-mr elliot was at that time [a very young man]1775-a very young man , just engaged in the study of the law ; and [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth found [him]98-mr elliot extremely agreeable , and every plan in [his]98-mr elliot favour was confirmed . [He]98-mr elliot was invited to [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall ; [he]98-mr elliot was talked of and expected all the rest of the year ; but [he]98-mr elliot never came . The following spring [he]98-mr elliot was seen again in [town]1776-town , found equally agreeable , again encouraged , invited , and expected , and again [he]98-mr elliot did not come ; and the next tidings were that [he]98-mr elliot was married . Instead of pushing [his]98-mr elliot fortune in the line marked out for [the heir of the house of Elliot]1777-the heir of the house of elliot , [he]98-mr elliot had purchased independence by uniting [himself]98-mr elliot to [a rich woman of inferior birth]1778-a rich woman of inferior birth . [Sir Walter]86-sir walter had resented it . As [the head of [the house]1780-the house]1779-the head of the house , [he]86-sir walter felt that [he]86-sir walter ought to have been consulted , especially after taking [the young man]1781-the young man so publicly by the hand ; “[231-great grandson of the second sir walter] For [they]233-they must have been seen together , ” [he]86-sir walter observed , “[231-great grandson of the second sir walter] once at [Tattersall ’s]7-tattersall ’s , and twice in [the lobby of [the House of Commons]235-the house of commons]234-the lobby of the house of commons . ” [His]86-sir walter disapprobation was expressed , but apparently very little regarded . [Mr Elliot]98-mr elliot had attempted no apology , and shewn [himself]98-mr elliot as unsolicitous of being longer noticed by [the family]1782-the family , as [Sir Walter]86-sir walter considered [him]98-mr elliot unworthy of it : all acquaintance between [them]233-they had ceased . This very awkward history of [Mr Elliot]98-mr elliot was still , after an interval of several years , felt with anger by [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth , who had liked [the man]1783-the man for [himself]98-mr elliot , and still more for being [[[her]87-elizabeth father]1745-her father ’s heir , and whose strong family pride could see only in [him]98-mr elliot a proper match for [[Sir Walter Elliot]86-sir walter ’s eldest daughter]1786-sir walter elliot ’s eldest daughter]1785-her father ’s heir , and whose strong family pride could see only in him a proper match for sir walter elliot ’s eldest daughter . There was not [a baronet from A to Z whom [her]87-elizabeth feelings could have so willingly acknowledged as an equal]1787-a baronet from a to z whom her feelings could have so willingly acknowledged as an equal . Yet so miserably had [he]98-mr elliot conducted [himself]98-mr elliot , that though [she]87-elizabeth was at this present time ( the summer of 1814 ) wearing black ribbons for [[his]98-mr elliot wife]1699-his wife , [she]87-elizabeth could not admit [him]98-mr elliot to be worth thinking of again . The disgrace of [his]98-mr elliot first marriage might , perhaps , as there was no reason to suppose it perpetuated by [offspring]1789-offspring , have been got over , had [he]98-mr elliot not done worse ; but [he]98-mr elliot had , as by the accustomary intervention of [kind friends]1790-kind friends , [they]1790-kind friends had been informed , spoken most disrespectfully of [them]1790-kind friends all , most slightingly and contemptuously of the very blood [he]98-mr elliot belonged to , and the honours which were hereafter to be [his]98-mr elliot own . This could not be pardoned . Such were [Elizabeth Elliot]87-elizabeth ’s sentiments and sensations ; such the cares to alloy , the agitations to vary , the sameness and the elegance , the prosperity and the nothingness of [her]87-elizabeth scene of life ; such the feelings to give interest to a long , uneventful residence in [one country circle]1791-one country circle , to fill the vacancies which there were no habits of utility abroad , no talents or accomplishments for [home]1756-home , to occupy . But now , another occupation and solicitude of mind was beginning to be added to these . [[Her]87-elizabeth father]1745-her father was growing distressed for money . [She]87-elizabeth knew , that when [he]98-mr elliot now took up [the Baronetage]1794-the baronetage , it was to drive the heavy bills of [[his]98-mr elliot tradespeople]1795-his tradespeople , and the unwelcome hints of [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd , [[his]98-mr elliot agent]1796-his agent , from [his]98-mr elliot thoughts . The Kellynch property was good , but not equal to [Sir Walter]86-sir walter ’s apprehension of [the state]1797-the state required in [its possessor]1798-its possessor . While [Lady Elliot]96-lady elliot lived , there had been method , moderation , and economy , which had just kept [him]98-mr elliot within [his]98-mr elliot income ; but with [her]87-elizabeth had died all such right - mindedness , and from that period [he]98-mr elliot had been constantly exceeding it . It had not been possible for [him]98-mr elliot to spend less ; [he]98-mr elliot had done nothing but what [Sir Walter Elliot]86-sir walter was imperiously called on to do ; but blameless as [he]98-mr elliot was , [he]98-mr elliot was not only growing dreadfully in debt , but was hearing of it so often , that it became vain to attempt concealing it longer , even partially , from [[his]98-mr elliot daughter]1799-his daughter . [He]98-mr elliot had given [her]237-her some hints of it the last spring in [town]1776-town ; [he]98-mr elliot had gone so far even as to say , “[231-great grandson of the second sir walter] Can [we]236-their retrench ? Does it occur to [you]237-her that there is any one article in which [we]236-their can retrench ? ” and [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth , to do [her]87-elizabeth justice , had , in the first ardour of female alarm , set seriously to think what could be done , and had finally proposed these two branches of economy , to cut off some unnecessary charities , and to refrain from new furnishing [the drawing - room]1801-the drawing - room ; to which expedients [she]87-elizabeth afterwards added the happy thought of [their]236-their taking no present down to [Anne]89-anne , as had been the usual yearly custom . But these measures , however good in themselves , were insufficient for the real extent of the evil , the whole of which [Sir Walter]86-sir walter found [himself]98-mr elliot obliged to confess to [her]237-her soon afterwards . [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth had nothing to propose of deeper efficacy . [She]87-elizabeth felt [herself]87-elizabeth ill - used and unfortunate , as did [[her]87-elizabeth father]1745-her father ; and [they]236-their were neither of [them]236-their able to devise any means of lessening [their]236-their expenses without compromising [their]236-their dignity , or relinquishing [their]236-their comforts in a way not to be borne . There was only a small part of [[his]86-sir walter estate]1803-his estate that [Sir Walter]86-sir walter could dispose of ; but had [every acre]1804-every acre been alienable , it would have made no difference . [He]86-sir walter had condescended to mortgage as far as [he]86-sir walter had the power , but [he]86-sir walter would never condescend to sell . No ; [he]86-sir walter would never disgrace [his]86-sir walter name so far . [The Kellynch estate]1805-the kellynch estate should be transmitted whole and entire , as [he]86-sir walter had received [it]1805-the kellynch estate . [[Their]236-their two confidential friends]1806-their two confidential friends , [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd , who lived in [the neighbouring market town]1807-the neighbouring market town , and [Lady Russell]97-lady russell , were called on to advise [them]236-their ; and [both father]1808-both father and [daughter]1809-daughter seemed to expect that something should be struck out by one or the other to remove [their]236-their embarrassments and reduce [their]236-their expenditure , without involving the loss of any indulgence of taste or pride . CHAPTER II . [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd , [a civil , cautious lawyer , who , whatever might be [his]99-mr shepherd hold or [his]99-mr shepherd views on [Sir Walter]86-sir walter]1810-a civil , cautious lawyer , who , whatever might be his hold or his views on sir walter , would rather have the disagreeable prompted by [anybody else]1811-anybody else , excused [himself]99-mr shepherd from offering the slightest hint , and only begged leave to recommend an implicit reference to the excellent judgement of [Lady Russell]97-lady russell , from whose known good sense [he]99-mr shepherd fully expected to have just such resolute measures advised as [he]99-mr shepherd meant to see finally adopted . [Lady Russell]97-lady russell was most anxiously zealous on the subject , and gave it much serious consideration . [She]97-lady russell was [a woman rather of sound than of quick abilities , whose difficulties in coming to any decision in this instance were great , from the opposition of two leading principles]1812-a woman rather of sound than of quick abilities , whose difficulties in coming to any decision in this instance were great , from the opposition of two leading principles . [She]97-lady russell was of strict integrity [herself]97-lady russell , with a delicate sense of honour ; but [she]97-lady russell was as desirous of saving [Sir Walter]86-sir walter ’s feelings , as solicitous for the credit of [the family]1782-the family , as aristocratic in [her]97-lady russell ideas of what was due to [them]1782-the family , as [anybody of sense]1814-anybody of sense and honesty could well be . [She]97-lady russell was [a benevolent , charitable , good woman]1815-a benevolent , charitable , good woman , and capable of strong attachments , most correct in [her]97-lady russell conduct , strict in [her]97-lady russell notions of decorum , and with manners that were held a standard of good - breeding . [She]97-lady russell had a cultivated mind , and was , generally speaking , rational and consistent — but [she]97-lady russell had prejudices on the side of ancestry ; [she]97-lady russell had a value for rank and consequence , which blinded [her]97-lady russell a little to the faults of those who possessed [them]1782-the family . [Herself]97-lady russell [the widow of only [a knight]1817-a knight]1816-the widow of only a knight , [she]97-lady russell gave the dignity of [a baronet]1818-a baronet all its due ; and [Sir Walter]86-sir walter , independent of [his]86-sir walter claims as [an old acquaintance]1819-an old acquaintance , [an attentive neighbour]1820-an attentive neighbour , [an obliging landlord]1821-an obliging landlord , [the husband of [[her]97-lady russell very dear friend]1823-her very dear friend , [the father of [Anne]89-anne]1824-the father of anne and [[her]89-anne sisters]1825-her sisters]1822-the husband of her very dear friend , the father of anne and her sisters , was , as being [Sir Walter]86-sir walter , in [her]97-lady russell apprehension , entitled to a great deal of compassion and consideration under [his]86-sir walter present difficulties . [They]1826-they must retrench ; that did not admit of a doubt . But [she]97-lady russell was very anxious to have it done with the least possible pain to [him]86-sir walter and [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth . [She]97-lady russell drew up plans of economy , [she]97-lady russell made exact calculations , and [she]97-lady russell did what [nobody else]1827-nobody else thought of doing : [she]97-lady russell consulted [Anne]89-anne , who never seemed considered by [the others]1828-the others as having any interest in the question . [She]97-lady russell consulted , and in a degree was influenced by [her]97-lady russell in marking out the scheme of retrenchment which was at last submitted to [Sir Walter]86-sir walter . Every emendation of [Anne]89-anne ’s had been on the side of honesty against importance . [She]97-lady russell wanted more vigorous measures , a more complete reformation , a quicker release from debt , a much higher tone of indifference for everything but justice and equity . “[239-your] If [we]238-we can persuade [[your]239-your father]240-your father to all this , ” said [Lady Russell]97-lady russell , looking over [her]97-lady russell paper , “[239-your] much may be done . If [he]240-your father will adopt these regulations , in seven years [he]240-your father will be clear ; and [I]0-i hope [we]238-we may be able to convince [him]240-your father and [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth , that [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall has a respectability in itself which can not be affected by these reductions ; and that the true dignity of [Sir Walter Elliot]86-sir walter will be very far from lessened in the eyes of [sensible people]241-sensible people , by acting like [a man of principle]242-a man of principle . What will [he]240-your father be doing , in fact , but what [very many of [[our]238-we first families]244-our first families]243-very many of our first families have done , or ought to do ? There will be nothing singular in [his]240-your father case ; and it is singularity which often makes the worst part of [our]238-we suffering , as it always does of [our]238-we conduct . [I]0-i have great hope of prevailing . [We]238-we must be serious and decided ; for after all , [the person who has contracted debts]245-the person who has contracted debts must pay [them]246-them ; and though a great deal is due to the feelings of [the gentleman]247-the gentleman , and [the head of [a house]249-a house , like [[your]250-your father]240-your father]248-the head of a house , like your father , there is still more due to the character of [an honest man]252-an honest man . ” This was the principle on which [Anne]89-anne wanted [[her]89-anne father]1745-her father to be proceeding , [[his]1745-her father friends]1830-his friends to be urging [him]1745-her father . [She]89-anne considered it as an act of indispensable duty to clear away the claims of [creditors]1831-creditors with all the expedition which the most comprehensive retrenchments could secure , and saw no dignity in anything short of it . [She]89-anne wanted it to be prescribed , and felt as a duty . [She]89-anne rated [Lady Russell]97-lady russell ’s influence highly ; and as to the severe degree of self - denial which [her]89-anne own conscience prompted , [she]89-anne believed there might be little more difficulty in persuading [them]1831-creditors to a complete , than to half a reformation . [Her]89-anne knowledge of [[her]89-anne father]1745-her father and [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth inclined [her]89-anne to think that the sacrifice of one pair of horses would be hardly less painful than of both , and so on , through the whole list of [Lady Russell]97-lady russell ’s too gentle reductions . How [Anne]89-anne ’s more rigid requisitions might have been taken is of little consequence . [Lady Russell]97-lady russell ’s had no success at all : could not be put up with , were not to be borne . “[252-an honest man] What ! every comfort of life knocked off ! [Journeys]8-journeys , [London]6-london , [servants]253-servants , horses , table — contractions and restrictions every where ! To live no longer with the decencies even of [a private gentleman]254-a private gentleman ! No , [he]254-a private gentleman would sooner quit [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall at once , than remain in [it]1-kellynch hall on such disgraceful terms . ” “[254-a private gentleman] Quit [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall . ” The hint was immediately taken up by [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd , whose interest was involved in the reality of [Sir Walter]86-sir walter ’s retrenching , and who was perfectly persuaded that nothing would be done without a change of abode . “[254-a private gentleman] Since the idea had been started in the very quarter which ought to dictate , [he]254-a private gentleman had no scruple , ” [he]254-a private gentleman said , “[254-a private gentleman] in confessing [his]254-a private gentleman judgement to be entirely on that side . It did not appear to [him]254-a private gentleman that [Sir Walter]86-sir walter could materially alter [his]86-sir walter style of living in [a house]249-a house which had such a character of hospitality and ancient dignity to support . In any other place [Sir Walter]86-sir walter might judge for [himself]86-sir walter ; and would be looked up to , as regulating the modes of life in whatever way [he]86-sir walter might choose to model [[his]86-sir walter household]256-his household . ” [Sir Walter]86-sir walter would quit [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall ; and after a very few days more of doubt and indecision , the great question of whither [he]86-sir walter should go was settled , and the first outline of this important change made out . There had been three alternatives , [London]6-london , [Bath]9-bath , or [another house in [the country]1758-the country]1833-another house in the country . All [Anne]89-anne ’s wishes had been for the latter . [A small house in [[their]1836-their own neighbourhood]1837-their own neighbourhood , where [they]1836-their might still have [[Lady Russell]97-lady russell ’s society]1838-lady russell ’s society]1835-a small house in their own neighbourhood , where they might still have lady russell ’s society , still be near [Mary]90-mary , and still have the pleasure of sometimes seeing [the lawns and groves of [Kellynch]5-kellynch]1839-the lawns and groves of kellynch , was the object of [her]89-anne ambition . But the usual fate of [Anne]89-anne attended [her]89-anne , in having something very opposite from [her]89-anne inclination fixed on . [She]89-anne disliked [Bath]9-bath , and did not think it agreed with [her]89-anne ; and [Bath]1840-bath was to be [[her]89-anne home]1841-her home . [Sir Walter]86-sir walter had at first thought more of [London]6-london ; but [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd felt that [he]99-mr shepherd could not be trusted in [London]6-london , and had been skilful enough to dissuade [him]99-mr shepherd from it , and make [Bath]9-bath preferred . It was a much safer place for [a gentleman]1842-a gentleman in [his]1842-a gentleman predicament : [he]1842-a gentleman might there be important at comparatively little expense . Two material advantages of [Bath]9-bath over [London]6-london had of course been given all [their]1843-their weight : [its]9-bath more convenient distance from [Kellynch]5-kellynch , only fifty miles , and [Lady Russell]97-lady russell ’s spending some part of every winter there ; and to the very great satisfaction of [Lady Russell , whose first views on the projected change]1844-lady russell , whose first views on the projected change had been for [Bath]9-bath , [Sir Walter]86-sir walter and [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth were induced to believe that [they]1843-their should lose neither consequence nor enjoyment by settling [there]1845-there . [Lady Russell]97-lady russell felt obliged to oppose [her]97-lady russell dear [Anne]89-anne ’s known wishes . It would be too much to expect [Sir Walter]86-sir walter to descend into [a small house in [[his]86-sir walter own neighbourhood]1847-his own neighbourhood]1846-a small house in his own neighbourhood . [Anne]89-anne [herself]89-anne would have found the mortifications of it more than [she]89-anne foresaw , and to [Sir Walter]86-sir walter ’s feelings they must have been dreadful . And with regard to [Anne]89-anne ’s dislike of [Bath]9-bath , [she]89-anne considered it as a prejudice and mistake arising , first , from the circumstance of [her]89-anne having been three years at [school]1848-school [there]1845-there , after [[her]89-anne mother]1735-her mother ’s death ; and secondly , from [her]89-anne happening to be not in perfectly good spirits the only winter which [she]89-anne had afterwards spent [there]1845-there with [herself]89-anne . [Lady Russell]97-lady russell was fond of [Bath]9-bath , in short , and disposed to think it must suit [them]1852-them all ; and as to [[her]97-lady russell young friend]1853-her young friend ’s health , by passing all the warm months with [her]97-lady russell at [Kellynch Lodge]10-kellynch lodge , every danger would be avoided ; and it was in fact , a change which must do both health and spirits good . [Anne]89-anne had been too little from [home]1756-home , too little seen . [Her]89-anne spirits were not high . A larger society would improve [them]1855-them . [She]97-lady russell wanted [her]89-anne to be more known . The undesirableness of [any other house in [the same neighbourhood]1857-the same neighbourhood]1856-any other house in the same neighbourhood for [Sir Walter]86-sir walter was certainly much strengthened by one part , and a very material part of the scheme , which had been happily engrafted on the beginning . [He]86-sir walter was not only to quit [[his]86-sir walter home]1858-his home , but to see it in the hands of [others]1859-others ; a trial of fortitude , which stronger heads than [Sir Walter]86-sir walter ’s have found too much . [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall was to be let . This , however , was a profound secret , not to be breathed beyond [their]1852-them own circle . [Sir Walter]86-sir walter could not have borne the degradation of being known to design letting [[his]86-sir walter house]1860-his house . [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd had once mentioned the word “[86-sir walter] advertise , ” but never dared approach it again . [Sir Walter]86-sir walter spurned the idea of its being offered in any manner ; forbad the slightest hint being dropped of [his]86-sir walter having such an intention ; and it was only on the supposition of [his]86-sir walter being spontaneously solicited by [some most unexceptionable applicant]1861-some most unexceptionable applicant , on [his]86-sir walter own terms , and as a great favour , that [he]86-sir walter would let it at all . How quick come the reasons for approving what [we]1862-we like ! [Lady Russell]97-lady russell had another excellent one at hand , for being extremely glad that [Sir Walter]86-sir walter and [[his]86-sir walter family]1698-his family were to remove from [the country]1758-the country . [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth had been lately forming an intimacy , which [she]97-lady russell wished to see interrupted . [Lady Russell]97-lady russell , indeed , had scarcely any influence with [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth , and seemed to love [her]87-elizabeth , rather because [she]87-elizabeth would love [her]87-elizabeth , than because [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth deserved it . [She]97-lady russell had never received from [her]87-elizabeth more than outward attention , nothing beyond the observances of complaisance ; had never succeeded in any point which [she]97-lady russell wanted to carry , against previous inclination . [She]97-lady russell had been repeatedly very earnest in trying to get [Anne]89-anne included in the visit to [London]6-london , sensibly open to all the injustice and all the discredit of the selfish arrangements which shut [her]97-lady russell out , and on many lesser occasions had endeavoured to give [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth the advantage of [her]87-elizabeth own better judgement and experience ; but always in vain : [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth would go [her]87-elizabeth own way ; and never had [she]87-elizabeth pursued it in more decided opposition to [Lady Russell]97-lady russell than in this selection of [Mrs Clay]101-mrs clay ; turning from the society of so deserving [a sister]1871-a sister , to bestow [her]87-elizabeth affection and confidence on one who ought to have been nothing to [her]87-elizabeth but [the object of distant civility]1872-the object of distant civility . CHAPTER III . “[86-sir walter] [I]0-i must take leave to observe , [Sir Walter]86-sir walter , ” said [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd one morning at [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall , as [he]99-mr shepherd laid down the newspaper , “[86-sir walter] that the present juncture is much in [our]257-our favour . This peace will be turning all [[our]257-our rich naval officers]258-our rich naval officers ashore . [They]258-our rich naval officers will be all wanting [a home]259-a home . Could not be a better time , [Sir Walter]86-sir walter , for having a choice of [tenants]260-tenants , [very responsible tenants]261-very responsible tenants . Many a noble fortune has been made during the war . If [a rich admiral]262-a rich admiral were to come in [our]257-our way , [Sir Walter]86-sir walter — ” “[86-sir walter] [He]262-a rich admiral would be [a very lucky man]263-a very lucky man , [Shepherd]99-mr shepherd , ” replied [Sir Walter]86-sir walter ; “[99-mr shepherd] that ’s all [I]0-i have to remark . A prize indeed would [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall be to [him]262-a rich admiral ; rather the greatest prize of all , let [him]262-a rich admiral have taken ever so many before ; hey , [Shepherd]99-mr shepherd ? ” [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd laughed , as [he]99-mr shepherd knew [he]99-mr shepherd must , at this wit , and then added — “[99-mr shepherd] [I]0-i presume to observe , [Sir Walter]86-sir walter , that , in the way of business , [gentlemen of the navy]264-gentlemen of the navy are well to deal with . [I]0-i have had a little knowledge of [their]264-gentlemen of the navy methods of doing business ; and [I]0-i am free to confess that [they]264-gentlemen of the navy have very liberal notions , and are as likely to make [desirable tenants]265-desirable tenants as [any set of people [one]1726-one should meet with]266-any set of people one should meet with . Therefore , [Sir Walter]86-sir walter , what [I]0-i would take leave to suggest is , that if in consequence of any rumours getting abroad of [your]86-sir walter intention ; which must be contemplated as a possible thing , because [we]268-our know how difficult it is to keep the actions and designs of [one part of [the world]1711-the world]269-one part of the world from the notice and curiosity of the other ; consequence has its tax ; [I]0-i , [John Shepherd]102-john shepherd , might conceal any family - matters that [I]0-i chose , for [nobody]271-nobody would think it worth [their]271-nobody while to observe [me]0-i ; but [Sir Walter Elliot]86-sir walter has eyes upon [him]86-sir walter which it may be very difficult to elude ; and therefore , thus much [I]0-i venture upon , that it will not greatly surprise [me]0-i if , with all [our]268-our caution , some rumour of the truth should get abroad ; in the supposition of which , as [I]0-i was going to observe , since applications will unquestionably follow , [I]0-i should think any from [[our]268-our wealthy naval commanders]272-our wealthy naval commanders particularly worth attending to ; and beg leave to add , that two hours will bring [me]0-i over at any time , to save [you]86-sir walter the trouble of replying . ” [Sir Walter]86-sir walter only nodded . But soon afterwards , rising and pacing [the room]1874-the room , [he]86-sir walter observed sarcastically — “[0-i] There are few among [the gentlemen of the navy]273-the gentlemen of the navy , [I]0-i imagine , who would not be surprised to find [themselves]273-the gentlemen of the navy in [a house of this description]274-a house of this description . ” “[273-the gentlemen of the navy] [They]273-the gentlemen of the navy would look around [them]273-the gentlemen of the navy , no doubt , and bless [their]273-the gentlemen of the navy good fortune , ” said [Mrs Clay]101-mrs clay , for [Mrs Clay]101-mrs clay was present : [[her]101-mrs clay father]1745-her father had driven [her]101-mrs clay over , nothing being of so much use to [Mrs Clay]101-mrs clay ’s health as a drive to [Kellynch]5-kellynch : “[273-the gentlemen of the navy] but [I]0-i quite agree with [[my]0-i father]275-my father in thinking [a sailor]276-a sailor might be [a very desirable tenant]277-a very desirable tenant . [I]0-i have known a good deal of the profession ; and besides [their]278-their liberality , [they]278-their are so neat and careful in all [their]278-their ways ! These valuable pictures of [yours]279-you , [Sir Walter]86-sir walter , if [you]279-you chose to leave them , would be perfectly safe . Everything in and about [the house]1780-the house would be taken such excellent care of ! [The gardens]281-the gardens and shrubberies would be kept in almost as high order as they are now . [You]279-you need not be afraid , [Miss Elliot]89-anne , of [[your]279-you own sweet flower gardens]282-your own sweet flower gardens being neglected . ” “[89-anne] As to all that , ” rejoined [Sir Walter]86-sir walter coolly , “[89-anne] supposing [I]0-i were induced to let [[my]0-i house]283-my house , [I]0-i have by no means made up [my]0-i mind as to the privileges to be annexed to it . [I]0-i am not particularly disposed to favour [a tenant]284-a tenant . [The park]285-the park would be open to [him]284-a tenant of course , and [few navy officers]286-few navy officers , or [men of any other description]287-men of any other description , can have had such a range ; but what restrictions [I]0-i might impose on the use of [the pleasure - grounds]288-the pleasure - grounds , is another thing . [I]0-i am not fond of the idea of [my]0-i shrubberies being always approachable ; and [I]0-i should recommend [Miss Elliot]89-anne to be on [her]89-anne guard with respect to [[her]89-anne flower garden]289-her flower garden . [I]0-i am very little disposed to grant [a tenant of Kellynch Hall]290-a tenant of kellynch hall any extraordinary favour , [I]0-i assure [you]291-you , be [he]290-a tenant of kellynch hall [sailor]292-sailor or [soldier]293-soldier . ” After a short pause , [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd presumed to say — “[0-i] In all these cases , there are established usages which make everything plain and easy between [landlord]294-landlord and [tenant]295-tenant . [Your]291-you interest , [Sir Walter]86-sir walter , is in pretty safe hands . Depend upon [me]0-i for taking care that [no tenant]296-no tenant has more than [his]290-a tenant of kellynch hall just rights . [I]0-i venture to hint , that [Sir Walter Elliot]86-sir walter can not be half so jealous for [his]86-sir walter own , as [John Shepherd]102-john shepherd will be for [him]86-sir walter . ” Here [Anne]89-anne spoke — “[297-the navy] [The navy]297-the navy , [I]0-i think , who have done so much for [us]298-us , have at least an equal claim with [any other set of men]299-any other set of men , for all the comforts and all the privileges which [any home]300-any home can give . [Sailors]301-sailors work hard enough for [their]301-sailors comforts , [we]298-us must all allow . ” “[89-anne] Very true , very true . What [Miss Anne]89-anne says , is very true , ” was [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd ’s rejoinder , and “[89-anne] Oh ! certainly , ” was [[his]99-mr shepherd daughter]1799-his daughter ’s ; but [Sir Walter]86-sir walter ’s remark was , soon afterwards — “[89-anne] The profession has its utility , but [I]0-i should be sorry to see [any friend of mine]302-any friend of mine belonging to it . ” “[0-i] Indeed ! ” was the reply , and with a look of surprise . “[0-i] Yes ; it is in two points offensive to [me]0-i ; [I]0-i have two strong grounds of objection to it . First , as being the means of bringing [persons of obscure birth]303-persons of obscure birth into undue distinction , and raising [men]304-men to honours which [[their]304-men fathers]305-their fathers and [grandfathers]306-grandfathers never dreamt of ; and secondly , as it cuts up [a man]307-a man ’s youth and vigour most horribly ; [a sailor]276-a sailor grows old sooner than [any other man]309-any other man . [I]0-i have observed it all [my]0-i life . [A man]307-a man is in greater danger in the navy of being insulted by the rise of [one whose father , [[his]307-a man father]312-his father might have disdained to speak to , and of becoming prematurely an object of disgust [himself]307-a man , than in any other line]311-one whose father , his father might have disdained to speak to , and of becoming prematurely an object of disgust himself , than in any other line . One day last spring , in [town]1776-town , [I]0-i was in company with [two men]314-two men , striking instances of what [I]0-i am talking of ; [Lord St Ives]103-lord st ives , whose father [we]315-we all know to have been [a country curate , without bread to eat]316-a country curate , without bread to eat ; [I]0-i was to give place to [Lord St Ives]103-lord st ives , and [a certain [Admiral Baldwin]104-admiral baldwin , the most deplorable - looking personage [you]318-you can imagine]317-a certain admiral baldwin , the most deplorable - looking personage you can imagine ; [his]104-admiral baldwin face the colour of mahogany , rough and rugged to the last degree ; all lines and wrinkles , nine grey hairs of a side , and nothing but a dab of powder at top . ‘ In the name of heaven , who is [that old fellow]319-that old fellow ? ’ said [I]0-i to [a friend of [mine]0-i who was standing near]320-a friend of mine who was standing near , ( [Sir Basil Morley]105-sir basil ) . ‘ [Old fellow]321-old fellow ! ’ cried [Sir Basil]105-sir basil , ‘ it is [Admiral Baldwin]104-admiral baldwin . What do [you]105-sir basil take [his]104-admiral baldwin age to be ? ’ ‘ Sixty , ’ said [I]0-i , ‘ or perhaps sixty - two . ’ ‘ Forty , ’ replied [Sir Basil]105-sir basil , ‘ forty , and no more . ’ Picture to [yourselves]322-yourselves [my]0-i amazement ; [I]0-i shall not easily forget [Admiral Baldwin]104-admiral baldwin . [I]0-i never saw quite so wretched an example of what [a sea - faring life]323-a sea - faring life can do ; but to a degree , [I]0-i know it is the same with [them]324-they all : [they]324-they are all knocked about , and exposed to every climate , and every weather , till [they]324-they are not fit to be seen . It is a pity [they]324-they are not knocked on the head at once , before [they]324-they reach [Admiral Baldwin]104-admiral baldwin ’s age . ” “[86-sir walter] Nay , [Sir Walter]86-sir walter , ” cried [Mrs Clay]101-mrs clay , “[86-sir walter] this is being severe indeed . Have a little mercy on [the poor men]325-the poor men . [We]326-we are not all born to be handsome . [The sea]327-the sea is no beautifier , certainly ; [sailors]301-sailors do grow old betimes ; [I]0-i have observed it ; [they]301-sailors soon lose the look of youth . But then , is not it the same with many other professions , perhaps most other ? [Soldiers , in active service]329-soldiers , in active service , are not at all better off : and even in the quieter professions , there is a toil and a labour of the mind , if not of the body , which seldom leaves [a man]307-a man ’s looks to the natural effect of time . [The lawyer]331-the lawyer plods , quite care - worn ; [the physician]332-the physician is up at all hours , and travelling in all weather ; and even [the clergyman]333-the clergyman — ” [she]1877-she stopt a moment to consider what might do for the clergyman;—“and[333-the clergyman] even [the clergyman]333-the clergyman , [you]335-you know is obliged to go into [infected rooms]336-infected rooms , and expose [his]333-the clergyman health and looks to all the injury of a poisonous atmosphere . In fact , as [I]0-i have long been convinced , though every profession is necessary and honourable in its turn , it is only [the lot of those who are not obliged to follow any , who can live in a regular way , in [the country]1758-the country , choosing [their]337-the lot of those who are not obliged to follow any , who can live in a regular way , in the country , choosing their own hours , following their own pursuits , and living on their own property own hours , following [their]337-the lot of those who are not obliged to follow any , who can live in a regular way , in the country , choosing their own hours , following their own pursuits , and living on their own property own pursuits , and living on [[their]337-the lot of those who are not obliged to follow any , who can live in a regular way , in the country , choosing their own hours , following their own pursuits , and living on their own property own property]339-their own property]337-the lot of those who are not obliged to follow any , who can live in a regular way , in the country , choosing their own hours , following their own pursuits , and living on their own property , without the torment of trying for more ; it is only [their]337-the lot of those who are not obliged to follow any , who can live in a regular way , in the country , choosing their own hours , following their own pursuits , and living on their own property lot , [I]0-i say , to hold the blessings of health and a good appearance to the utmost : [I]0-i know [no other set of men]340-no other set of men but what lose something of [their]337-the lot of those who are not obliged to follow any , who can live in a regular way , in the country , choosing their own hours , following their own pursuits , and living on their own property personableness when [they]337-the lot of those who are not obliged to follow any , who can live in a regular way , in the country , choosing their own hours , following their own pursuits , and living on their own property cease to be quite young . ” It seemed as if [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd , in this anxiety to bespeak [Sir Walter]86-sir walter ’s good will towards [a naval officer as tenant]1878-a naval officer as tenant , had been gifted with foresight ; for the very first application for [the house]1780-the house was from [an Admiral Croft]106-admiral croft , with whom [he]99-mr shepherd shortly afterwards fell into company in attending the quarter sessions at [Taunton]11-taunton ; and indeed , [he]99-mr shepherd had received a hint of [the Admiral]1880-the admiral from [a [London]6-london correspondent]1881-a london correspondent . By the report which [he]99-mr shepherd hastened over to [Kellynch]5-kellynch to make , [Admiral Croft]106-admiral croft was [a native of [Somersetshire]2-somersetshire]1882-a native of somersetshire , who having acquired a very handsome fortune , was wishing to settle in [[his]106-admiral croft [own country]1884-own country]1883-his own country , and had come down to [Taunton]11-taunton in order to look at some advertised places in [that immediate neighbourhood]1885-that immediate neighbourhood , which , however , had not suited [him]106-admiral croft ; that accidentally hearing—(it was just as [he]99-mr shepherd had foretold , [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd observed , [Sir Walter]86-sir walter ’s concerns could not be kept a secret,)—accidentally hearing of the possibility of [Kellynch Hall]5-kellynch being to let , and understanding [his]99-mr shepherd ( [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd ’s ) connection with [the owner]1886-the owner , [he]99-mr shepherd had introduced [himself]99-mr shepherd to [him]1886-the owner in order to make particular inquiries , and had , in the course of a pretty long conference , expressed as strong an inclination for the place as [a man who knew it only by description]1887-a man who knew it only by description could feel ; and given [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd , in [his]99-mr shepherd explicit account of [himself]99-mr shepherd , every proof of [his]99-mr shepherd being [a most responsible , eligible tenant]1888-a most responsible , eligible tenant . “[0-i] And who is [Admiral Croft]106-admiral croft ? ” was [Sir Walter]86-sir walter ’s cold suspicious inquiry . [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd answered for [his]99-mr shepherd being of [[a gentleman]1842-a gentleman ’s family]1890-a gentleman ’s family , and mentioned [a place]1891-a place ; and [Anne]89-anne , after the little pause which followed , added — “[106-admiral croft] [He]106-admiral croft is [a rear admiral of the white]341-a rear admiral of the white . [He]106-admiral croft was in the Trafalgar action , and has been in [the East Indies]12-the east indies since ; [he]106-admiral croft was stationed [there]1845-there , [I]0-i believe , several years . ” “[106-admiral croft] Then [I]0-i take it for granted , ” observed [Sir Walter]86-sir walter , “[106-admiral croft] that [his]106-admiral croft face is about as orange as the cuffs and capes of [my]0-i livery . ” [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd hastened to assure [him]99-mr shepherd , that [Admiral Croft]106-admiral croft was [a very hale , hearty , well - looking man]1892-a very hale , hearty , well - looking man , a little weather - beaten , to be sure , but not much , and quite the gentleman in all [his]106-admiral croft notions and behaviour ; not likely to make the smallest difficulty about terms , only wanted [a comfortable home]1893-a comfortable home , and to get into [it]1893-a comfortable home as soon as possible ; knew [he]106-admiral croft must pay for [his]106-admiral croft convenience ; knew what rent [a ready - furnished house of that consequence]1894-a ready - furnished house of that consequence might fetch ; should not have been surprised if [Sir Walter]86-sir walter had asked more ; had inquired about [the manor]1895-the manor ; would be glad of the deputation , certainly , but made no great point of it ; said [he]106-admiral croft sometimes took out a gun , but never killed ; quite [the gentleman]247-the gentleman . [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd was eloquent on the subject ; pointing out all the circumstances of [[the Admiral]1880-the admiral ’s family]1898-the admiral ’s family , which made [him]106-admiral croft peculiarly desirable as [a tenant]284-a tenant . [He]106-admiral croft was [a married man]1900-a married man , and without [children]1901-children ; the very state to be wished for . [A house]249-a house was never taken good care of , [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd observed , without [a lady]1903-a lady : [he]99-mr shepherd did not know , whether furniture might not be in danger of suffering as much where there was [no lady]1904-no lady , as where there were [many children]1905-many children . [A lady]1903-a lady , without [a family]1907-a family , was the very best preserver of furniture in [the world]1711-the world . [He]99-mr shepherd had seen [Mrs Croft]107-mrs croft , too ; [she]107-mrs croft was at [Taunton]11-taunton with [the admiral]1880-the admiral , and had been present almost all the time [they]1910-they were talking the matter over . “[106-admiral croft] And [a very well - spoken , genteel , shrewd lady]343-a very well - spoken , genteel , shrewd lady , [she]343-a very well - spoken , genteel , shrewd lady seemed to be , ” continued [he]99-mr shepherd ; “[343-a very well - spoken , genteel , shrewd lady] asked more questions about [the house]1780-the house , and terms , and taxes , than [the Admiral]1880-the admiral [himself]1880-the admiral , and seemed more conversant with business ; and moreover , [Sir Walter]86-sir walter , [I]0-i found [she]343-a very well - spoken , genteel , shrewd lady was not quite unconnected in [this country]346-this country , any more than [[her]343-a very well - spoken , genteel , shrewd lady husband]347-her husband ; that is to say , [she]343-a very well - spoken , genteel , shrewd lady is sister to [a gentleman who did live amongst [us]349-us once]348-a gentleman who did live amongst us once ; [she]343-a very well - spoken , genteel , shrewd lady told [me]0-i so [herself]343-a very well - spoken , genteel , shrewd lady : sister to [the gentleman who lived a few years back at [Monkford]13-monkford]350-the gentleman who lived a few years back at monkford . Bless [me]0-i ! what was [his]350-the gentleman who lived a few years back at monkford name ? At this moment [I]0-i can not recollect [his]350-the gentleman who lived a few years back at monkford name , though [I]0-i have heard it so lately . [I]0-i shall forget [my]0-i own name soon , [I]0-i suppose . A name that [I]0-i am so very well acquainted with ; knew [the gentleman]247-the gentleman so well by sight ; seen [him]247-the gentleman a hundred times ; came to consult [me]0-i once , [I]0-i remember , about a trespass of [one of [[his]247-the gentleman neighbours]357-his neighbours]356-one of his neighbours ; [[farmer]358-farmer ’s man]359-farmer ’s man breaking into [[his]247-the gentleman orchard]360-his orchard ; wall torn down ; apples stolen ; caught in the fact ; and afterwards , contrary to [my]0-i judgement , submitted to an amicable compromise . Very odd indeed ! ” After waiting another moment — “[361-you] [You]361-you mean [Mr Wentworth]110-mr wentworth , [I]0-i suppose ? ” said [Anne]89-anne . [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd was all gratitude . “[110-mr wentworth] [Wentworth]110-mr wentworth was the very name ! [Mr Wentworth]110-mr wentworth was [the very man]362-the very man . Oh ! ay , [Mr Wentworth]110-mr wentworth , [the curate of [Monkford]13-monkford]366-the curate of monkford . [You]363-you misled [me]0-i by the term [gentleman]367-gentleman . [I]0-i thought [you]363-you were speaking of [some man of property]368-some man of property : [Mr Wentworth]110-mr wentworth was [nobody]271-nobody , [I]0-i remember ; quite unconnected ; nothing to do with [the Strafford family]370-the strafford family . [One]1726-one wonders how the names of many of [[our]372-our nobility]373-our nobility become so common . ” As [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd perceived that this connexion of [the Crofts]111-the crofts did [them]111-the crofts no service with [Sir Walter]86-sir walter , [he]99-mr shepherd mentioned it no more ; returning , with all [his]99-mr shepherd zeal , to dwell on the circumstances more indisputably in [their]111-the crofts favour ; [their]111-the crofts age , and number , and fortune ; the high idea [they]111-the crofts had formed of [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall , and extreme solicitude for the advantage of renting [it]1-kellynch hall ; making it appear as if [they]111-the crofts ranked nothing beyond the happiness of being [the tenants of [Sir Walter Elliot]86-sir walter]1911-the tenants of sir walter elliot : an extraordinary taste , certainly , could [they]111-the crofts have been supposed in the secret of [Sir Walter]86-sir walter ’s estimate of the dues of [a tenant]284-a tenant . It succeeded , however ; and though [Sir Walter]86-sir walter must ever look with an evil eye on anyone intending to inhabit [that house]1913-that house , and think [them]111-the crofts infinitely too well off in being permitted to rent [it]1913-that house on the highest terms , [he]86-sir walter was talked into allowing [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd to proceed in the treaty , and authorising [him]86-sir walter to wait on [Admiral Croft]106-admiral croft , who still remained at [Taunton]11-taunton , and fix a day for [the house]1780-the house being seen . [Sir Walter]86-sir walter was not very wise ; but still [he]86-sir walter had experience enough of [the world]1711-the world to feel , that [a more unobjectionable tenant]1916-a more unobjectionable tenant , in all essentials , than [Admiral Croft]106-admiral croft bid fair to be , could hardly offer . So far went [his]86-sir walter understanding ; and [his]86-sir walter vanity supplied a little additional soothing , in [the Admiral]1880-the admiral ’s situation in life , which was just high enough , and not too high . “[0-i] [I]0-i have let [[my]0-i house]283-my house to [Admiral Croft]106-admiral croft , ” would sound extremely well ; very much better than to [any mere Mr.]1918-any mere mr. — — ; [a Mr.]1919-a mr. ( save , perhaps , [some half dozen in [the nation]1921-the nation]1920-some half dozen in the nation , ) always needs a note of explanation . [An admiral]1922-an admiral speaks [his]1922-an admiral own consequence , and , at the same time , can never make [a baronet]1818-a baronet look small . In all [their]1924-their dealings and intercourse , [Sir Walter Elliot]86-sir walter must ever have the precedence . Nothing could be done without a reference to [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth : but [her]87-elizabeth inclination was growing so strong for a removal , that [she]87-elizabeth was happy to have it fixed and expedited by [a tenant at hand]1925-a tenant at hand ; and not a word to suspend decision was uttered by [her]87-elizabeth . [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd was completely empowered to act ; and no sooner had such an end been reached , than [Anne]89-anne , who had been [a most attentive listener to the whole]1926-a most attentive listener to the whole , left [the room]1874-the room , to seek the comfort of cool air for [her]89-anne flushed cheeks ; and as [she]89-anne walked along [a favourite grove]1928-a favourite grove , said , with a gentle sigh , “[106-admiral croft] A few months more , and [he]375-he , perhaps , may be walking [here]376-here . ” CHAPTER IV . [He]375-he was not [Mr Wentworth]110-mr wentworth , [the former curate of [Monkford]13-monkford]1929-the former curate of monkford , however suspicious appearances may be , but [a Captain [Frederick Wentworth]112-captain wentworth , [his]375-he brother , who being made commander in consequence of the action off [St Domingo]14-st domingo , and not immediately employed , had come into [Somersetshire]2-somersetshire]112-captain wentworth , in the summer of 1806 ; and having [no parent]1930-no parent living , found [a home]259-a home for half a year at [Monkford]13-monkford . [He]375-he was , at that time , [a remarkably fine young man , with a great deal of intelligence , spirit , and brilliancy]1932-a remarkably fine young man , with a great deal of intelligence , spirit , and brilliancy ; and [Anne]89-anne [an extremely pretty girl , with gentleness , modesty , taste , and feeling]1933-an extremely pretty girl , with gentleness , modesty , taste , and feeling . Half the sum of attraction , on either side , might have been enough , for [he]375-he had nothing to do , and [she]89-anne had hardly [anybody to love]1934-anybody to love ; but the encounter of such lavish recommendations could not fail . [They]1935-they were gradually acquainted , and when acquainted , rapidly and deeply in love . It would be difficult to say which had seen highest perfection in the other , or which had been the happiest : [she]89-anne , in receiving [his]375-he declarations and proposals , or [he]375-he in having them accepted . A short period of exquisite felicity followed , and but a short one . Troubles soon arose . [Sir Walter]86-sir walter , on being applied to , without actually withholding [his]86-sir walter consent , or saying it should never be , gave it all the negative of great astonishment , great coldness , great silence , and a professed resolution of doing nothing for [[his]86-sir walter daughter]1799-his daughter . [He]86-sir walter thought it a very degrading alliance ; and [Lady Russell]97-lady russell , though with more tempered and pardonable pride , received it as [a most unfortunate one]1937-a most unfortunate one . [Anne Elliot]89-anne , with all [her]89-anne claims of birth , beauty , and mind , to throw [herself]89-anne away at nineteen ; involve [herself]89-anne at nineteen in an engagement with [a young man]1938-a young man , who had nothing but [himself]1938-a young man to recommend [him]1938-a young man , and [no hopes of attaining affluence , but in the chances of a most uncertain profession]1939-no hopes of attaining affluence , but in the chances of a most uncertain profession , and no connexions to secure even [his]1938-a young man farther rise in the profession , would be , indeed , a throwing away , which [she]89-anne grieved to think of ! [Anne Elliot]89-anne , so young ; known to so few , to be snatched off by [a stranger without alliance or fortune]1940-a stranger without alliance or fortune ; or rather sunk by [him]1938-a young man into [a state of most wearing , anxious , youth - killing dependence]1941-a state of most wearing , anxious , youth - killing dependence ! It must not be , if by any fair interference of friendship , any representations from one who had almost [a mother]1716-a mother ’s love , and [mother]1943-mother ’s rights , it would be prevented . [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth had no fortune . [He]112-captain wentworth had been lucky in [his]112-captain wentworth profession ; but spending freely , what had come freely , had realized nothing . But [he]112-captain wentworth was confident that [he]112-captain wentworth should soon be rich : full of life and ardour , [he]112-captain wentworth knew that [he]112-captain wentworth should soon have [a ship]1944-a ship , and soon be on a station that would lead to everything [he]112-captain wentworth wanted . [He]112-captain wentworth had always been lucky ; [he]112-captain wentworth knew [he]112-captain wentworth should be so still . Such confidence , powerful in its own warmth , and bewitching in the wit which often expressed it , must have been enough for [Anne]89-anne ; but [Lady Russell]97-lady russell saw it very differently . [His]112-captain wentworth sanguine temper , and fearlessness of mind , operated very differently on [her]97-lady russell . [She]97-lady russell saw in it but an aggravation of the evil . It only added a dangerous character to [himself]112-captain wentworth . [He]112-captain wentworth was brilliant , [he]112-captain wentworth was headstrong . [Lady Russell]97-lady russell had little taste for wit , and of anything approaching to imprudence a horror . [She]97-lady russell deprecated the connexion in every light . Such opposition , as these feelings produced , was more than [Anne]89-anne could combat . Young and gentle as [she]97-lady russell was , it might yet have been possible to withstand [[her]97-lady russell father]1745-her father ’s ill - will , though unsoftened by one kind word or look on the part of [[her]97-lady russell sister]1946-her sister ; but [Lady Russell]97-lady russell , whom [she]97-lady russell had always loved and relied on , could not , with such steadiness of opinion , and such tenderness of manner , be continually advising [her]97-lady russell in vain . [She]97-lady russell was persuaded to believe the engagement a wrong thing : indiscreet , improper , hardly capable of success , and not deserving it . But it was not a merely selfish caution , under which [she]97-lady russell acted , in putting an end to it . Had [she]97-lady russell not imagined [herself]97-lady russell consulting [his]112-captain wentworth good , even more than [her]97-lady russell own , [she]97-lady russell could hardly have given [him]112-captain wentworth up . The belief of being prudent , and self - denying , principally for [his]112-captain wentworth advantage , was [her]97-lady russell chief consolation , under the misery of a parting , a final parting ; and every consolation was required , for [she]97-lady russell had to encounter all the additional pain of opinions , on [his]112-captain wentworth side , totally unconvinced and unbending , and of [his]112-captain wentworth feeling [himself]112-captain wentworth ill used by so forced a relinquishment . [He]112-captain wentworth had left [the country]1758-the country in consequence . A few months had seen the beginning and the end of [their]1948-their acquaintance ; but not with a few months ended [Anne]89-anne ’s share of suffering from it . [Her]97-lady russell attachment and regrets had , for a long time , clouded every enjoyment of youth , and an early loss of bloom and spirits had been their lasting effect . More than seven years were gone since this little history of sorrowful interest had reached its close ; and time had softened down much , perhaps nearly all of peculiar attachment to [him]112-captain wentworth , but [she]97-lady russell had been too dependent on time alone ; no aid had been given in change of place ( except in one visit to [Bath]9-bath soon after the rupture ) , or in any novelty or enlargement of society . [No one]1949-no one had ever come within the Kellynch circle , who could bear a comparison with [Frederick Wentworth]112-captain wentworth , as [he]112-captain wentworth stood in [her]97-lady russell memory . No second attachment , the only thoroughly natural , happy , and sufficient cure , at [her]97-lady russell time of life , had been possible to the nice tone of [her]97-lady russell mind , the fastidiousness of [her]97-lady russell taste , in the small limits of the society around [them]1948-their . [She]97-lady russell had been solicited , when about two - and - twenty , to change [her]97-lady russell name , by [the young man]1781-the young man , who not long afterwards found a more willing mind in [[her]97-lady russell younger sister]1951-her younger sister ; and [Lady Russell]97-lady russell had lamented [her]97-lady russell refusal ; for [Charles Musgrove]92-charles was [the eldest son of [a man , whose landed property and general importance were second in [that country]1954-that country , only to [Sir Walter]86-sir walter ’s]1953-a man , whose landed property and general importance were second in that country , only to sir walter ’s , and of good character and appearance]1952-the eldest son of a man , whose landed property and general importance were second in that country , only to sir walter ’s , and of good character and appearance ; and however [Lady Russell]97-lady russell might have asked yet for something more , while [Anne]89-anne was nineteen , [she]97-lady russell would have rejoiced to see [her]89-anne at twenty - two so respectably removed from the partialities and injustice of [[[her]89-anne father]1745-her father ’s house]1866-her father ’s house , and settled so permanently near [herself]89-anne . But in this case , [Anne]89-anne had left nothing for advice to do ; and though [Lady Russell]97-lady russell , as satisfied as ever with [her]97-lady russell own discretion , never wished the past undone , [she]97-lady russell began now to have the anxiety which borders on hopelessness for [Anne]89-anne ’s being tempted , by [some man of talents and independence]1957-some man of talents and independence , to enter a state for which [she]97-lady russell held [her]89-anne to be peculiarly fitted by [her]89-anne warm affections and domestic habits . [They]1958-their knew not [each other]1959-each other ’s opinion , either its constancy or its change , on the one leading point of [Anne]89-anne ’s conduct , for the subject was never alluded to ; but [Anne]89-anne , at seven - and - twenty , thought very differently from what [she]89-anne had been made to think at nineteen . [She]89-anne did not blame [Lady Russell]97-lady russell , [she]89-anne did not blame [herself]89-anne for having been guided by [her]97-lady russell ; but [she]89-anne felt that were [any young person]1960-any young person , in similar circumstances , to apply to [her]89-anne for counsel , [they]1960-any young person would never receive any of such certain immediate wretchedness , such uncertain future good . [She]89-anne was persuaded that under every disadvantage of disapprobation at [home]1756-home , and every anxiety attending [his]1957-some man of talents and independence profession , all [their]1958-their probable fears , delays , and disappointments , [she]89-anne should yet have been [a happier woman]1962-a happier woman in maintaining the engagement , than [she]89-anne had been in the sacrifice of it ; and this , [she]89-anne fully believed , had the usual share , had even more than the usual share of all such solicitudes and suspense been theirs , without reference to the actual results of [their]1958-their case , which , as it happened , would have bestowed earlier prosperity than could be reasonably calculated on . All [his]1957-some man of talents and independence sanguine expectations , all [his]1957-some man of talents and independence confidence had been justified . [His]1957-some man of talents and independence genius and ardour had seemed to foresee and to command [his]1957-some man of talents and independence prosperous path . [He]1957-some man of talents and independence had , very soon after [their]1958-their engagement ceased , got employ : and all that [he]1957-some man of talents and independence had told [her]89-anne would follow , had taken place . [He]1957-some man of talents and independence had distinguished [himself]1957-some man of talents and independence , and early gained the other step in rank , and must now , by successive captures , have made a handsome fortune . [She]89-anne had only navy lists and newspapers for [her]89-anne authority , but [she]89-anne could not doubt [his]1957-some man of talents and independence being rich ; and , in favour of [his]1957-some man of talents and independence constancy , [she]89-anne had no reason to believe [him]1957-some man of talents and independence married . How eloquent could [Anne Elliot]89-anne have been ! how eloquent , at least , were [her]89-anne wishes on the side of early warm attachment , and a cheerful confidence in futurity , against that over - anxious caution which seems to insult exertion and distrust [Providence]113-providence ! [She]89-anne had been forced into prudence in [her]89-anne youth , [she]89-anne learned romance as [she]89-anne grew older : the natural sequel of an unnatural beginning . With all these circumstances , recollections and feelings , [she]89-anne could not hear that [[Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth ’s sister]1963-captain wentworth ’s sister was likely to live at [Kellynch]5-kellynch without a revival of former pain ; and many a stroll , and many a sigh , were necessary to dispel the agitation of the idea . [She]89-anne often told [herself]89-anne it was folly , before [she]89-anne could harden [her]89-anne nerves sufficiently to feel the continual discussion of [the Crofts]111-the crofts and [their]111-the crofts business no evil . [She]89-anne was assisted , however , by that perfect indifference and apparent unconsciousness , among [the only three of [[her]89-anne own friends]1965-her own friends]1964-the only three of her own friends in the secret of the past , which seemed almost to deny any recollection of it . [She]89-anne could do justice to the superiority of [Lady Russell]97-lady russell ’s motives in this , over those of [[her]89-anne father]1745-her father and [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth ; [she]89-anne could honour all the better feelings of [her]89-anne calmness ; but the general air of oblivion among [them]1964-the only three of her own friends was highly important from whatever it sprung ; and in the event of [Admiral Croft]106-admiral croft ’s really taking [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall , [she]89-anne rejoiced anew over the conviction which had always been most grateful to [her]89-anne , of the past being known to [those three only among [her]89-anne connexions]1967-those three only among her connexions , by whom no syllable , [she]89-anne believed , would ever be whispered , and in the trust that among [his]106-admiral croft , [the brother only with whom [he]106-admiral croft had been residing]1968-the brother only with whom he had been residing , had received any information of [their]1969-their short - lived engagement . [That brother]1970-that brother had been long removed from [the country]1758-the country and being [a sensible man]1972-a sensible man , and , moreover , [a single man]1973-a single man at the time , [she]89-anne had a fond dependence on [no human creature]1974-no human creature ’s having heard of it from [him]1970-that brother . [The sister]1975-the sister , [Mrs Croft]107-mrs croft , had then been out of [England]16-england , accompanying [[her]107-mrs croft husband]347-her husband on [a foreign station]1977-a foreign station , and [[her]107-mrs croft own sister]1978-her own sister , [Mary]90-mary , had been at [school]1848-school while it all occurred ; and never admitted by the pride of some , and the delicacy of [others , to the smallest knowledge of it afterwards]1980-others , to the smallest knowledge of it afterwards . With these supports , [she]89-anne hoped that the acquaintance between [herself]89-anne and [the Crofts]111-the crofts , which , with [Lady Russell]97-lady russell , still resident in [Kellynch]5-kellynch , and [Mary]90-mary fixed only three miles off , must be anticipated , need not involve any particular awkwardness . CHAPTER V. On the morning appointed for [Admiral]1981-admiral and [Mrs Croft]107-mrs croft ’s seeing [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall , [Anne]89-anne found it most natural to take [her]89-anne almost daily walk to [[Lady Russell]97-lady russell ’s]1982-lady russell ’s , and keep out of the way till all was over ; when [she]89-anne found it most natural to be sorry that [she]89-anne had missed the opportunity of seeing [them]111-the crofts .
