This meeting of [the two parties]1983-the two parties proved highly satisfactory , and decided the whole business at once . [Each lady]1984-each lady was previously well disposed for an agreement , and saw nothing , therefore , but good manners in the other ; and with regard to [the gentlemen]1985-the gentlemen , there was such an hearty good humour , such an open , trusting liberality on [the Admiral]1880-the admiral ’s side , as could not but influence [Sir Walter]86-sir walter , who had besides been flattered into [his]86-sir walter very best and most polished behaviour by [Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd ’s assurances of [his]86-sir walter being known , by report , to [the Admiral]1880-the admiral , as a model of good breeding . [The house]1780-the house and [grounds]1989-grounds , and furniture , were approved , [the Crofts]111-the crofts were approved , terms , time , every thing , and every body , was right ; and [[Mr Shepherd]99-mr shepherd ’s clerks]1990-mr shepherd ’s clerks were set to work , without there having been a single preliminary difference to modify of all that “[375-he] This indenture sheweth . ” [Sir Walter]86-sir walter , without hesitation , declared [the Admiral]1880-the admiral to be [the best - looking sailor [he]86-sir walter had ever met with]1992-the best - looking sailor he had ever met with , and went so far as to say , that if [[his]86-sir walter own man]1993-his own man might have had the arranging of [his]86-sir walter hair , [he]86-sir walter should not be ashamed of being seen with [him]86-sir walter any where ; and [the Admiral]1880-the admiral , with sympathetic cordiality , observed to [[his]1880-the admiral wife]1699-his wife as [they]377-they drove back through [the park]285-the park , “[375-he] [I]0-i thought [we]377-they should soon come to a deal , [[my]0-i dear]351-my dear , in spite of what [they]379-they told [us]377-they at [Taunton]11-taunton . [The Baronet]380-the baronet will never set [the Thames]17-the thames on fire , but there seems to be no harm in [him]380-the baronet . ”—reciprocal compliments , which would have been esteemed about equal . [The Crofts]111-the crofts were to have possession at [Michaelmas]122-michaelmas ; and as [Sir Walter]86-sir walter proposed removing to [Bath]9-bath in the course of the preceding month , there was no time to be lost in making every dependent arrangement . [Lady Russell]97-lady russell , convinced that [Anne]89-anne would not be allowed to be of any use , or any importance , in the choice of [the house which [they]377-they were going to secure]1997-the house which they were going to secure , was very unwilling to have [her]89-anne hurried away so soon , and wanted to make it possible for [her]89-anne to stay behind till [she]89-anne might convey [her]89-anne to [Bath]9-bath [herself]89-anne after Christmas ; but having engagements of [her]89-anne own which must take [her]89-anne from [Kellynch]5-kellynch for several weeks , [she]89-anne was unable to give the full invitation [she]89-anne wished , and [Anne]89-anne though dreading the possible heats of September in all the white glare of [Bath]9-bath , and grieving to forego all the influence so sweet and so sad of the autumnal months in [the country]1758-the country , did not think that , everything considered , [she]89-anne wished to remain . It would be most right , and most wise , and , therefore must involve least suffering to go with [the others]1828-the others . Something occurred , however , to give [her]89-anne a different duty . [Mary]90-mary , often a little unwell , and always thinking a great deal of [her]90-mary own complaints , and always in the habit of claiming [Anne]89-anne when anything was the matter , was indisposed ; and foreseeing that [she]89-anne should not have a day ’s health all the autumn , entreated , or rather required [her]89-anne , for it was hardly entreaty , to come to [Uppercross Cottage]19-uppercross cottage , and bear [her]89-anne company as long as [she]89-anne should want [her]89-anne , instead of going to [Bath]9-bath . “[0-i] [I]0-i can not possibly do without [Anne]89-anne , ” was [Mary]90-mary ’s reasoning ; and [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth ’s reply was , “[0-i] Then [I]0-i am sure [Anne]89-anne had better stay , for [nobody]271-nobody will want [her]89-anne in [Bath]9-bath . ” To be claimed as a good , though in an improper style , is at least better than being rejected as no good at all ; and [Anne]89-anne , glad to be thought of some use , glad to have anything marked out as a duty , and certainly not sorry to have the scene of it in [the country]1758-the country , and [[her]89-anne own dear country]2001-her own dear country , readily agreed to stay . This invitation of [Mary]90-mary ’s removed all [Lady Russell]97-lady russell ’s difficulties , and it was consequently soon settled that [Anne]89-anne should not go to [Bath]9-bath till [Lady Russell]97-lady russell took [her]89-anne , and that all the intervening time should be divided between [Uppercross Cottage]19-uppercross cottage and [Kellynch Lodge]10-kellynch lodge . So far all was perfectly right ; but [Lady Russell]97-lady russell was almost startled by the wrong of one part of the Kellynch Hall plan , when it burst on [her]97-lady russell , which was , [Mrs Clay]101-mrs clay ’s being engaged to go to [Bath]9-bath with [Sir Walter]86-sir walter and [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth , as [a most important and valuable assistant to the latter in all the business before [her]97-lady russell]2002-a most important and valuable assistant to the latter in all the business before her . [Lady Russell]97-lady russell was extremely sorry that such a measure should have been resorted to at all , wondered , grieved , and feared ; and the affront it contained to [Anne]89-anne , in [Mrs Clay]101-mrs clay ’s being of so much use , while [Anne]89-anne could be of none , was a very sore aggravation . [Anne]89-anne [herself]89-anne was become hardened to such affronts ; but [she]89-anne felt the imprudence of the arrangement quite as keenly as [Lady Russell]97-lady russell . With a great deal of quiet observation , and a knowledge , which [she]89-anne often wished less , of [[her]89-anne father]1745-her father ’s character , [she]89-anne was sensible that results the most serious to [[his]1745-her father family]1698-his family from the intimacy were more than possible . [She]89-anne did not imagine that [[her]89-anne father]1745-her father had at present an idea of the kind . [Mrs Clay]101-mrs clay had freckles , and a projecting tooth , and a clumsy wrist , which [he]1745-her father was continually making severe remarks upon , in [her]101-mrs clay absence ; but [she]101-mrs clay was young , and certainly altogether well - looking , and possessed , in an acute mind and assiduous pleasing manners , infinitely more dangerous attractions than any merely personal might have been . [Anne]89-anne was so impressed by the degree of [their]2006-their danger , that [she]89-anne could not excuse [herself]89-anne from trying to make it perceptible to [[her]89-anne sister]1946-her sister . [She]89-anne had little hope of success ; but [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth , who in the event of such a reverse would be so much more to be pitied than [herself]87-elizabeth , should never , [she]87-elizabeth thought , have reason to reproach [her]87-elizabeth for giving no warning . [She]87-elizabeth spoke , and seemed only to offend . [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth could not conceive how such an absurd suspicion should occur to [her]87-elizabeth , and indignantly answered for [each party]2008-each party ’s perfectly knowing [their]383-their situation . “[271-nobody] [Mrs Clay]101-mrs clay , ” said [she]87-elizabeth , warmly , “[271-nobody] never forgets who [she]101-mrs clay is ; and as [I]0-i am rather better acquainted with [her]101-mrs clay sentiments than [you]382-you can be , [I]0-i can assure [you]382-you , that upon the subject of marriage [they]383-their are particularly nice , and that [she]101-mrs clay reprobates all inequality of condition and rank more strongly than [most people]384-most people . And as to [[my]0-i father]275-my father , [I]0-i really should not have thought that [he]275-my father , who has kept [himself]275-my father single so long for [our]386-our sakes , need be suspected now . If [Mrs Clay]101-mrs clay were [a very beautiful woman]387-a very beautiful woman , [I]0-i grant [you]382-you , it might be wrong to have [her]101-mrs clay so much with [me]0-i ; not that anything in [the world]1711-the world , [I]0-i am sure , would induce [[my]0-i father]275-my father to make a degrading match , but [he]275-my father might be rendered unhappy . But poor [Mrs Clay]101-mrs clay who , with all [her]101-mrs clay merits , can never have been reckoned tolerably pretty , [I]0-i really think poor [Mrs Clay]101-mrs clay may be staying [here]376-here in perfect safety . [One]1726-one would imagine [you]382-you had never heard [[my]0-i father]275-my father speak of [her]101-mrs clay personal misfortunes , though [I]0-i know [you]382-you must fifty times . That tooth of [hers]101-mrs clay and those freckles . Freckles do not disgust [me]0-i so very much as they do [him]275-my father . [I]0-i have known a face not materially disfigured by [a few]393-a few , but [he]275-my father abominates [them]393-a few . [You]382-you must have heard [him]275-my father notice [Mrs Clay]101-mrs clay ’s freckles . ” “[275-my father] There is hardly any personal defect , ” replied [Anne]89-anne , “[275-my father] which an agreeable manner might not gradually reconcile [one]1726-one to . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i think very differently , ” answered [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth , shortly ; “[0-i] an agreeable manner may set off handsome features , but can never alter plain ones . However , at any rate , as [I]0-i have a great deal more at stake on this point than [anybody else]1811-anybody else can have , [I]0-i think it rather unnecessary in [you]382-you to be advising [me]0-i . ” [Anne]89-anne had done ; glad that it was over , and not absolutely hopeless of doing good . [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth , though resenting the suspicion , might yet be made observant by it . The last office of [the four carriage - horses]2009-the four carriage - horses was to draw [Sir Walter]86-sir walter , [Miss Elliot]89-anne , and [Mrs Clay]101-mrs clay to [Bath]9-bath . [The party]2010-the party drove off in very good spirits ; [Sir Walter]86-sir walter prepared with condescending bows for [all [the afflicted tenantry]2012-the afflicted tenantry and cottagers who might have had a hint to show [themselves]2011-all the afflicted tenantry and cottagers who might have had a hint to show themselves]2011-all the afflicted tenantry and cottagers who might have had a hint to show themselves , and [Anne]89-anne walked up at the same time , in a sort of desolate tranquillity , to [the Lodge]2013-the lodge , where [she]89-anne was to spend the first week . [[Her]89-anne friend]2014-her friend was not in better spirits than [herself]89-anne . [Lady Russell]97-lady russell felt this break - up of [the family]1782-the family exceedingly . [Their]1782-the family respectability was as dear to [her]97-lady russell as [her]97-lady russell own , and a daily intercourse had become precious by habit . It was painful to look upon [[their]1782-the family deserted grounds]2016-their deserted grounds , and still worse to anticipate the new hands [they]1782-the family were to fall into ; and to escape the solitariness and the melancholy of so altered [a village]2017-a village , and be out of the way when [Admiral]106-admiral croft and [Mrs Croft]107-mrs croft first arrived , [she]97-lady russell had determined to make [her]97-lady russell own absence from [home]1756-home begin when [she]97-lady russell must give up [Anne]89-anne . Accordingly [their]1782-the family removal was made together , and [Anne]89-anne was set down at [Uppercross Cottage]19-uppercross cottage , in the first stage of [Lady Russell]97-lady russell ’s journey . [Uppercross]3-uppercross was [a moderate - sized village]2019-a moderate - sized village , which a few years back had been completely in the old English style , containing [only [two houses]2021-two houses superior in appearance to those of [the yeomen]2022-the yeomen and [labourers]2023-labourers]2020-only two houses superior in appearance to those of the yeomen and labourers ; [the mansion of [the squire]2025-the squire , with [its]2024-the mansion of the squire , with its high walls , great gates , and old trees , substantial and unmodernized , and the compact , tight parsonage , enclosed in its own neat garden high walls , great gates , and old trees , substantial and unmodernized , and [the compact , tight parsonage]2026-the compact , tight parsonage , enclosed in [its]2024-the mansion of the squire , with its high walls , great gates , and old trees , substantial and unmodernized , and the compact , tight parsonage , enclosed in its own neat garden own neat garden]2024-the mansion of the squire , with its high walls , great gates , and old trees , substantial and unmodernized , and the compact , tight parsonage , enclosed in its own neat garden , with a vine and a pear - tree trained round [its]2024-the mansion of the squire , with its high walls , great gates , and old trees , substantial and unmodernized , and the compact , tight parsonage , enclosed in its own neat garden casements ; but upon the marriage of [the young ’ squire]2027-the young ’ squire , [it]2024-the mansion of the squire , with its high walls , great gates , and old trees , substantial and unmodernized , and the compact , tight parsonage , enclosed in its own neat garden had received the improvement of [a farm - house]2028-a farm - house elevated into [a cottage]2029-a cottage , for [[his]2027-the young ’ squire residence]2030-his residence , and [Uppercross Cottage]19-uppercross cottage , with [its]19-uppercross cottage veranda , French windows , and other prettiness , was quite as likely to catch [the traveller]2031-the traveller ’s eye as the more consistent and considerable aspect and premises of [the Great House]2032-the great house , about a quarter of a mile farther on . Here [Anne]89-anne had often been staying . [She]89-anne knew the ways of [Uppercross]3-uppercross as well as those of [Kellynch]5-kellynch . [The two families]2033-the two families were so continually meeting , so much in the habit of running in and out of [[each other]1959-each other ’s house]2035-each other ’s house at all hours , that it was rather a surprise to [her]89-anne to find [Mary]90-mary alone ; but being alone , [her]90-mary being unwell and out of spirits was almost a matter of course . Though better endowed than [the elder sister]2036-the elder sister , [Mary]90-mary had not [Anne]89-anne ’s understanding nor temper . While well , and happy , and properly attended to , [she]90-mary had great good humour and excellent spirits ; but any indisposition sunk [her]90-mary completely . [She]90-mary had no resources for solitude ; and inheriting a considerable share of the Elliot self - importance , was very prone to add to every other distress that of fancying [herself]90-mary neglected and ill - used . In person , [she]90-mary was inferior to [both sisters]2037-both sisters , and had , even in [her]90-mary bloom , only reached the dignity of being “[396-a fine girl] [a fine girl]396-a fine girl . ” [She]90-mary was now lying on the faded sofa of [the pretty little drawing - room]2038-the pretty little drawing - room , the once elegant furniture of which had been gradually growing shabby , under the influence of four summers and [two children]1867-two children ; and , on [Anne]89-anne ’s appearing , greeted [her]397-you with — “[396-a fine girl] So , [you]397-you are come at last ! [I]0-i began to think [I]0-i should never see [you]397-you . [I]0-i am so ill [I]0-i can hardly speak . [I]0-i have not seen a creature the whole morning ! ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am sorry to find [you]397-you unwell , ” replied [Anne]89-anne . “[0-i] [You]397-you sent [me]0-i such a good account of [yourself]397-you on Thursday ! ” “[397-you] Yes , [I]0-i made the best of it ; [I]0-i always do : but [I]0-i was very far from well at the time ; and [I]0-i do not think [I]0-i ever was so ill in [my]0-i life as [I]0-i have been all this morning : very unfit to be left alone , [I]0-i am sure . Suppose [I]0-i were to be seized of a sudden in some dreadful way , and not able to ring the bell ! So , [Lady Russell]97-lady russell would not get out . [I]0-i do not think [she]97-lady russell has been in [this house]398-this house three times this summer . ” [Anne]89-anne said what was proper , and enquired after [[her]89-anne husband]347-her husband . “[97-lady russell] Oh ! [Charles]92-charles is out shooting . [I]0-i have not seen [him]399-he since seven o’clock . [He]399-he would go , though [I]0-i told [him]399-he how ill [I]0-i was . [He]399-he said [he]399-he should not stay out long ; but [he]399-he has never come back , and now it is almost one . [I]0-i assure [you]400-you , [I]0-i have not seen [a soul]401-a soul this whole long morning . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i have had [[your]0-i little boys]402-your little boys with [you]0-i ? ” “[0-i] Yes , as long as [I]0-i could bear [their]402-your little boys noise ; but [they]402-your little boys are so unmanageable that [they]402-your little boys do [me]0-i more harm than good . [Little Charles]92-charles does not mind a word [I]0-i say , and [Walter]86-sir walter is growing quite as bad . ” “[86-sir walter] Well , [you]400-you will soon be better now , ” replied [Anne]89-anne , cheerfully . “[400-you] [You]400-you know [I]0-i always cure [you]400-you when [I]0-i come . How are [[your]400-you neighbours]403-your neighbours at [the Great House]2032-the great house ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i can give [you]400-you no account of [them]403-your neighbours . [I]0-i have not seen one of [them]403-your neighbours to - day , except [Mr Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove , who just stopped and spoke through the window , but without getting off [his]114-mrs musgrove horse ; and though [I]0-i told [him]114-mrs musgrove how ill [I]0-i was , not one of [them]403-your neighbours have been near [me]0-i . It did not happen to suit [the Miss Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves , [I]0-i suppose , and [they]403-your neighbours never put [themselves]403-your neighbours out of [their]403-your neighbours way . ” “[403-your neighbours] [You]400-you will see [them]403-your neighbours yet , perhaps , before the morning is gone . It is early . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i never want [them]403-your neighbours , [I]0-i assure [you]400-you . [They]403-your neighbours talk and laugh a great deal too much for [me]0-i . Oh ! [Anne]89-anne , [I]0-i am so very unwell ! It was quite unkind of [you]400-you not to come on Thursday . ” “[400-you] [[My]0-i dear]351-my dear [Mary]90-mary , recollect what a comfortable account [you]400-you sent [me]0-i of [yourself]400-you ! [You]400-you wrote in the cheerfullest manner , and said [you]400-you were perfectly well , and in no hurry for [me]0-i ; and that being the case , [you]400-you must be aware that [my]0-i wish would be to remain with [Lady Russell]97-lady russell to the last : and besides what [I]0-i felt on [her]97-lady russell account , [I]0-i have really been so busy , have had so much to do , that [I]0-i could not very conveniently have left [Kellynch]5-kellynch sooner . ” “[0-i] Dear [me]0-i ! what can [you]0-i possibly have to do ? ” “[0-i] A great many things , [I]0-i assure [you]400-you . More than [I]0-i can recollect in a moment ; but [I]0-i can tell [you]400-you some . [I]0-i have been making a duplicate of the catalogue of [[my]0-i father]275-my father ’s books and pictures . [I]0-i have been several times in [the garden]407-the garden with [Mackenzie]116-mackenzie , trying to understand , and make [him]116-mackenzie understand , which of [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth ’s plants are for [Lady Russell]97-lady russell . [I]0-i have had all [my]0-i own little concerns to arrange , books and music to divide , and all [my]0-i trunks to repack , from not having understood in time what was intended as to the waggons : and one thing [I]0-i have had to do , [Mary]90-mary , of a more trying nature : going to [almost every house in [the parish]409-the parish]408-almost every house in the parish , as a sort of take - leave . [I]0-i was told that [they]410-they wished it . But all these things took up a great deal of time . ” “[90-mary] Oh ! well ! ” and after a moment ’s pause , “[90-mary] but [you]90-mary have never asked [me]0-i one word about [our]411-our dinner at [the Pooles]20-the pooles yesterday . ” “[90-mary] Did [you]90-mary go then ? [I]0-i have made no enquiries , because [I]0-i concluded [you]90-mary must have been obliged to give up the party . ” “[0-i] Oh yes ! [I]0-i went . [I]0-i was very well yesterday ; nothing at all the matter with [me]0-i till this morning . It would have been strange if [I]0-i had not gone . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am very glad [you]90-mary were well enough , and [I]0-i hope [you]90-mary had a pleasant party . ” “[0-i] Nothing remarkable . [One]1726-one always knows beforehand what the dinner will be , and who will be [there]1845-there ; and it is so very uncomfortable not having [a carriage]414-a carriage of [one]1726-one ’s own . [Mr]416-mr and [Mrs Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove took [me]0-i , and [we]417-we were so crowded ! [They]418-they are both so very large , and take up so much room ; and [Mr Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove always sits forward . So , there was [I]0-i , crowded into the back seat with [Henrietta]117-henrietta and [Louisa]118-louisa ; and [I]0-i think it very likely that [my]0-i illness to - day may be owing to it . ” A little further perseverance in patience and forced cheerfulness on [Anne]89-anne ’s side produced nearly a cure on [Mary]90-mary ’s . [She]89-anne could soon sit upright on the sofa , and began to hope [she]89-anne might be able to leave it by dinner - time . Then , forgetting to think of it , [she]89-anne was at the other end of [the room]1874-the room , beautifying a nosegay ; then , [she]89-anne ate [her]89-anne cold meat ; and then [she]89-anne was well enough to propose a little walk . “[0-i] Where shall [we]417-we go ? ” said [she]89-anne , when [they]417-we were ready . “[0-i] [I]0-i suppose [you]419-you will not like to call at [the Great House]2032-the great house before [they]421-they have been to see [you]419-you ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i have not the smallest objection on that account , ” replied [Anne]89-anne . “[0-i] [I]0-i should never think of standing on such ceremony with [people]422-people [I]0-i know so well as [Mrs]423-mrs and [the Miss Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves . ” “[115-the miss musgroves] Oh ! but [they]421-they ought to call upon [you]0-i as soon as possible . [They]421-they ought to feel what is due to [you]0-i as [[my]0-i sister]424-my sister . However , [we]425-we may as well go and sit with [them]421-they a little while , and when [we]425-we have that over , [we]425-we can enjoy [our]425-we walk . ” [Anne]89-anne had always thought such a style of intercourse highly imprudent ; but [she]89-anne had ceased to endeavour to check it , from believing that , though there were on each side [continual subjects of offence]2042-continual subjects of offence , [neither family]2043-neither family could now do without it . To [the Great House]2032-the great house accordingly [they]425-we went , to sit the full half hour in [the old - fashioned square parlour , with a small carpet and shining floor , to which [the present daughters of the house]2046-the present daughters of the house]2045-the old - fashioned square parlour , with a small carpet and shining floor , to which the present daughters of the house were gradually giving the proper air of confusion by a grand piano - forte and a harp , flower - stands and little tables placed in every direction . Oh ! could the originals of the portraits against the wainscot , could [the gentlemen in brown velvet]2047-the gentlemen in brown velvet and [the ladies in blue satin]2048-the ladies in blue satin have seen what was going on , have been conscious of such an overthrow of all order and neatness ! The portraits [themselves]425-we seemed to be staring in astonishment . [The Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves , like [[their]115-the miss musgroves houses]2049-their houses , were in a state of alteration , perhaps of improvement . [The father]2050-the father and [mother]1943-mother were in the old English style , and [the young people]2052-the young people in the new . [Mr]2053-mr and [Mrs Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove were [a very good sort of people]2054-a very good sort of people ; friendly and hospitable , not much educated , and not at all elegant . [[Their]115-the miss musgroves children]2055-their children had more modern minds and manners . There was [a numerous family]2056-a numerous family ; but [the only two grown up]2057-the only two grown up , excepting [Charles]92-charles , were [Henrietta]117-henrietta and [Louisa]118-louisa , [young ladies of nineteen and twenty]2058-young ladies of nineteen and twenty , who had brought from [school]1848-school at [Exeter]21-exeter all the usual stock of accomplishments , and were now like thousands of [other young ladies , living to be fashionable , happy , and merry]2060-other young ladies , living to be fashionable , happy , and merry . [Their]115-the miss musgroves dress had every advantage , [their]115-the miss musgroves faces were rather pretty , [their]115-the miss musgroves spirits extremely good , [their]115-the miss musgroves manner unembarrassed and pleasant ; [they]115-the miss musgroves were of consequence at [home]1756-home , and favourites abroad . [Anne]89-anne always contemplated [them]115-the miss musgroves as [some of the happiest creatures of [her]89-anne acquaintance]2062-some of the happiest creatures of her acquaintance ; but still , saved as [we]2063-we all are , by some comfortable feeling of superiority from wishing for the possibility of exchange , [she]89-anne would not have given up [her]89-anne own more elegant and cultivated mind for all [their]115-the miss musgroves enjoyments ; and envied [them]115-the miss musgroves nothing but that seemingly perfect good understanding and agreement together , that good - humoured mutual affection , of which [she]89-anne had known so little [herself]89-anne with [either of [[her]89-anne sisters]1825-her sisters]2064-either of her sisters . [They]115-the miss musgroves were received with great cordiality . Nothing seemed amiss on the side of [the Great House family]2066-the great house family , which was generally , as [Anne]89-anne very well knew , the least to blame . The half hour was chatted away pleasantly enough ; and [she]89-anne was not at all surprised , at the end of it , to have [their]115-the miss musgroves walking party joined by both [the Miss Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves , at [Mary]90-mary ’s particular invitation . CHAPTER VI . [Anne]89-anne had not wanted this visit to [Uppercross]3-uppercross , to learn that a removal from one set of [people]422-people to another , though at a distance of only three miles , will often include a total change of conversation , opinion , and idea . [She]89-anne had never been staying [there]1845-there before , without being struck by it , or without wishing that [other Elliots]2069-other elliots could have [her]89-anne advantage in seeing how unknown , or unconsidered there , were the affairs which at [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall were treated as of such general publicity and pervading interest ; yet , with all this experience , [she]89-anne believed [she]89-anne must now submit to feel that another lesson , in the art of knowing [our]2070-our own nothingness beyond [our]2070-our own circle , was become necessary for [her]89-anne ; for certainly , coming as [she]89-anne did , with a heart full of the subject which had been completely occupying [both houses]2071-both houses in [Kellynch]5-kellynch for many weeks , [she]89-anne had expected rather more curiosity and sympathy than [she]89-anne found in the separate but very similar remark of [Mr]2072-mr and [Mrs Musgrove]92-charles : “[89-anne] So , [Miss Anne]89-anne , [Sir Walter]86-sir walter and [[your]89-anne sister]426-your sister are gone ; and what part of [Bath]1840-bath do [you]89-anne think [they]428-they will settle in ? ” and this , without much waiting for an answer ; or in [the young ladies]2073-the young ladies ’ addition of , “[0-i] [I]0-i hope [we]429-we shall be in [Bath]9-bath in the winter ; but remember , [papa]430-papa , if [we]429-we do go , [we]429-we must be in a good situation : none of [[your]430-papa Queen]431-your queen Squares for [us]429-we ! ” or in the anxious supplement from [Mary]90-mary , of—“Upon[0-i] [my]0-i word , [I]0-i shall be pretty well off , when [you]432-you are all gone away to be happy at [Bath]9-bath ! ” [She]90-mary could only resolve to avoid such self - delusion in future , and think with heightened gratitude of the extraordinary blessing of having [one such truly sympathising friend]2074-one such truly sympathising friend as [Lady Russell]97-lady russell . [The Mr Musgroves]119-the mr musgroves had [their]119-the mr musgroves own game to guard , and to destroy , [their]119-the mr musgroves own horses , dogs , and newspapers to engage [them]119-the mr musgroves , and [the females]2075-the females were fully occupied in all the other common subjects of housekeeping , [neighbours]1724-neighbours , dress , dancing , and music . [She]90-mary acknowledged it to be very fitting , that every little social commonwealth should dictate its own matters of discourse ; and hoped , ere long , to become [a not unworthy member of the one [she]90-mary was now transplanted into]2077-a not unworthy member of the one she was now transplanted into . With the prospect of spending at least two months at [Uppercross]3-uppercross , it was highly incumbent on [her]90-mary to clothe [her]90-mary imagination , [her]90-mary memory , and all [her]90-mary ideas in as much of [Uppercross]3-uppercross as possible . [She]90-mary had no dread of these two months . [Mary]90-mary was not so repulsive and unsisterly as [Elizabeth]87-elizabeth , nor so inaccessible to all influence of [hers]90-mary ; neither was there anything among the other component parts of [the cottage]2078-the cottage inimical to comfort . [She]90-mary was always on friendly terms with [[her]90-mary brother - in - law]2079-her brother - in - law ; and in [the children]2080-the children , who loved [her]90-mary nearly as well , and respected [her]90-mary a great deal more than [[their]2080-the children mother]2081-their mother , [she]90-mary had an object of interest , amusement , and wholesome exertion . [Charles Musgrove]92-charles was civil and agreeable ; in sense and temper [he]2079-her brother - in - law was undoubtedly superior to [[his]2079-her brother - in - law wife]1699-his wife , but not of powers , or conversation , or grace , to make the past , as [they]2083-they were connected together , at all a dangerous contemplation ; though , at the same time , [Anne]89-anne could believe , with [Lady Russell]97-lady russell , that a more equal match might have greatly improved [him]2079-her brother - in - law ; and that [a woman of real understanding]2084-a woman of real understanding might have given more consequence to [his]2079-her brother - in - law character , and more usefulness , rationality , and elegance to [his]2079-her brother - in - law habits and pursuits . As it was , [he]2079-her brother - in - law did nothing with much zeal , but sport ; and [his]2079-her brother - in - law time was otherwise trifled away , without benefit from books or anything else . [He]2079-her brother - in - law had very good spirits , which never seemed much affected by [[his]2079-her brother - in - law wife]1699-his wife ’s occasional lowness , bore with [her]1699-his wife unreasonableness sometimes to [Anne]89-anne ’s admiration , and upon the whole , though there was very often a little disagreement ( in which [she]1699-his wife had sometimes more share than [she]1699-his wife wished , being appealed to by [both parties]2086-both parties ) , [they]2083-they might pass for [a happy couple]2087-a happy couple . [They]2083-they were always perfectly agreed in the want of more money , and a strong inclination for a handsome present from [[his]2079-her brother - in - law father]312-his father ; but here , as on most topics , [he]2079-her brother - in - law had the superiority , for while [Mary]90-mary thought it a great shame that such a present was not made , [he]2079-her brother - in - law always contended for [[his]2079-her brother - in - law father]312-his father ’s having many other uses for [his]2079-her brother - in - law money , and a right to spend it as [he]2079-her brother - in - law liked . As to the management of [[their]2083-they children]2055-their children , [his]2079-her brother - in - law theory was much better than [[his]2079-her brother - in - law wife]1699-his wife ’s , and [his]2079-her brother - in - law practice not so bad . “[0-i] [I]0-i could manage them very well , if it were not for [Mary]90-mary ’s interference , ” was what [Anne]89-anne often heard [him]2079-her brother - in - law say , and had a good deal of faith in ; but when listening in turn to [Mary]90-mary ’s reproach of “[92-charles] [Charles]92-charles spoils [the children]2080-the children so that [I]0-i can not get [them]2080-the children into any order , ” [she]89-anne never had the smallest temptation to say , “[92-charles] Very true . ” One of the least agreeable circumstances of [her]89-anne residence there was [her]89-anne being treated with too much confidence by [all parties]2092-all parties , and being too much in the secret of the complaints of [each house]2093-each house . Known to have some influence with [[her]89-anne sister]1946-her sister , [she]89-anne was continually requested , or at least receiving hints to exert it , beyond what was practicable . “[92-charles] [I]0-i wish [you]434-you could persuade [Mary]90-mary not to be always fancying [herself]90-mary ill , ” was [Charles]92-charles ’s language ; and , in an unhappy mood , thus spoke [Mary]90-mary : “[434-you] [I]0-i do believe if [Charles]92-charles were to see [me]0-i dying , [he]435-he would not think there was anything the matter with [me]0-i . [I]0-i am sure , [Anne]89-anne , if [you]434-you would , [you]434-you might persuade [him]435-he that [I]0-i really am very ill — a great deal worse than [I]0-i ever own . ” [Mary]90-mary ’s declaration was , “[0-i] [I]0-i hate sending [the children]2080-the children to [the Great House]2032-the great house , though [[their]2080-the children grandmamma]438-their grandmamma is always wanting to see [them]2080-the children , for [she]438-their grandmamma humours and indulges [them]2080-the children to such a degree , and gives [them]2080-the children so much trash and sweet things , that [they]2080-the children are sure to come back sick and cross for the rest of the day . ” And [Mrs Musgrove]92-charles took the first opportunity of being alone with [Anne]89-anne , to say , “[89-anne] Oh ! [Miss Anne]89-anne , [I]0-i can not help wishing [Mrs Charles]92-charles had a little of [your]89-anne method with [those children]439-those children . [They]439-those children are quite different creatures with [you]89-anne ! But to be sure , in general they are so spoilt ! It is a pity [you]89-anne can not put [[your]89-anne sister]426-your sister in the way of managing [them]439-those children . [They]439-those children are [as fine healthy children as ever]441-as fine healthy children as ever were seen , [poor little dears]442-poor little dears ! without partiality ; but [Mrs Charles]92-charles knows no more how [they]439-those children should be treated — ! Bless [me]0-i ! how troublesome [they]439-those children are sometimes . [I]0-i assure [you]89-anne , [Miss Anne]89-anne , it prevents [my]0-i wishing to see [them]439-those children at [[our]443-our house]444-our house so often as [I]0-i otherwise should . [I]0-i believe [Mrs Charles]92-charles is not quite pleased with [my]0-i not inviting [them]439-those children oftener ; but [you]89-anne know it is very bad to have [children]1901-children with one that [one]1726-one is obligated to be checking every moment ; “ do n’t do this , ”[1726-one] and “ do n’t do that ; ”[1726-one] or that [one]1726-one can only keep in tolerable order by more cake than is good for [them]439-those children . ” [She]92-charles had this communication , moreover , from [Mary]90-mary . “[92-charles] [Mrs Musgrove]92-charles thinks [all [her]92-charles servants]448-all her servants so steady , that it would be high treason to call it in question ; but [I]0-i am sure , without exaggeration , that [[her]92-charles upper house - maid]449-her upper house - maid and [laundry - maid]450-laundry - maid , instead of being in [their]448-all her servants business , are gadding about [the village]451-the village , all day long . [I]0-i meet [them]448-all her servants wherever [I]0-i go ; and [I]0-i declare , [I]0-i never go twice into [[my]0-i nursery]452-my nursery without seeing something of [them]448-all her servants . If [Jemima]120-jemima were not [the trustiest , steadiest creature in [the world]1711-the world]453-the trustiest , steadiest creature in the world , it would be enough to spoil [her]120-jemima ; for [she]120-jemima tells [me]0-i , [they]448-all her servants are always tempting [her]120-jemima to take a walk with [them]448-all her servants . ” And on [Mrs Musgrove]92-charles ’s side , it was , “[0-i] [I]0-i make a rule of never interfering in any of [[my]0-i daughter - in - law]455-my daughter - in - law ’s concerns , for [I]0-i know it would not do ; but [I]0-i shall tell [you]456-you , [Miss Anne]89-anne , because [you]456-you may be able to set things to rights , that [I]0-i have no very good opinion of [[Mrs Charles]92-charles ’s nursery - maid]457-mrs charles ’s nursery - maid : [I]0-i hear strange stories of [her]457-mrs charles ’s nursery - maid ; [she]457-mrs charles ’s nursery - maid is always upon the gad ; and from [my]0-i own knowledge , [I]0-i can declare , [she]457-mrs charles ’s nursery - maid is such [a fine - dressing lady]458-a fine - dressing lady , that [she]457-mrs charles ’s nursery - maid is enough to ruin [any servants [she]457-mrs charles ’s nursery - maid comes near]459-any servants she comes near . [Mrs Charles]92-charles quite swears by [her]457-mrs charles ’s nursery - maid , [I]0-i know ; but [I]0-i just give [you]456-you this hint , that [you]456-you may be upon the watch ; because , if [you]456-you see anything amiss , [you]456-you need not be afraid of mentioning it . ” Again , it was [Mary]90-mary ’s complaint , that [Mrs Musgrove]92-charles was very apt not to give [her]457-mrs charles ’s nursery - maid the precedence that was [her]457-mrs charles ’s nursery - maid due , when [they]2095-they dined at [the Great House]2032-the great house with [other families]2097-other families ; and [she]457-mrs charles ’s nursery - maid did not see any reason why [she]457-mrs charles ’s nursery - maid was to be considered so much at [home]1756-home as to lose [her]457-mrs charles ’s nursery - maid place . And one day when [Anne]89-anne was walking with only [the Musgroves]119-the mr musgroves , one of [them]119-the mr musgroves after talking of rank , [people of rank]2099-people of rank , and [jealousy of rank]2100-jealousy of rank , said , “[0-i] [I]0-i have no scruple of observing to [you]456-you , how nonsensical [some persons]460-some persons are about [their]460-some persons place , because all [the world]1711-the world knows how easy and indifferent [you]456-you are about it ; but [I]0-i wish [anybody]462-anybody could give [Mary]90-mary a hint that it would be a great deal better if [she]90-mary were not so very tenacious , especially if [she]90-mary would not be always putting [herself]90-mary forward to take place of [mamma]463-mamma . [Nobody]271-nobody doubts [her]271-nobody right to have precedence of [mamma]463-mamma , but it would be more becoming in [her]271-nobody not to be always insisting on it . It is not that [mamma]121-mamma cares about it the least in [the world]1711-the world , but [I]0-i know it is taken notice of by [many persons]467-many persons . ” How was [Anne]89-anne to set all these matters to rights ? [She]89-anne could do little more than listen patiently , soften every grievance , and excuse each to [the other]2101-the other ; give [them]467-many persons all hints of the forbearance necessary between [such near neighbours]2102-such near neighbours , and make those hints broadest which were meant for [[her]89-anne sister]1946-her sister ’s benefit . In all other respects , [her]89-anne visit began and proceeded very well . [Her]89-anne own spirits improved by change of place and subject , by being removed three miles from [Kellynch]5-kellynch ; [Mary]90-mary ’s ailments lessened by having [a constant companion]2104-a constant companion , and [their]467-many persons daily intercourse with [the other family]2105-the other family , since there was neither superior affection , confidence , nor employment in [the cottage]2078-the cottage , to be interrupted by it , was rather an advantage . It was certainly carried nearly as far as possible , for [they]467-many persons met every morning , and hardly ever spent an evening asunder ; but [she]89-anne believed [they]467-many persons should not have done so well without the sight of [Mr]2107-mr and [Mrs Musgrove]92-charles ’s respectable forms in the usual places , or without the talking , laughing , and singing of [[their]467-many persons daughters]2108-their daughters . [She]89-anne played a great deal better than either of [the Miss Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves , but having no voice , no knowledge of the harp , and [no fond parents]2109-no fond parents , to sit by and fancy [themselves]467-many persons delighted , [her]89-anne performance was little thought of , only out of civility , or to refresh [the others]1828-the others , as [she]89-anne was well aware . [She]89-anne knew that when [she]89-anne played [she]89-anne was giving pleasure only to [herself]89-anne ; but this was no new sensation . Excepting one short period of [her]89-anne life , [she]89-anne had never , since the age of fourteen , never since the loss of [[her]89-anne dear mother]2111-her dear mother , known the happiness of being listened to , or encouraged by any just appreciation or real taste . In music [she]89-anne had been always used to feel alone in [the world]1711-the world ; and [Mr]2113-mr and [Mrs Musgrove]92-charles ’s fond partiality for [[their]467-many persons own daughters]2114-their own daughters ’ performance , and total indifference to [any other person]2115-any other person ’s , gave [her]89-anne much more pleasure for [their]467-many persons sakes , than mortification for [her]89-anne own . The party at [the Great House]2032-the great house was sometimes increased by [other company]2117-other company . [The neighbourhood]1752-the neighbourhood was not large , but [the Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves were visited by [everybody]2119-everybody , and had more dinner - parties , and [more callers]2120-more callers , [more visitors]2121-more visitors by invitation and by chance , than [any other family]2122-any other family . [They]467-many persons were more completely popular . [The girls]2123-the girls were wild for dancing ; and the evenings ended , occasionally , in an unpremeditated little ball . There was [a family of [cousins]2125-cousins within a walk of [Uppercross]3-uppercross]2124-a family of cousins within a walk of uppercross , in less affluent circumstances , who depended on [the Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves for all [their]2124-a family of cousins within a walk of uppercross pleasures : [they]2124-a family of cousins within a walk of uppercross would come at any time , and help play at anything , or dance anywhere ; and [Anne]89-anne , very much preferring the office of [musician]2126-musician to a more active post , played country dances to [them]115-the miss musgroves by the hour together ; a kindness which always recommended [her]89-anne musical powers to the notice of Mr and [Mrs Musgrove]92-charles more than anything else , and often drew this compliment;—“Well[89-anne] done , [Miss Anne]89-anne ! very well done indeed ! Lord bless [me]0-i ! how those little fingers of yours fly about ! ” So passed the first three weeks . [Michaelmas]122-michaelmas came ; and now [Anne]89-anne ’s heart must be in [Kellynch]5-kellynch again . [A beloved home]2127-a beloved home made over to [others]1859-others ; all the precious rooms and furniture , groves , and prospects , beginning to own other eyes and other limbs ! [She]89-anne could not think of much else on the 29th of September ; and [she]89-anne had this sympathetic touch in the evening from [Mary , who , on having occasion to note down the day of the month]2129-mary , who , on having occasion to note down the day of the month , exclaimed , “[468-dear] [Dear]468-dear [me]0-i , is not this the day [the Crofts]111-the crofts were to come to [Kellynch]5-kellynch ? [I]0-i am glad [I]0-i did not think of it before . How low it makes [me]0-i ! ” [The Crofts]111-the crofts took possession with true naval alertness , and were to be visited . [Mary]90-mary deplored the necessity for [herself]90-mary . “[271-nobody] [Nobody]271-nobody knew how much [she]271-nobody should suffer . [She]271-nobody should put it off as long as [she]271-nobody could ; ” but was not easy till [she]89-anne had talked [Charles]92-charles into driving [her]89-anne over on an early day , and was in a very animated , comfortable state of imaginary agitation , when [she]89-anne came back . [Anne]89-anne had very sincerely rejoiced in there being no means of [her]89-anne going . [She]89-anne wished , however , to see [the Crofts]111-the crofts , and was glad to be within when the visit was returned . [They]111-the crofts came : [the master of [the house]1780-the house]2130-the master of the house was not at [home]1756-home , but [the two sisters]2133-the two sisters were together ; and as it chanced that [Mrs Croft]107-mrs croft fell to the share of [Anne]89-anne , while [the Admiral]1880-the admiral sat by [Mary]90-mary , and made [himself]1880-the admiral very agreeable by [his]1880-the admiral good - humoured notice of [[her]89-anne little boys]2135-her little boys , [she]89-anne was well able to watch for a likeness , and if it failed [her]89-anne in the features , to catch it in the voice , or in the turn of sentiment and expression . [Mrs Croft]107-mrs croft , though neither tall nor fat , had a squareness , uprightness , and vigour of form , which gave importance to [[her]107-mrs croft person]2136-her person . [She]107-mrs croft had bright dark eyes , good teeth , and altogether an agreeable face ; though [her]107-mrs croft reddened and weather - beaten complexion , the consequence of [her]107-mrs croft having been almost as much at [sea]2137-sea as [[her]107-mrs croft husband]347-her husband , made [her]107-mrs croft seem to have lived some years longer in [the world]1711-the world than [her]107-mrs croft real eight - and - thirty . [Her]107-mrs croft manners were open , easy , and decided , like one who had no distrust of [herself]107-mrs croft , and [no doubts of what to do ; without any approach to coarseness , however , or any want of good humour]2140-no doubts of what to do ; without any approach to coarseness , however , or any want of good humour . [Anne]89-anne gave [her]89-anne credit , indeed , for feelings of great consideration towards [herself]89-anne , in all that related to [Kellynch]5-kellynch , and it pleased [her]89-anne : especially , as [she]89-anne had satisfied [herself]89-anne in the very first half minute , in the instant even of introduction , that there was not the smallest symptom of any knowledge or suspicion on [Mrs Croft]107-mrs croft ’s side , to give a bias of any sort . [She]89-anne was quite easy on that head , and consequently full of strength and courage , till for a moment electrified by [Mrs Croft]107-mrs croft ’s suddenly saying , — “[271-nobody] It was [you]470-you , and not [[your]470-you sister]426-your sister , [I]0-i find , that [[my]0-i brother]472-my brother had the pleasure of being acquainted with , when [he]472-my brother was in [this country]346-this country . ” [Anne]89-anne hoped [she]89-anne had outlived the age of blushing ; but the age of emotion [she]89-anne certainly had not . “[470-you] Perhaps [you]470-you may not have heard that [he]472-my brother is married ? ” added [Mrs Croft]107-mrs croft . [She]89-anne could now answer as [she]89-anne ought ; and was happy to feel , when [Mrs Croft]107-mrs croft ’s next words explained it to be [Mr Wentworth]110-mr wentworth of whom [she]89-anne spoke , that [she]89-anne had said nothing which might not do for [either brother]2141-either brother . [She]89-anne immediately felt how reasonable it was , that [Mrs Croft]107-mrs croft should be thinking and speaking of [Edward]123-edward , and not of [Frederick]112-captain wentworth ; and with shame at [her]89-anne own forgetfulness applied [herself]89-anne to the knowledge of [[their]474-their former neighbour]2142-their former neighbour ’s present state with proper interest . The rest was all tranquillity ; till , just as [they]474-their were moving , [she]89-anne heard [the Admiral]1880-the admiral say to [Mary]90-mary — “[470-you] [We]474-their are expecting [a brother of [Mrs Croft]107-mrs croft ’s]475-a brother of mrs croft ’s here soon ; [I]0-i dare say [you]107-mrs croft know [him]475-a brother of mrs croft ’s by name . ” [He]475-a brother of mrs croft ’s was cut short by the eager attacks of [the little boys]2144-the little boys , clinging to [him]475-a brother of mrs croft ’s like [an old friend]2145-an old friend , and declaring [he]475-a brother of mrs croft ’s should not go ; and being too much engrossed by proposals of carrying [them]2144-the little boys away in [his]475-a brother of mrs croft ’s coat pockets , & c. , to have another moment for finishing or recollecting what [he]475-a brother of mrs croft ’s had begun , [Anne]89-anne was left to persuade [herself]89-anne , as well as [she]89-anne could , that [the same brother]2146-the same brother must still be in question . [She]89-anne could not , however , reach such a degree of certainty , as not to be anxious to hear whether anything had been said on the subject at [the other house]2147-the other house , where [the Crofts]111-the crofts had previously been calling . [The folks of the Great House]2148-the folks of the great house were to spend the evening of this day at [the Cottage]2078-the cottage ; and it being now too late in the year for such visits to be made on foot , [the coach]2150-the coach was beginning to be listened for , when [the youngest Miss Musgrove]118-louisa walked in . That [she]118-louisa was coming to apologize , and that [they]477-they should have to spend the evening by [themselves]477-they , was the first black idea ; and [Mary]90-mary was quite ready to be affronted , when [Louisa]118-louisa made all right by saying , that [she]118-louisa only came on foot , to leave more room for the harp , which was bringing in [the carriage]2151-the carriage . “[475-a brother of mrs croft ’s] And [I]0-i will tell [you]476-you [our]477-they reason , ” [she]118-louisa added , “[0-i] and all about it . [I]0-i am come on to give [you]476-you notice , that [papa]430-papa and [mamma]463-mamma are out of spirits this evening , especially [mamma]463-mamma ; [she]463-mamma is thinking so much of poor [Richard]112-captain wentworth ! And [we]477-they agreed it would be best to have the harp , for it seems to amuse [her]463-mamma more than the piano - forte . [I]0-i will tell [you]476-you why [she]463-mamma is out of spirits . When [the Crofts]111-the crofts called this morning , ( [they]111-the crofts called here afterwards , did not [they]111-the crofts ? ) , [they]111-the crofts happened to say , that [[her]463-mamma brother]481-her brother , [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth , is just returned to [England]16-england , or paid off , or something , and is coming to see [them]111-the crofts almost directly ; and most unluckily it came into [mamma]121-mamma ’s head , when [they]111-the crofts were gone , that [Wentworth]112-captain wentworth , or something very like it , was the name of [poor [Richard]112-captain wentworth ’s captain]482-poor richard ’s captain at one time ; [I]0-i do not know when or where , but a great while before [he]482-poor richard ’s captain died , [poor fellow]483-poor fellow ! And upon looking over [his]482-poor richard ’s captain letters and things , [she]463-mamma found it was so , and is perfectly sure that this must be [the very man]362-the very man , and [her]463-mamma head is quite full of it , and of poor [Richard]112-captain wentworth ! So [we]485-we must be as merry as [we]485-we can , that [she]463-mamma may not be dwelling upon such gloomy things . ” The real circumstances of this pathetic piece of family history were , that [the Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves had had the ill fortune of [a very troublesome , hopeless son]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son ; and the good fortune to lose [him]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son before [he]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son reached [his]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son twentieth year ; that [he]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son had been sent to [sea]2137-sea because [he]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son was stupid and unmanageable on [shore]2154-shore ; that [he]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son had been very little cared for at any time by [[his]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son family]1698-his family , though quite as much as [he]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son deserved ; seldom heard of , and scarcely at all regretted , when the intelligence of [his]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son death abroad had worked its way to [Uppercross]3-uppercross , two years before . [He]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son had , in fact , though [[his]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son sisters]2156-his sisters were now doing all [they]2156-his sisters could for [him]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son , by calling [him]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son “[112-captain wentworth] poor [Richard]112-captain wentworth , ” been nothing better than [a thick - headed , unfeeling , unprofitable [Dick Musgrove]124-dick musgrove , who had never done anything to entitle [himself]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son to more than the abbreviation of [his]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son name , living or dead]124-dick musgrove . [He]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son had been several years at [sea]2137-sea , and had , in the course of those removals to which [all midshipmen]2158-all midshipmen are liable , and especially such midshipmen as [every captain]2159-every captain wishes to get rid of , been six months on board [[Captain Frederick Wentworth]112-captain wentworth ’s frigate]2160-captain frederick wentworth ’s frigate , [the Laconia]22-the laconia ; and from [the Laconia]22-the laconia [he]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son had , under the influence of [[his]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son captain]2161-his captain , written the only two letters which [[his]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son father]312-his father and [mother]1943-mother had ever received from [him]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son during the whole of [his]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son absence ; that is to say , the only two disinterested letters ; all the rest had been mere applications for money . In each letter [he]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son had spoken well of [[his]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son captain]2161-his captain ; but yet , so little were [they]2165-they in the habit of attending to such matters , so unobservant and incurious were [they]2165-they as to the names of [men]304-men or [ships]2167-ships , that it had made scarcely any impression at the time ; and that [Mrs Musgrove]92-charles should have been suddenly struck , this very day , with a recollection of the name of [Wentworth]112-captain wentworth , as connected with [[her]92-charles son]2168-her son , seemed one of those extraordinary bursts of mind which do sometimes occur . [She]92-charles had gone to [her]92-charles letters , and found it all as [she]92-charles supposed ; and the re - perusal of these letters , after so long an interval , [[her]92-charles poor son]2169-her poor son gone for ever , and all the strength of [his]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son faults forgotten , had affected [her]92-charles spirits exceedingly , and thrown [her]92-charles into greater grief for [him]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son than [she]92-charles had known on first hearing of [his]2152-a very troublesome , hopeless son death . [Mr Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove was , in a lesser degree , affected likewise ; and when [they]2165-they reached [the cottage]2078-the cottage , [they]2165-they were evidently in want , first , of being listened to anew on this subject , and afterwards , of all the relief which [cheerful companions]2171-cheerful companions could give [them]2165-they . To hear [them]2165-they talking so much of [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth , repeating [his]112-captain wentworth name so often , puzzling over past years , and at last ascertaining that it might , that it probably would , turn out to be [the very same Captain Wentworth whom [they]2165-they recollected meeting , once or twice , after [their]2165-they coming back from [Clifton]23-clifton]125-captain wentworth — [a very fine young man]2172-a very fine young man — but [they]2165-they could not say whether it was seven or eight years ago , was a new sort of trial to [Anne]89-anne ’s nerves . [She]89-anne found , however , that it was one to which [she]89-anne must inure [herself]89-anne . Since [he]112-captain wentworth actually was expected in [the country]1758-the country , [she]89-anne must teach [herself]89-anne to be insensible on such points . And not only did it appear that [he]112-captain wentworth was expected , and speedily , but [the Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves , in [their]115-the miss musgroves warm gratitude for the kindness [he]112-captain wentworth had shewn [poor Dick]124-dick musgrove , and very high respect for [his]112-captain wentworth character , stamped as it was by [poor [Dick]124-dick musgrove ’s]2174-poor dick ’s having been six months under [his]112-captain wentworth care , and mentioning [him]112-captain wentworth in strong , though not perfectly well - spelt praise , as “[112-captain wentworth] [a fine dashing felow]486-a fine dashing felow , only two perticular about [the schoolmaster]487-the schoolmaster , ” were bent on introducing [themselves]115-the miss musgroves , and seeking [his]112-captain wentworth acquaintance , as soon as [they]115-the miss musgroves could hear of [his]112-captain wentworth arrival . The resolution of doing so helped to form the comfort of [their]115-the miss musgroves evening . CHAPTER VII . A very few days more , and [Captain Wentworth]125-captain wentworth was known to be at [Kellynch]5-kellynch , and [Mr Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove had called on [him]125-captain wentworth , and come back warm in [his]125-captain wentworth praise , and [he]125-captain wentworth was engaged with [the Crofts]2175-the crofts to dine at [Uppercross]3-uppercross , by the end of another week . It had been a great disappointment to [Mr Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove to find that no earlier day could be fixed , so impatient was [he]114-mrs musgrove to shew [his]114-mrs musgrove gratitude , by seeing [Captain Wentworth]125-captain wentworth under [his]125-captain wentworth own roof , and welcoming [him]125-captain wentworth to all that was strongest and best in [[his]125-captain wentworth cellars]2176-his cellars . But a week must pass ; only a week , in [Anne]89-anne ’s reckoning , and then , [she]89-anne supposed , [they]115-the miss musgroves must meet ; and soon [she]89-anne began to wish that [she]89-anne could feel secure even for a week . [Captain Wentworth]125-captain wentworth made a very early return to [Mr Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove ’s civility , and [she]89-anne was all but calling [there]1845-there in the same half hour . [She]89-anne and [Mary]90-mary were actually setting forward for [the Great House]2032-the great house , where , as [she]89-anne afterwards learnt , [they]115-the miss musgroves must inevitably have found [him]125-captain wentworth , when [they]115-the miss musgroves were stopped by [the eldest boy]2179-the eldest boy ’s being at that moment brought [home]1756-home in consequence of a bad fall . [The child]2181-the child ’s situation put the visit entirely aside ; but [she]89-anne could not hear of [her]89-anne escape with indifference , even in the midst of the serious anxiety which [they]115-the miss musgroves afterwards felt on [his]125-captain wentworth account . [His]125-captain wentworth collar - bone was found to be dislocated , and such injury received in the back , as roused the most alarming ideas . It was an afternoon of distress , and [Anne]89-anne had every thing to do at once ; [the apothecary]2182-the apothecary to send for , [the father]2050-the father to have pursued and informed , [the mother]1743-the mother to support and keep from hysterics , [the servants]2185-the servants to control , [the youngest child]2186-the youngest child to banish , and [the poor suffering one to attend and soothe]2187-the poor suffering one to attend and soothe ; besides sending , as soon as [she]89-anne recollected it , proper notice to [the other house]2147-the other house , which brought [her]89-anne an accession rather of [frightened , enquiring companions]2189-frightened , enquiring companions , than of [very useful assistants]2190-very useful assistants . [[Her]89-anne brother]481-her brother ’s return was the first comfort ; [he]481-her brother could take best care of [[his]481-her brother wife]1699-his wife ; and the second blessing was the arrival of [the apothecary]2182-the apothecary . Till [he]125-captain wentworth came and had examined [the child]2181-the child , [their]2195-they apprehensions were the worse for being vague ; [they]2195-they suspected great injury , but knew not where ; but now the collar - bone was soon replaced , and though [Mr Robinson]126-mr robinson felt and felt , and rubbed , and looked grave , and spoke low words both to [the father]2050-the father and [the aunt]2197-the aunt , still [they]2195-they were all to hope the best , and to be able to part and eat [their]2195-they dinner in tolerable ease of mind ; and then it was , just before [they]2195-they parted , that [the two young aunts]2198-the two young aunts were able so far to digress from [[their]2198-the two young aunts nephew]2199-their nephew ’s state , as to give the information of [Captain Wentworth]125-captain wentworth ’s visit ; staying five minutes behind [[their]2195-they father]2200-their father and [mother]1943-mother , to endeavour to express how perfectly delighted [they]2195-they were with [him]125-captain wentworth , how much handsomer , how infinitely more agreeable [they]2195-they thought [him]125-captain wentworth than [any individual among [their]2195-they male acquaintance]2202-any individual among their male acquaintance , who had been at all a favourite before . How glad [they]2195-they had been to hear [papa]430-papa invite [him]125-captain wentworth to stay dinner , how sorry when [he]125-captain wentworth said it was quite out of [his]125-captain wentworth power , and how glad again when [he]125-captain wentworth had promised in reply to [papa]127-papa and [mamma]463-mamma ’s farther pressing invitations to come and dine with [them]2195-they on the morrow — actually on the morrow ; and [he]125-captain wentworth had promised it in so pleasant a manner , as if [he]125-captain wentworth felt all the motive of [their]2195-they attention just as [he]125-captain wentworth ought . And in short , [he]125-captain wentworth had looked and said everything with such exquisite grace , that [they]2195-they could assure [them]2195-they all , [their]2195-they heads were both turned by [him]125-captain wentworth ; and off [they]2195-they ran , quite as full of glee as of love , and apparently more full of [Captain Wentworth]125-captain wentworth than of [little Charles]92-charles . The same story and the same raptures were repeated , when [the two girls]2205-the two girls came with [[their]2205-the two girls father]2200-their father , through the gloom of the evening , to make enquiries ; and [Mr Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove , no longer under the first uneasiness about [[his]114-mrs musgrove heir]2207-his heir , could add [his]114-mrs musgrove confirmation and praise , and hope there would be now no occasion for putting [Captain Wentworth]125-captain wentworth off , and only be sorry to think that [the cottage party]2208-the cottage party , probably , would not like to leave [the little boy]2209-the little boy , to give [him]2209-the little boy the meeting . “[486-a fine dashing felow] Oh no ; as to leaving [the little boy]2209-the little boy , ” both [father]1739-father and [mother]1943-mother were in much too strong and recent alarm to bear the thought ; and [Anne]89-anne , in the joy of the escape , could not help adding [her]89-anne warm protestations to [theirs]490-theirs . [Charles Musgrove]92-charles , indeed , afterwards , [shewed]2212-shewed more of inclination ; “[2209-the little boy] [the child]2181-the child was going on so well , and [he]2181-the child wished so much to be introduced to [Captain Wentworth]125-captain wentworth , that , perhaps , [he]2181-the child might join [them]490-theirs in the evening ; [he]2181-the child would not dine from [home]1756-home , but [he]2181-the child might walk in for half an hour . ” But in this [he]2181-the child was eagerly opposed by [[his]2181-the child wife]1699-his wife , with “[92-charles] Oh ! no , indeed , [Charles]92-charles , [I]0-i can not bear to have [you]92-charles go away . Only think if anything should happen ? ” [The child]2181-the child had a good night , and was going on well the next day . It must be a work of time to ascertain that no injury had been done to the spine ; but [Mr Robinson]126-mr robinson found nothing to increase alarm , and [Charles Musgrove]92-charles began , consequently , to feel no necessity for longer confinement . [The child]2181-the child was to be kept in bed and amused as quietly as possible ; but what was there for [a father]2216-a father to do ? This was quite a female case , and it would be highly absurd in [him]2181-the child , who could be of no use at [home]1756-home , to shut [himself]2181-the child up . [[His]2181-the child father]312-his father very much wished [him]2181-the child to meet [Captain Wentworth]125-captain wentworth , and there being no sufficient reason against it , [he]2181-the child ought to go ; and it ended in [his]2181-the child making a bold , public declaration , when [he]2181-the child came in from [shooting]2219-shooting , of [his]2181-the child meaning to dress directly , and dine at [the other house]2147-the other house . “[92-charles] Nothing can be going on better than [the child]2181-the child , ” said [he]0-i ; “[92-charles] so [I]0-i told [[my]0-i father]275-my father , just now , that [I]0-i would come , and [he]275-my father thought [me]0-i quite right . [[Your]494-you sister]426-your sister being with [you]494-you , [[my]0-i love]496-my love , [I]0-i have no scruple at all . [You]494-you would not like to leave [him]2181-the child [yourself]494-you , but [you]494-you see [I]0-i can be of no use . [Anne]89-anne will send for [me]0-i if anything is the matter . ” [Husbands]2221-husbands and [wives]2222-wives generally understand when opposition will be vain . [Mary]90-mary knew , from [Charles]92-charles ’s manner of speaking , that [he]0-i was quite determined on going , and that it would be of no use to teaze [him]0-i . [She]90-mary said nothing , therefore , till [he]0-i was out of [the room]1874-the room , but as soon as there was only [Anne]89-anne to hear — “[89-anne] So [you]494-you and [I]0-i are to be left to shift by [ourselves]497-ourselves , with [this poor sick child]498-this poor sick child ; and not a creature coming near [us]497-ourselves all the evening ! [I]0-i knew how it would be . This is always [my]0-i luck . If there is anything disagreeable going on [men]304-men are always sure to get out of it , and [Charles]92-charles is as bad as any of [them]304-men . Very unfeeling ! [I]0-i must say it is very unfeeling of [him]0-i to be running away from [[his]0-i poor little boy]500-his poor little boy . Talks of [his]0-i being going on so well ! How does [he]0-i know that [he]0-i is going on well , or that there may not be a sudden change half an hour hence ? [I]0-i did not think [Charles]92-charles would have been so unfeeling . So here [he]0-i is to go away and enjoy [himself]0-i , and because [I]0-i am [the poor mother]501-the poor mother , [I]0-i am not to be allowed to stir ; and yet , [I]0-i am sure , [I]0-i am more unfit than [anybody else]1811-anybody else to be about [the child]2181-the child . [My]0-i being [the mother]1743-the mother is the very reason why [my]0-i feelings should not be tried . [I]0-i am not at all equal to it . [You]0-i saw how hysterical [I]0-i was yesterday . ” “[0-i] But that was only the effect of the suddenness of [your]0-i alarm — of the shock . [You]0-i will not be hysterical again . [I]0-i dare say [we]505-we shall have nothing to distress [us]505-we . [I]0-i perfectly understand [Mr Robinson]126-mr robinson ’s directions , and have no fears ; and indeed , [Mary]90-mary , [I]0-i can not wonder at [[your]90-mary husband]506-your husband . [Nursing]128-nursing does not belong to [a man]307-a man ; it is not [[his]307-a man province]508-his province . [A sick child]509-a sick child is always [[the mother]1743-the mother ’s property]511-the mother ’s property : [her]1743-the mother own feelings generally make it so . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i hope [I]0-i am as fond of [[my]0-i child]512-my child as [any mother]513-any mother , but [I]0-i do not know that [I]0-i am of any more use in [the sick - room]514-the sick - room than [Charles]92-charles , for [I]0-i can not be always scolding and teazing [the poor child]515-the poor child when it is ill ; and [you]516-you saw , this morning , that if [I]0-i told [him]515-the poor child to keep quiet , [he]515-the poor child was sure to begin kicking about . [I]0-i have not nerves for the sort of thing . ” “[0-i] But , could [you]0-i be comfortable [yourself]0-i , to be spending the whole evening away from [the poor boy]517-the poor boy ? ” “[0-i] Yes ; [you]0-i see [[his]517-the poor boy papa]518-his papa can , and why should not [I]0-i ? [Jemima]120-jemima is so careful ; and [she]120-jemima could send [us]519-us word every hour how [he]515-the poor child was . [I]0-i really think [Charles]92-charles might as well have told [[his]517-the poor boy father]312-his father [we]519-us would all come . [I]0-i am not more alarmed about [little Charles]92-charles now than [he]515-the poor child is . [I]0-i was dreadfully alarmed yesterday , but the case is very different to - day . ” “[0-i] Well , if [you]0-i do not think it too late to give notice for [yourself]0-i , suppose [you]0-i were to go , as well as [[your]0-i husband]506-your husband . Leave [little Charles]92-charles to [my]0-i care . [Mr and Mrs Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove can not think it wrong while [I]0-i remain with [him]515-the poor child . ” “[114-mrs musgrove] Are [you]0-i serious ? ” cried [Mary]90-mary , [her]90-mary eyes brightening . “[0-i] Dear [me]0-i ! that ’s a very good thought , very good , indeed . To be sure , [I]0-i may just as well go as not , for [I]0-i am of no use at [home]1756-home — am [I]0-i ? and it only harasses [me]0-i . [You]0-i , who have not [a mother]1716-a mother ’s feelings , are [a great deal the properest person]524-a great deal the properest person . [You]0-i can make [little Charles]92-charles do anything ; [he]515-the poor child always minds [you]0-i at a word . It will be a great deal better than leaving [him]515-the poor child only with [Jemima]120-jemima . Oh ! [I]0-i shall certainly go ; [I]0-i am sure [I]0-i ought if [I]0-i can , quite as much as [Charles]92-charles , for [they]525-they want [me]0-i excessively to be acquainted with [Captain Wentworth]125-captain wentworth , and [I]0-i know [you]0-i do not mind being left alone . An excellent thought of [yours]0-i , indeed , [Anne]89-anne . [I]0-i will go and tell [Charles]92-charles , and get ready directly . [You]0-i can send for [us]526-us , [you]0-i know , at a moment ’s notice , if anything is the matter ; but [I]0-i dare say there will be nothing to alarm [you]0-i . [I]0-i should not go , [you]0-i may be sure , if [I]0-i did not feel quite at ease about [[my]0-i dear child]527-my dear child . ” The next moment [she]89-anne was tapping at [[her]89-anne husband]347-her husband ’s dressing - room door , and as [Anne]89-anne followed [her]89-anne up [stairs]2225-stairs , [she]89-anne was in time for the whole conversation , which began with [Mary]90-mary ’s saying , in a tone of great exultation — “[0-i] [I]0-i mean to go with [you]92-charles , [Charles]92-charles , for [I]0-i am of no more use at [home]1756-home than [you]92-charles are . If [I]0-i were to shut [myself]0-i up for ever with [the child]2181-the child , [I]0-i should not be able to persuade [him]2181-the child to do anything [he]2181-the child did not like . [Anne]89-anne will stay ; [Anne]89-anne undertakes to stay at [home]1756-home and take care of [him]2181-the child . It is [Anne]89-anne ’s own proposal , and so [I]0-i shall go with [you]92-charles , which will be a great deal better , for [I]0-i have not dined at [the other house]2147-the other house since Tuesday . ” “[89-anne] This is very kind of [Anne]89-anne , ” was [[her]89-anne husband]347-her husband ’s answer , “[89-anne] and [I]0-i should be very glad to have [you]89-anne go ; but it seems rather hard that [she]89-anne should be left at [home]1756-home by [herself]89-anne , to nurse [[our]533-them sick child]534-our sick child . ” [Anne]89-anne was now at hand to take up [her]89-anne own cause , and the sincerity of [her]89-anne manner being soon sufficient to convince [him]347-her husband , where conviction was at least very agreeable , [he]347-her husband had no farther scruples as to [her]89-anne being left to dine alone , though [he]347-her husband still wanted [her]89-anne to join [them]533-them in the evening , when [the child]2181-the child might be at rest for the night , and kindly urged [her]89-anne to let [him]347-her husband come and fetch [her]89-anne , but [she]89-anne was quite unpersuadable ; and this being the case , [she]89-anne had ere long the pleasure of seeing [them]533-them set off together in high spirits . [They]533-them were gone , [she]89-anne hoped , to be happy , however oddly constructed such happiness might seem ; as for [herself]89-anne , [she]89-anne was left with as many sensations of comfort , as were , perhaps , ever likely to be [hers]89-anne . [She]89-anne knew [herself]89-anne to be of the first utility to [the child]2181-the child ; and what was it to [her]89-anne if [Frederick Wentworth]112-captain wentworth were only half a mile distant , making [himself]112-captain wentworth agreeable to [others]1859-others ? [She]89-anne would have liked to know how [he]112-captain wentworth felt as to a meeting . Perhaps indifferent , if indifference could exist under such circumstances . [He]112-captain wentworth must be either indifferent or unwilling . Had [he]112-captain wentworth wished ever to see [her]89-anne again , [he]112-captain wentworth need not have waited till this time ; [he]112-captain wentworth would have done what [she]89-anne could not but believe that in [his]112-captain wentworth place [she]89-anne should have done long ago , when events had been early giving [him]112-captain wentworth the independence which alone had been wanting . [[Her]89-anne brother]481-her brother and [sister]1740-sister came back delighted with [their]2232-they new acquaintance , and [their]2232-they visit in general . There had been music , singing , talking , laughing , all that was most agreeable ; charming manners in [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth , no shyness or reserve ; [they]2232-they seemed all to know [each other]1959-each other perfectly , and [he]112-captain wentworth was coming the very next morning to shoot with [Charles]92-charles . [He]112-captain wentworth was to come to breakfast , but not at [the Cottage]2078-the cottage , though that had been proposed at first ; but then [he]112-captain wentworth had been pressed to come to [the Great House]2032-the great house instead , and [he]112-captain wentworth seemed afraid of being in [Mrs Charles Musgrove]92-charles ’s way , on account of [the child]2181-the child , and therefore , somehow , [they]2232-they hardly knew how , it ended in [Charles]92-charles ’s being to meet [him]112-captain wentworth to breakfast at [[his]112-captain wentworth father]312-his father ’s . [Anne]89-anne understood it . [He]112-captain wentworth wished to avoid seeing [her]89-anne . [He]112-captain wentworth had inquired after [her]89-anne , [she]89-anne found , slightly , as might suit [a former slight acquaintance]2238-a former slight acquaintance , seeming to acknowledge such as [she]89-anne had acknowledged , actuated , perhaps , by the same view of escaping introduction when [they]2232-they were to meet . The morning hours of [the Cottage]2078-the cottage were always later than those of [the other house]2147-the other house , and on the morrow the difference was so great that [Mary]90-mary and [Anne]89-anne were not more than beginning breakfast when [Charles]92-charles came in to say that [they]2232-they were just setting off , that [he]112-captain wentworth was come for [his]112-captain wentworth dogs , that [[his]112-captain wentworth sisters]2156-his sisters were following with [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth ; [[his]112-captain wentworth sisters]2156-his sisters meaning to visit [Mary]90-mary and [the child]2181-the child , and [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth proposing also to wait on [her]89-anne for a few minutes if not inconvenient ; and though [Charles]92-charles had answered for [the child]2181-the child ’s being in no such state as could make it inconvenient , [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth would not be satisfied without [his]112-captain wentworth running on to give notice . [Mary]90-mary , very much gratified by this attention , was delighted to receive [him]112-captain wentworth , while a thousand feelings rushed on [Anne]89-anne , of which this was the most consoling , that it would soon be over . And it was soon over . In two minutes after [Charles]92-charles ’s preparation , [the others]1828-the others appeared ; [they]1828-the others were in [the drawing - room]1801-the drawing - room .
