[Her]90-mary eye half met [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth ’s , a bow , a curtsey passed ; [she]90-mary heard [his]112-captain wentworth voice ; [he]112-captain wentworth talked to [Mary]90-mary , said all that was right , said something to [the Miss Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves , enough to mark an easy footing ; [the room]1874-the room seemed full , full of [persons]2248-persons and voices , but a few minutes ended it . [Charles]92-charles shewed [himself]92-charles at the window , all was ready , [[their]1828-the others visitor]2249-their visitor had bowed and was gone , [the Miss Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves were gone too , suddenly resolving to walk to [the end of [the village]451-the village]2250-the end of the village with [the sportsmen]2252-the sportsmen : [the room]1874-the room was cleared , and [Anne]89-anne might finish [her]89-anne breakfast as [she]89-anne could . “[89-anne] It is over ! it is over ! ” [she]90-mary repeated to [herself]90-mary again and again , in nervous gratitude . “[89-anne] The worst is over ! ” [Mary]90-mary talked , but [she]90-mary could not attend . [She]90-mary had seen [him]2254-him . [They]2255-they had met . [They]2255-they had been once more in [the same room]2256-the same room . Soon , however , [she]90-mary began to reason with [herself]90-mary , and try to be feeling less . Eight years , almost eight years had passed , since all had been given up . How absurd to be resuming the agitation which such an interval had banished into distance and indistinctness ! What might not eight years do ? Events of every description , changes , alienations , removals — all , all must be comprised in it , and oblivion of the past — how natural , how certain too ! It included nearly a third part of [her]90-mary own life . Alas ! with all [her]90-mary reasoning , [she]90-mary found , that to retentive feelings eight years may be little more than nothing . Now , how were [his]2254-him sentiments to be read ? Was this like wishing to avoid [her]90-mary ? And the next moment [she]90-mary was hating [herself]90-mary for the folly which asked the question . On one other question which perhaps [her]90-mary utmost wisdom might not have prevented , [she]90-mary was soon spared all suspense ; for , after [the Miss Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves had returned and finished [their]115-the miss musgroves visit at [the Cottage]2078-the cottage [she]90-mary had this spontaneous information from [Mary]90-mary : — “[112-captain wentworth] [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth is not very gallant by [you]535-you , [Anne]89-anne , though [he]112-captain wentworth was so attentive to [me]0-i . [Henrietta]117-henrietta asked [him]112-captain wentworth what [he]112-captain wentworth thought of [you]535-you , when [they]536-they went away , and [he]112-captain wentworth said , ‘ [You]535-you were so altered [he]112-captain wentworth should not have known [you]535-you again . ’ ” [Mary]90-mary had no feelings to make [her]90-mary respect [[her]90-mary sister]1946-her sister ’s in a common way , but [she]90-mary was perfectly unsuspicious of being inflicting any peculiar wound . “[112-captain wentworth] Altered beyond [his]112-captain wentworth knowledge . ” [Anne]89-anne fully submitted , in silent , deep mortification . Doubtless it was so , and [she]89-anne could take no revenge , for [he]112-captain wentworth was not altered , or not for the worse . [She]89-anne had already acknowledged it to [herself]89-anne , and [she]89-anne could not think differently , let [him]112-captain wentworth think of [her]89-anne as [he]112-captain wentworth would . No : the years which had destroyed [her]89-anne youth and bloom had only given [him]112-captain wentworth a more glowing , manly , open look , in no respect lessening [his]112-captain wentworth personal advantages . [She]89-anne had seen the same [Frederick Wentworth]112-captain wentworth . “[112-captain wentworth] So altered that [he]112-captain wentworth should not have known [her]537-her again ! ” These were words which could not but dwell with [her]89-anne . Yet [she]89-anne soon began to rejoice that [she]89-anne had heard them . [They]2259-they were of sobering tendency ; they allayed agitation ; [they]2259-they composed , and consequently must make [her]89-anne happier . [Frederick Wentworth]112-captain wentworth had used such words , or something like them , but without an idea that they would be carried round to [her]89-anne . [He]112-captain wentworth had thought [her]89-anne wretchedly altered , and in the first moment of appeal , had spoken as [he]112-captain wentworth felt . [He]112-captain wentworth had not forgiven [Anne Elliot]89-anne . [She]89-anne had used [him]112-captain wentworth ill , deserted and disappointed [him]112-captain wentworth ; and worse , [she]89-anne had shewn a feebleness of character in doing so , which [his]112-captain wentworth own decided , confident temper could not endure . [She]89-anne had given [him]112-captain wentworth up to oblige [others]1859-others . It had been the effect of over - persuasion . It had been weakness and timidity . [He]112-captain wentworth had been most warmly attached to [her]89-anne , and had never seen [a woman since whom [he]112-captain wentworth thought [her]89-anne equal]2261-a woman since whom he thought her equal ; but , except from some natural sensation of curiosity , [he]112-captain wentworth had no desire of meeting [her]89-anne again . [Her]89-anne power with [him]112-captain wentworth was gone for ever . It was now [his]112-captain wentworth object to marry . [He]112-captain wentworth was rich , and being turned on [shore]2154-shore , fully intended to settle as soon as [he]112-captain wentworth could be properly tempted ; actually looking round , ready to fall in love with all the speed which a clear head and a quick taste could allow . [He]112-captain wentworth had a heart for either of [the Miss Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves , if [they]115-the miss musgroves could catch it ; a heart , in short , for [any pleasing young woman who came in [his]112-captain wentworth way]2263-any pleasing young woman who came in his way , excepting [Anne Elliot]89-anne . This was [his]112-captain wentworth only secret exception , when [he]112-captain wentworth said to [[his]112-captain wentworth sister]2264-his sister , in answer to [her]2264-his sister suppositions : — “[112-captain wentworth] Yes , here [I]0-i am , [Sophia]129-sophy , quite ready to make a foolish match . [Anybody between fifteen and thirty]538-anybody between fifteen and thirty may have [me]0-i for asking . A little beauty , and a few smiles , and a few compliments to [the navy]297-the navy , and [I]0-i am [a lost man]540-a lost man . Should not this be enough for [a sailor , who has had no society among [women]542-women]541-a sailor , who has had no society among women to make [him]541-a sailor , who has had no society among women nice ? ” [He]112-captain wentworth said it , [she]129-sophy knew , to be contradicted . [His]112-captain wentworth bright proud eye spoke the conviction that [he]112-captain wentworth was nice ; and [Anne Elliot]89-anne was not out of [his]112-captain wentworth thoughts , when [he]112-captain wentworth more seriously described [the woman [he]112-captain wentworth should wish to meet with]2265-the woman he should wish to meet with . “[0-i] A strong mind , with sweetness of manner , ” made the first and the last of the description . “[0-i] That is [the woman [I]0-i want]543-the woman i want , ” said [he]112-captain wentworth . “[543-the woman i want] Something a little inferior [I]0-i shall of course put up with , but it must not be much . If [I]0-i am [a fool]544-a fool , [I]0-i shall be [a fool]544-a fool indeed , for [I]0-i have thought on the subject more than [most men]546-most men . ” CHAPTER VIII . From this time [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth and [Anne Elliot]89-anne were repeatedly in the same circle . [They]2266-they were soon dining in company together at [[Mr Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove ’s]2267-mr musgrove ’s , for [the little boy]2209-the little boy ’s state could no longer supply [[his]2209-the little boy aunt]2269-his aunt with a pretence for absenting [herself]2269-his aunt ; and this was but the beginning of other dinings and other meetings . Whether former feelings were to be renewed must be brought to the proof ; former times must undoubtedly be brought to the recollection of each ; [they]2266-they could not but be reverted to ; the year of [their]2266-they engagement could not but be named by [him]2209-the little boy , in the little narratives or descriptions which conversation called forth . [His]2209-the little boy profession qualified [him]2209-the little boy , [his]2209-the little boy disposition lead [him]2209-the little boy , to talk ; and “[0-i] That was in the year six ; ” “[0-i] That happened before [I]0-i went to [sea]2137-sea in the year six , ” occurred in the course of the first evening [they]2266-they spent together : and though [his]2209-the little boy voice did not falter , and though [she]89-anne had no reason to suppose [his]2209-the little boy eye wandering towards [her]89-anne while [he]2209-the little boy spoke , [Anne]89-anne felt the utter impossibility , from [her]89-anne knowledge of [his]2209-the little boy mind , that [he]2209-the little boy could be unvisited by remembrance any more than [herself]89-anne . There must be the same immediate association of thought , though [she]89-anne was very far from conceiving it to be of equal pain . [They]2266-they had no conversation together , no intercourse but what the commonest civility required . Once so much to [each other]1959-each other ! Now nothing ! There had been a time , when of [all the large party now filling [the drawing - room at [Uppercross]3-uppercross]2272-the drawing - room at uppercross]2271-all the large party now filling the drawing - room at uppercross , [they]2266-they would have found it most difficult to cease to speak to [one another]2273-one another . With the exception , perhaps , of [Admiral]106-admiral croft and [Mrs Croft]107-mrs croft , who seemed particularly attached and happy , ( [Anne]89-anne could allow no other exceptions even among [the married couples]2274-the married couples ) , there could have been [no two hearts so open , no tastes so similar , no feelings so in unison]2275-no two hearts so open , no tastes so similar , no feelings so in unison , no countenances so beloved . Now [they]2266-they were as [strangers]2276-strangers ; nay , worse than [strangers]2276-strangers , for [they]2266-they could never become acquainted . It was a perpetual estrangement . When [he]2209-the little boy talked , [she]89-anne heard the same voice , and discerned the same mind . There was a very general ignorance of all naval matters throughout [the party]2010-the party ; and [he]2209-the little boy was very much questioned , and especially by [the two Miss Musgroves]2279-the two miss musgroves , who seemed hardly to have any eyes but for [him]2209-the little boy , as to the manner of living on board , daily regulations , food , hours , & c. , and [their]2279-the two miss musgroves surprise at [his]2209-the little boy accounts , at learning the degree of accommodation and arrangement which was practicable , drew from [him]2209-the little boy some pleasant ridicule , which reminded [Anne]89-anne of the early days when [she]89-anne too had been ignorant , and [she]89-anne too had been accused of supposing [sailors]301-sailors to be living on board without anything to eat , or [any cook to dress it if there were]2281-any cook to dress it if there were , or [any servant to wait , or any knife and fork to use]2282-any servant to wait , or any knife and fork to use . From thus listening and thinking , [she]89-anne was roused by a whisper of [Mrs Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove ’s who , overcome by fond regrets , could not help saying — “[0-i] Ah ! [Miss Anne]89-anne , if it had pleased [Heaven]130-heaven to spare [[my]0-i poor son]548-my poor son , [I]0-i dare say [he]548-my poor son would have been just such another by this time . ” [Anne]89-anne suppressed a smile , and listened kindly , while [Mrs Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove relieved [her]89-anne heart a little more ; and for a few minutes , therefore , could not keep pace with the conversation of [the others]1828-the others . When [she]89-anne could let [her]89-anne attention take its natural course again , [she]89-anne found [the Miss Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves just fetching the Navy List ( [[their]549-their own navy]2284-their own navy list , the first that had ever been at [Uppercross]3-uppercross ) , and sitting down together to pore over it , with the professed view of finding out [the ships that [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth had commanded]2285-the ships that captain wentworth had commanded . “[89-anne] [Your]89-anne first was [the Asp]131-the asp , [I]0-i remember ; [we]549-their will look for [the Asp]131-the asp . ” “[89-anne] [You]89-anne will not find [her]131-the asp [there]1845-there . Quite worn out and broken up . [I]0-i was [the last man who commanded [her]131-the asp]551-the last man who commanded her . [Hardly fit for service]552-hardly fit for service then . [Reported fit for home service]553-reported fit for home service for a year or two , and so [I]0-i was sent off to [the West Indies]25-the west indies . ” [The girls]2123-the girls looked all amazement . “[26-the admiralty] [The Admiralty]26-the admiralty , ” [he]0-i continued , “[26-the admiralty] entertain [themselves]26-the admiralty now and then , with sending [a few hundred men]554-a few hundred men to [sea]2137-sea , in [a ship not fit to be employed]556-a ship not fit to be employed . But [they]26-the admiralty have a great many to provide for ; and among [the thousands that may just as well go to the bottom as not]557-the thousands that may just as well go to the bottom as not , it is impossible for [them]26-the admiralty to distinguish [the very set who may be least missed]558-the very set who may be least missed . ” “[564-lucky fellow] Phoo ! phoo ! ” cried [the Admiral]1880-the admiral , “[564-lucky fellow] what stuff [these young fellows]559-these young fellows talk ! Never was [a better sloop than [the Asp]561-the asp in [her]131-the asp day]560-a better sloop than the asp in her day . For [an old built sloop]562-an old built sloop , [you]563-you would not see [her]131-the asp equal . [Lucky fellow]564-lucky fellow to get [her]131-the asp ! [He]564-lucky fellow knows there must have been [twenty better men than [himself]564-lucky fellow]565-twenty better men than himself applying for [her]131-the asp at the same time . [Lucky fellow]564-lucky fellow to get anything so soon , with no more interest than [his]564-lucky fellow . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i felt [my]0-i luck , [Admiral]106-admiral croft , [I]0-i assure [you]106-admiral croft ; ” replied [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth , seriously . “[0-i] [I]0-i was as well satisfied with [my]0-i appointment as [you]106-admiral croft can desire . It was a great object with [me]0-i at that time to be at [sea]2137-sea ; a very great object , [I]0-i wanted to be doing something . ” “[0-i] To be sure [you]106-admiral croft did . What should [a young fellow like [you]106-admiral croft]568-a young fellow like you do ashore for half a year together ? If [a man]307-a man had not [a wife]570-a wife , [he]307-a man soon wants to be afloat again . ” “[307-a man] But , [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth , ” cried [Louisa]118-louisa , “[112-captain wentworth] how vexed [you]112-captain wentworth must have been when [you]112-captain wentworth came to [the Asp]561-the asp , to see what an old thing [they]572-they had given [you]112-captain wentworth . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i knew pretty well what [she]561-the asp was before that day ; ” said [he]0-i , smiling . “[0-i] [I]0-i had no more discoveries to make than [you]106-admiral croft would have as to the fashion and strength of any old pelisse , which [you]106-admiral croft had seen lent about among half [your]106-admiral croft acquaintance ever since [you]106-admiral croft could remember , and which at last , on some very wet day , is lent to [yourself]106-admiral croft . Ah ! [she]561-the asp was a dear old Asp to [me]0-i . [She]561-the asp did all that [I]0-i wanted . [I]0-i knew [she]561-the asp would . [I]0-i knew that [we]573-our should either go to the bottom together , or that [she]561-the asp would be the making of [me]0-i ; and [I]0-i never had two days of foul weather all the time [I]0-i was at [sea]2137-sea in [her]561-the asp ; and after taking [privateers]575-privateers enough to be very entertaining , [I]0-i had the good luck in [my]0-i passage [home]1756-home the next autumn , to fall in with [the very French frigate [I]0-i wanted]577-the very french frigate i wanted . [I]0-i brought [her]561-the asp into [Plymouth]27-plymouth ; and here another instance of luck . [We]573-our had not been six hours in [the Sound]578-the sound , when a gale came on , which lasted four days and nights , and which would have done for [poor old Asp]131-the asp in half the time ; [our]573-our touch with [the Great Nation]132-the great nation not having much improved [our]573-our condition . Four - and - twenty hours later , and [I]0-i should only have been a gallant [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth , in a small paragraph at one corner of the newspapers ; and being lost in only [a sloop]579-a sloop , [nobody]271-nobody would have thought about [me]0-i . ” [Anne]89-anne ’s shudderings were to [herself]89-anne alone ; but [the Miss Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves could be as open as [they]115-the miss musgroves were sincere , in [their]115-the miss musgroves exclamations of pity and horror . “[0-i] And so then , [I]0-i suppose , ” said [Mrs Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove , in a low voice , as if thinking aloud , “[0-i] so then [he]112-captain wentworth went away to [the Laconia]22-the laconia , and there [he]112-captain wentworth met with [[our]573-our poor boy]581-our poor boy . [Charles]92-charles , [[my]0-i dear]351-my dear , ” ( beckoning [him]0-i to [her]1943-mother ) , “[92-charles] do ask [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth where it was [he]112-captain wentworth first met with [[your]92-charles poor brother]583-your poor brother . [I]0-i always forgot . ” “[0-i] It was at [Gibraltar]28-gibraltar , [mother]1943-mother , [I]0-i know . [Dick]124-dick musgrove had been left ill at [Gibraltar]28-gibraltar , with a recommendation from [[his]124-dick musgrove former captain]585-his former captain to [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth . ” “[112-captain wentworth] Oh ! but , [Charles]92-charles , tell [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth , [he]112-captain wentworth need not be afraid of mentioning [poor Dick]124-dick musgrove before [me]0-i , for it would be rather a pleasure to hear [him]112-captain wentworth talked of by [such a good friend]586-such a good friend . ” [Charles]92-charles , being somewhat more mindful of the probabilities of the case , only nodded in reply , and walked away . [The girls]2123-the girls were now hunting for [the Laconia]22-the laconia ; and [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth could not deny [himself]112-captain wentworth the pleasure of taking the precious volume into [his]112-captain wentworth own hands to save [them]2123-the girls the trouble , and once more read aloud the little statement of [her]587-her name and rate , and [present non - commissioned class]2289-present non - commissioned class , observing over it that [she]587-her too had been one of [the best friends man ever had]2290-the best friends man ever had . “[112-captain wentworth] Ah ! those were pleasant days when [I]0-i had [the Laconia]22-the laconia ! How fast [I]0-i made money in [her]587-her . [A friend of mine]588-a friend of mine and [I]0-i had such a lovely cruise together off [the Western Islands]29-the western islands . [Poor Harville]133-poor harville , [sister]1740-sister ! [You]1740-sister know how much [he]133-poor harville wanted money : worse than [myself]0-i . [He]133-poor harville had [a wife]570-a wife . [Excellent fellow]591-excellent fellow . [I]0-i shall never forget [his]133-poor harville happiness . [He]133-poor harville felt it all , so much for [her]570-a wife sake . [I]0-i wished for [him]133-poor harville again the next summer , when [I]0-i had still the same luck in [the Mediterranean]30-the mediterranean . ” “[0-i] And [I]0-i am sure , [Sir]592-sir , ” said [Mrs Musgrove]92-charles , “[0-i] it was a lucky day for [us]593-us , when [you]592-sir were put [captain]594-captain into [that ship]595-that ship . [We]593-us shall never forget what [you]592-sir did . ” [Her]92-charles feelings made [her]92-charles speak low ; and [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth , hearing only in part , and probably not having [Dick Musgrove]124-dick musgrove at all near [his]112-captain wentworth thoughts , looked rather in suspense , and as if waiting for more . “[592-sir] [[My]0-i brother]472-my brother , ” whispered [one of [the girls]2123-the girls]2291-one of the girls ; “[592-sir] [mamma]463-mamma is thinking of poor [Richard]112-captain wentworth . ” “[112-captain wentworth] [Poor dear fellow]598-poor dear fellow ! ” continued [Mrs Musgrove]92-charles ; “[598-poor dear fellow] [he]598-poor dear fellow was grown so steady , and such [an excellent correspondent]599-an excellent correspondent , while [he]598-poor dear fellow was under [your]592-sir care ! Ah ! it would have been a happy thing , if [he]598-poor dear fellow had never left [you]592-sir . [I]0-i assure [you]592-sir , [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth , [we]600-we are very sorry [he]598-poor dear fellow ever left [you]592-sir . ” There was a momentary expression in [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth ’s face at this speech , a certain glance of [his]112-captain wentworth bright eye , and curl of [his]112-captain wentworth handsome mouth , which convinced [Anne]89-anne , that instead of sharing in [Mrs Musgrove]92-charles ’s kind wishes , as to [[her]92-charles son]2168-her son , [he]112-captain wentworth had probably been at some pains to get rid of [him]2168-her son ; but it was too transient an indulgence of self - amusement to be detected by [any who understood [him]112-captain wentworth less than [herself]92-charles]2294-any who understood him less than herself ; in another moment [he]112-captain wentworth was perfectly collected and serious , and almost instantly afterwards coming up to the sofa , on which [she]92-charles and [Mrs Musgrove]92-charles were sitting , took a place by [the latter]2295-the latter , and entered into conversation with [her]92-charles , in a low voice , about [[her]92-charles son]2168-her son , doing it with so much sympathy and natural grace , as [shewed]2297-shewed the kindest consideration for all that was real and unabsurd in [the parent]2298-the parent ’s feelings . [They]2299-they were actually on the same sofa , for [Mrs Musgrove]92-charles had most readily made room for [him]112-captain wentworth ; [they]2299-they were divided only by [Mrs Musgrove]92-charles . It was no insignificant barrier , indeed . [Mrs Musgrove]92-charles was of a comfortable , substantial size , infinitely more fitted by nature to express good cheer and good humour , than tenderness and sentiment ; and while the agitations of [Anne]89-anne ’s slender form , and pensive face , may be considered as very completely screened , [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth should be allowed some credit for the self - command with which [he]112-captain wentworth attended to [her]92-charles large fat sighings over the destiny of [a son]2300-a son , whom alive [nobody had cared for]2301-nobody had cared for . Personal size and mental sorrow have certainly no necessary proportions . [A large bulky figure]2302-a large bulky figure has as good a right to be in deep affliction , as the most graceful set of limbs in [the world]1711-the world . But , fair or not fair , there are unbecoming conjunctions , which reason will patronize in vain — which taste can not tolerate — which ridicule will seize . [The Admiral]1880-the admiral , after taking two or three refreshing turns about [the room]1874-the room with [his]1880-the admiral hands behind [him]1880-the admiral , being called to order by [[his]1880-the admiral wife]1699-his wife , now came up to [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth , and without any observation of what [he]1880-the admiral might be interrupting , thinking only of [his]1880-the admiral own thoughts , began with — “[0-i] If [you]601-you had been a week later at [Lisbon]31-lisbon , last spring , [Frederick]112-captain wentworth , [you]601-you would have been asked to give a passage to [Lady Mary Grierson]90-mary and [[her]90-mary daughters]1721-her daughters . ” “[0-i] Should [I]0-i ? [I]0-i am glad [I]0-i was not a week later then . ” [The Admiral]1880-the admiral abused [him]112-captain wentworth for [his]0-i want of gallantry . [He]0-i defended [himself]0-i ; though professing that [he]0-i would never willingly admit [any ladies on board [a ship]1944-a ship of [his]0-i]2308-any ladies on board a ship of his , excepting for a ball , or a visit , which a few hours might comprehend . “[0-i] But , if [I]0-i know [myself]0-i , ” said [he]0-i , “[0-i] this is from no want of gallantry towards [them]603-them . It is rather from feeling how impossible it is , with [all one]604-all one ’s efforts , and [all one]604-all one ’s sacrifices , to make the accommodations on board such as [women]542-women ought to have . There can be no want of gallantry , [Admiral]1981-admiral , in rating the claims of [women]542-women to every personal comfort high , and this is what [I]0-i do . [I]0-i hate to hear of [women on board]609-women on board , or to see [them]609-women on board on board ; and [no ship under [my]0-i command]610-no ship under my command shall ever convey [a family of ladies]611-a family of ladies anywhere , if [I]0-i can help it . ” This brought [[his]0-i sister]2264-his sister upon [him]0-i . “[112-captain wentworth] Oh ! [Frederick]112-captain wentworth ! But [I]0-i can not believe it of [you.—All idle refinement!—Women]612-you.—all idle refinement!—women may be as comfortable on board , as in [the best house in [England]16-england]613-the best house in england . [I]0-i believe [I]0-i have lived as much on board as [most women]614-most women , and [I]0-i know nothing superior to the accommodations of [a man - of - war]615-a man - of - war . [I]0-i declare [I]0-i have not a comfort or an indulgence about [me]0-i , even at [Kellynch Hall]1-kellynch hall , ” ( with a kind bow to [Anne]89-anne ) , “[0-i] beyond what [I]0-i always had in most of [the ships [I]0-i have lived in]616-the ships i have lived in ; and [they]616-the ships i have lived in have been five altogether . ” “[616-the ships i have lived in] Nothing to the purpose , ” replied [[her]89-anne brother]481-her brother . “[616-the ships i have lived in] [You]0-i were living with [[your]0-i husband]506-your husband , and were [the only woman on board]618-the only woman on board . ” “[0-i] But [you]0-i , [yourself]0-i , brought [Mrs Harville]134-mrs harville , [[her]134-mrs harville sister]1946-her sister , [[her]134-mrs harville cousin]620-her cousin , and [three children]621-three children , round from [Portsmouth]32-portsmouth to [Plymouth]27-plymouth . Where was this superfine , extraordinary sort of gallantry of [yours]0-i then ? ” “[0-i] All merged in [my]0-i friendship , [Sophia]129-sophy . [I]0-i would assist [[any brother officer]622-any brother officer ’s wife]623-any brother officer ’s wife that [I]0-i could , and [I]0-i would bring anything of [Harville]134-mrs harville ’s from [the world]1711-the world ’s end , if [he]622-any brother officer wanted it . But do not imagine that [I]0-i did not feel it an evil in itself . ” “[0-i] Depend upon it , [they]625-they were all perfectly comfortable . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i might not like [them]625-they the better for that perhaps . [Such a number of [women]542-women and [children]1901-children]626-such a number of women and children have no right to be comfortable on board . ” “[0-i] [[My]0-i dear]351-my dear [Frederick]112-captain wentworth , [you]112-captain wentworth are talking quite idly . Pray , what would become of [[us]630-we [poor sailors]632-poor sailors ’ wives]631-us poor sailors ’ wives , who often want to be conveyed to [one port]633-one port or another , after [[our]630-we husbands]634-our husbands , if [everybody]2119-everybody had [your]112-captain wentworth feelings ? ” “[0-i] [My]0-i feelings , [you]112-captain wentworth see , did not prevent [my]0-i taking [Mrs Harville]134-mrs harville and all [[her]134-mrs harville family]636-her family to [Plymouth]27-plymouth . ” “[112-captain wentworth] But [I]0-i hate to hear [you]112-captain wentworth talking so like [a fine gentleman]637-a fine gentleman , and as if [women]542-women were [all fine ladies]639-all fine ladies , instead of [rational creatures]640-rational creatures . [We]630-we none of [us]630-we expect to be in smooth water all [our]630-we days . ” “[630-we] Ah ! [[my]0-i dear]351-my dear , ” said [the Admiral]1880-the admiral , “[630-we] when [he]642-he has got [a wife]570-a wife , [he]642-he will sing a different tune . When [he]642-he is married , if [we]630-we have the good luck to live to another war , [we]630-we shall see [him]642-he do as [you]112-captain wentworth and [I]0-i , and [a great many others]644-a great many others , have done . [We]630-we shall have [him]642-he very thankful to anybody that will bring [him]642-he [[his]642-he wife]1699-his wife . ” “[630-we] Ay , that [we]630-we shall . ” “[630-we] Now [I]0-i have done , ” cried [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth . “[0-i] When once [married people]646-married people begin to attack [me]0-i with,—‘Oh ! [you]112-captain wentworth will think very differently , when [you]112-captain wentworth are married . ’ [I]0-i can only say , ‘ No , [I]0-i shall not ; ’ and then [they]646-married people say again , ‘ Yes , [you]112-captain wentworth will , ’ and there is an end of it . ” [He]0-i got up and moved away . “[646-married people] What [a great traveller]647-a great traveller [you]112-captain wentworth must have been , [ma’am]648-ma’am ! ” said [Mrs Musgrove]92-charles to [Mrs Croft]107-mrs croft . “[648-ma’am] Pretty well , [ma’am]648-ma’am , in the fifteen years of [my]0-i marriage ; though [many women]650-many women have done more . [I]0-i have crossed [the Atlantic]651-the atlantic four times , and have been once to [the East Indies]12-the east indies , and back again , and only once ; besides being in different places about [home]1756-home : [Cork]33-cork , and [Lisbon]31-lisbon , and [Gibraltar]28-gibraltar . But [I]0-i never went beyond [the Streights]34-the streights , and never was in [the West Indies]25-the west indies . [We]653-we do not call [Bermuda]35-bermuda or [Bahama]36-bahama , [you]112-captain wentworth know , [the West Indies]25-the west indies . ” [Mrs Musgrove]92-charles had not a word to say in dissent ; [she]92-charles could not accuse [herself]92-charles of having ever called [them]2313-them anything in the whole course of [her]92-charles life . “[653-we] And [I]0-i do assure [you]112-captain wentworth , [ma’am]648-ma’am , ” pursued [Mrs Croft]107-mrs croft , “[0-i] that nothing can exceed the accommodations of [a man - of - war]615-a man - of - war ; [I]0-i speak , [you]112-captain wentworth know , of the higher rates . When [you]112-captain wentworth come to [a frigate]656-a frigate , of course , [you]112-captain wentworth are more confined ; though [any reasonable woman]657-any reasonable woman may be perfectly happy in one of [them]656-a frigate ; and [I]0-i can safely say , that the happiest part of [my]0-i life has been spent on board [a ship]1944-a ship . While [we]659-we were together , [you]112-captain wentworth know , there was nothing to be feared . Thank [God]135-god ! [I]0-i have always been blessed with excellent health , and no climate disagrees with [me]0-i . A little disordered always the first twenty - four hours of going to [sea]2137-sea , but never knew what sickness was afterwards . The only time [I]0-i ever really suffered in body or mind , the only time that [I]0-i ever fancied [myself]0-i unwell , or had any ideas of danger , was the winter that [I]0-i passed by [myself]0-i at [Deal]37-deal , when [the Admiral]1880-the admiral ( [Captain Croft]136-captain croft then ) was in [the North Seas]38-the north seas . [I]0-i lived in perpetual fright at that time , and had all manner of imaginary complaints from not knowing what to do with [myself]0-i , or when [I]0-i should hear from [him]1880-the admiral next ; but as long as [we]659-we could be together , nothing ever ailed [me]0-i , and [I]0-i never met with the smallest inconvenience . ” “[0-i] Aye , to be sure . Yes , indeed , oh yes ! [I]0-i am quite of [your]662-your opinion , [Mrs Croft]107-mrs croft , ” was [Mrs Musgrove]92-charles ’s hearty answer . “[107-mrs croft] There is nothing so bad as a separation . [I]0-i am quite of [your]662-your opinion . [I]0-i know what it is , for [Mr Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove always attends the assizes , and [I]0-i am so glad when they are over , and [he]114-mrs musgrove is safe back again . ” The evening ended with dancing . On its being proposed , [Anne]89-anne offered [her]89-anne services , as usual ; and though [her]89-anne eyes would sometimes fill with tears as [she]89-anne sat at the instrument , [she]89-anne was extremely glad to be employed , and desired nothing in return but to be unobserved . It was a merry , joyous party , and [no one]1949-no one seemed in higher spirits than [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth . [She]89-anne felt that [he]112-captain wentworth had every thing to elevate [him]112-captain wentworth which general attention and deference , and especially the attention of all [the young women]2315-the young women , could do . [The Miss Hayters]137-the hayters , [the females of the family of [cousins already mentioned]2317-cousins already mentioned]2316-the females of the family of cousins already mentioned , were apparently admitted to the honour of being in love with [him]112-captain wentworth ; and as for [Henrietta]117-henrietta and [Louisa]118-louisa , [they]2316-the females of the family of cousins already mentioned both seemed so entirely occupied by [him]112-captain wentworth , that nothing but the continued appearance of the most perfect good - will between [themselves]2316-the females of the family of cousins already mentioned could have made it credible that [they]2316-the females of the family of cousins already mentioned were [not decided rivals]2318-not decided rivals . If [he]112-captain wentworth were a little spoilt by such universal , such eager admiration , who could wonder ? These were some of the thoughts which occupied [Anne]89-anne , while [her]89-anne fingers were mechanically at work , proceeding for half an hour together , equally without error , and without consciousness . Once [she]89-anne felt that [he]112-captain wentworth was looking at [herself]89-anne , observing [her]89-anne altered features , perhaps , trying to trace in them the ruins of the face which had once charmed [him]112-captain wentworth ; and once [she]89-anne knew that [he]112-captain wentworth must have spoken of [her]89-anne ; [she]89-anne was hardly aware of it , till [she]89-anne heard the answer ; but then [she]89-anne was sure of [his]112-captain wentworth having asked [[his]112-captain wentworth partner]2319-his partner whether [Miss Elliot]89-anne never danced ? The answer was , “[107-mrs croft] Oh , no ; never ; [she]663-she has quite given up dancing . [She]663-she had rather play . [She]663-she is never tired of playing . ” Once , too , [he]112-captain wentworth spoke to [her]89-anne . [She]89-anne had left the instrument on the dancing being over , and [he]112-captain wentworth had sat down to try to make out an air which [he]112-captain wentworth wished to give [the Miss Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves an idea of . Unintentionally [she]89-anne returned to that part of [the room]1874-the room ; [he]112-captain wentworth saw [her]89-anne , and , instantly rising , said , with studied politeness — “[663-she] [I]0-i beg [your]663-she pardon , [madam]664-madam , this is [your]663-she seat ; ” and though [she]89-anne immediately drew back with a decided negative , [he]112-captain wentworth was not to be induced to sit down again . [Anne]89-anne did not wish for more of such looks and speeches . [His]112-captain wentworth cold politeness , [his]112-captain wentworth ceremonious grace , were worse than anything . [CHAPTER IX]138-chapter ix . [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth was come to [Kellynch]5-kellynch as to [a home]259-a home , to stay as long as [he]112-captain wentworth liked , being as thoroughly the object of [the Admiral]1880-the admiral ’s fraternal kindness as of [[his]112-captain wentworth wife]1699-his wife ’s . [He]112-captain wentworth had intended , on first arriving , to proceed very soon into [Shropshire]39-shropshire , and visit [the brother]2324-the brother settled in [that country]1954-that country , but the attractions of [Uppercross]3-uppercross induced [him]112-captain wentworth to put this off . There was so much of friendliness , and of flattery , and of everything most bewitching in [his]112-captain wentworth reception [there]1845-there ; [the old]2327-the old were so hospitable , [the young]2328-the young so agreeable , that [he]112-captain wentworth could not but resolve to remain where [he]112-captain wentworth was , and take all the charms and perfections of [[Edward]123-edward ’s wife]2329-edward ’s wife upon credit a little longer . It was soon [Uppercross]139-uppercross with [him]112-captain wentworth almost every day . [The Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves could hardly be more ready to invite than [he]112-captain wentworth to come , particularly in the morning , when [he]112-captain wentworth had [no companion]2330-no companion at [home]1756-home , for [the Admiral]106-admiral croft and [Mrs Croft]107-mrs croft were generally out of doors together , interesting [themselves]115-the miss musgroves in [their]115-the miss musgroves new possessions , [their]115-the miss musgroves grass , and [their]115-the miss musgroves sheep , and dawdling about in a way not endurable to [a third person]2332-a third person , or driving out in a gig , lately added to [their]115-the miss musgroves establishment . Hitherto there had been but one opinion of [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth among [the Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves and [[their]115-the miss musgroves dependencies]2333-their dependencies . It was unvarying , warm admiration everywhere ; but this intimate footing was not more than established , when [a certain [Charles Hayter]91-charles]2334-a certain charles hayter returned among [them]115-the miss musgroves , to be a good deal disturbed by it , and to think [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth very much in the way . [Charles Hayter]91-charles was [the eldest of [all the cousins]2336-all the cousins]2335-the eldest of all the cousins , and [a very amiable , pleasing young man , between whom and [Henrietta]117-henrietta]2337-a very amiable , pleasing young man , between whom and henrietta there had been a considerable appearance of attachment previous to [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth ’s introduction . [He]91-charles was in orders ; and having a curacy in [the neighbourhood]1752-the neighbourhood , where residence was not required , lived at [[[his]91-charles father]312-his father ’s house]2340-his father ’s house , only two miles from [Uppercross]3-uppercross . A short absence from [home]1756-home had left [[his]91-charles fair one]2342-his fair one unguarded by [his]91-charles attentions at this critical period , and when [he]91-charles came back [he]91-charles had the pain of finding very altered manners , and of seeing [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth . [Mrs Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove and [Mrs Hayter]140-mrs hayter were [sisters]2343-sisters . [They]2343-sisters had each had money , but [their]2343-sisters marriages had made a material difference in [their]2343-sisters degree of consequence . [Mr Hayter]141-mr hayter had some property of [his]141-mr hayter own , but it was insignificant compared with [Mr Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove ’s ; and while [the Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves were in [the first class of society in [the country]1758-the country]2344-the first class of society in the country , [the young Hayters]2346-the young hayters would , from [[their]2346-the young hayters parents]2347-their parents ’ inferior , retired , and unpolished way of living , and [their]2346-the young hayters own defective education , have been hardly in any class at all , but for [their]2346-the young hayters connexion with [Uppercross]3-uppercross , [this eldest son of course excepted]2348-this eldest son of course excepted , who had chosen to be [a scholar]2349-a scholar and [a gentleman]1842-a gentleman , and who was very superior in cultivation and manners to [all the rest]2351-all the rest . [The two families]2033-the two families had always been on excellent terms , there being no pride on one side , and no envy on the other , and only such a consciousness of superiority in [the Miss Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves , as made [them]2346-the young hayters pleased to improve [[their]2346-the young hayters cousins]2353-their cousins . [Charles]91-charles ’s attentions to [Henrietta]117-henrietta had been observed by [[her]117-henrietta father]1745-her father and [mother]1943-mother without any disapprobation . “[663-she] It would not be a great match for [her]665-her ; but if [Henrietta]117-henrietta liked [him,”—and Henrietta]117-henrietta did seem to like [him]91-charles . [Henrietta]117-henrietta fully thought so [herself]117-henrietta , before [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth came ; but from that time [Cousin Charles]142-cousin charles had been very much forgotten . Which of [the two sisters]2133-the two sisters was preferred by [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth was as yet quite doubtful , as far as [Anne]89-anne ’s observation reached . [Henrietta]117-henrietta was perhaps the prettiest , [Louisa]118-louisa had the higher spirits ; and [she]118-louisa knew not now , whether the more gentle or the more lively character were most likely to attract [him]91-charles . [Mr]2357-mr and [Mrs Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove , either from seeing little , or from an entire confidence in the discretion of both [[their]2358-them daughters]2108-their daughters , and of [all the young men who came near [them]2358-them]2360-all the young men who came near them , seemed to leave everything to take its chance . There was not the smallest appearance of solicitude or remark about [them]2358-them in [the Mansion - house]2361-the mansion - house ; but it was different at [the Cottage]2078-the cottage : [the young couple there]2363-the young couple there were more disposed to speculate and wonder ; and [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth had not been above four or five times in [[the Miss Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves ’ company]2364-the miss musgroves ’ company , and [Charles Hayter]91-charles had but just reappeared , when [Anne]89-anne had to listen to the opinions of [[her]89-anne brother]481-her brother and sister , as to which was the one liked best . [Charles]91-charles gave it for [Louisa]118-louisa , [Mary]90-mary for [Henrietta]117-henrietta , but quite agreeing that to have [him]666-a pleasanter man marry either could be extremely delightful . [Charles]91-charles “[666-a pleasanter man] had never seen [a pleasanter man]666-a pleasanter man in [his]666-a pleasanter man life ; and from what [he]666-a pleasanter man had once heard [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth [himself]112-captain wentworth say , was very sure that [he]112-captain wentworth had not made less than twenty thousand pounds by the war . Here was a fortune at once ; besides which , there would be the chance of what might be done in any future war ; and [he]666-a pleasanter man was sure [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth was as likely [a man to distinguish [himself]112-captain wentworth as [any officer in the navy]668-any officer in the navy]667-a man to distinguish himself as any officer in the navy . Oh ! it would be a capital match for [either of [[his]112-captain wentworth sisters]2156-his sisters]669-either of his sisters . ” “[0-i] Upon [my]0-i word it would , ” replied [Mary]90-mary . “[0-i] Dear [me]0-i ! If [he]112-captain wentworth should rise to any very great honours ! If [he]112-captain wentworth should ever be made [a baronet]1818-a baronet ! ‘ [Lady Wentworth]143-lady wentworth ’ sounds very well . That would be a noble thing , indeed , for [Henrietta]117-henrietta ! [She]117-henrietta would take place of [me]0-i then , and [Henrietta]117-henrietta would not dislike that . [Sir Frederick]144-sir frederick and [Lady Wentworth]143-lady wentworth ! It would be but a new creation , however , and [I]0-i never think much of [your]672-your new creations . ” It suited [Mary]90-mary best to think [Henrietta]117-henrietta the one preferred on the very account of [Charles Hayter]91-charles , whose pretensions [she]90-mary wished to see put an end to . [She]90-mary looked down very decidedly upon [the Hayters]137-the hayters , and thought it would be quite a misfortune to have the existing connection between [the families]2366-the families renewed — very sad for [herself]90-mary and [[her]90-mary children]1713-her children . “[672-your] [You]672-your know , ” said [she]90-mary , “[672-your] [I]0-i can not think [him]673-him at all a fit match for [Henrietta]117-henrietta ; and considering the alliances which [the Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves have made , [she]117-henrietta has no right to throw [herself]117-henrietta away . [I]0-i do not think [any young woman]674-any young woman has a right to make a choice that may be disagreeable and inconvenient to [the principal part of [[her]674-any young woman family]636-her family]675-the principal part of her family , and be giving bad connections to [those who have not been used to [them]675-the principal part of her family]677-those who have not been used to them . And , pray , who is [Charles Hayter]91-charles ? Nothing but [a country curate]678-a country curate . A most improper match for [Miss Musgrove of Uppercross]139-uppercross . ” [[Her]90-mary husband]347-her husband , however , would not agree with [her]90-mary here ; for besides having a regard for [[his]347-her husband cousin]2369-his cousin , [Charles Hayter]91-charles was [an eldest son]2370-an eldest son , and [he]91-charles saw things as [an eldest son]2370-an eldest son [himself]91-charles . “[139-uppercross] Now [you]0-i are talking nonsense , [Mary]90-mary , ” was therefore [his]91-charles answer . “[0-i] It would not be a great match for [Henrietta]117-henrietta , but [Charles]91-charles has a very fair chance , through [the Spicers]145-the spicers , of getting something from [the Bishop]679-the bishop in the course of a year or two ; and [you]0-i will please to remember , that [he]91-charles is [the eldest son]680-the eldest son ; whenever [[my]0-i uncle]681-my uncle dies , [he]91-charles steps into very pretty property . [The estate at [Winthrop]40-winthrop]682-the estate at winthrop is not less than two hundred and fifty acres , besides [the farm near [Taunton]11-taunton]683-the farm near taunton , which is [some of the best land in [the country]1758-the country]684-some of the best land in the country . [I]0-i grant [you]0-i , that any of [them]686-them but [Charles]91-charles would be a very shocking match for [Henrietta]117-henrietta , and indeed it could not be ; [he]91-charles is the only one that could be possible ; but [he]91-charles is [a very good - natured , good sort of a fellow]687-a very good - natured , good sort of a fellow ; and whenever [Winthrop]40-winthrop comes into [his]91-charles hands , [he]91-charles will make a different sort of place of it , and live in a very different sort of way ; and with that property , [he]91-charles will never be [a contemptible man]688-a contemptible man — good , freehold property . No , no ; [Henrietta]117-henrietta might do worse than marry [Charles Hayter]91-charles ; and if [she]117-henrietta has [him]91-charles , and [Louisa]118-louisa can get [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth , [I]0-i shall be very well satisfied . ” “[91-charles] [Charles]91-charles may say what [he]91-charles pleases , ” cried [Mary]90-mary to [Anne]89-anne , as soon as [he]0-i was out of [the room]1874-the room , “[91-charles] but it would be shocking to have [Henrietta]117-henrietta marry [Charles Hayter]91-charles ; a very bad thing for [her]117-henrietta , and still worse for [me]0-i ; and therefore it is very much to be wished that [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth may soon put [him]91-charles quite out of [her]117-henrietta head , and [I]0-i have very little doubt that [he]91-charles has . [She]117-henrietta took hardly any notice of [Charles Hayter]91-charles yesterday . [I]0-i wish [you]689-you had been there to see [her]117-henrietta behaviour . And as to [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth ’s liking [Louisa]118-louisa as well as [Henrietta]117-henrietta , it is nonsense to say so ; for [he]112-captain wentworth certainly does like [Henrietta]117-henrietta a great deal the best . But [Charles]91-charles is so positive ! [I]0-i wish [you]689-you had been with [us]690-us yesterday , for then [you]689-you might have decided between [us]690-us ; and [I]0-i am sure [you]689-you would have thought as [I]0-i did , unless [you]689-you had been determined to give it against [me]0-i . ” A dinner at [Mr Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove ’s had been the occasion when all these things should have been seen by [Anne]89-anne ; but [she]89-anne had staid at [home]1756-home , under the mixed plea of a headache of [her]89-anne own , and some return of indisposition in [little Charles]91-charles . [She]89-anne had thought only of avoiding [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth ; but an escape from being appealed to as umpire was now added to the advantages of a quiet evening . As to [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth ’s views , [she]89-anne deemed it of more consequence that [he]112-captain wentworth should know [his]112-captain wentworth own mind early enough not to be endangering the happiness of [either sister]2374-either sister , or impeaching [his]112-captain wentworth own honour , than that [he]112-captain wentworth should prefer [Henrietta]117-henrietta to [Louisa]118-louisa , or [Louisa]118-louisa to [Henrietta]117-henrietta . Either of [them]2375-them would , in all probability , make [him]112-captain wentworth [an affectionate , good - humoured wife]2376-an affectionate , good - humoured wife . With regard to [Charles Hayter]91-charles , [she]89-anne had delicacy which must be pained by any lightness of conduct in [a well - meaning young woman]2377-a well - meaning young woman , and a heart to sympathize in any of the sufferings it occasioned ; but if [Henrietta]117-henrietta found [herself]117-henrietta mistaken in the nature of [her]117-henrietta feelings , the alteration could not be understood too soon . [Charles Hayter]91-charles had met with much to disquiet and mortify [him]91-charles in [[his]91-charles cousin]2369-his cousin ’s behaviour . [She]89-anne had too old a regard for [him]112-captain wentworth to be so wholly estranged as might in two meetings extinguish every past hope , and leave [him]112-captain wentworth nothing to do but to keep away from [Uppercross]3-uppercross : but there was such a change as became very alarming , when [such a man as [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth]2379-such a man as captain wentworth was to be regarded as the probable cause . [He]112-captain wentworth had been absent only two [Sundays]147-sundays , and when [they]2380-they parted , had left [her]89-anne interested , even to the height of [his]112-captain wentworth wishes , in [his]112-captain wentworth prospect of soon quitting [his]112-captain wentworth present curacy , and obtaining that of [Uppercross]3-uppercross instead . It had then seemed the object nearest [her]89-anne heart , that [Dr Shirley]148-dr shirley , [the rector]2381-the rector , who for more than forty years had been zealously discharging all the duties of [[his]148-dr shirley office]2382-his office , but was now growing too infirm for many of [them]2382-his office , should be quite fixed on engaging [a curate]2383-a curate ; should make [his]148-dr shirley curacy quite as good as [he]148-dr shirley could afford , and should give [Charles Hayter]91-charles the promise of it . The advantage of [his]112-captain wentworth having to come only to [Uppercross]3-uppercross , instead of going six miles another way ; of [his]112-captain wentworth having , in every respect , a better curacy ; of [his]112-captain wentworth belonging to [[their]2380-they dear]2384-their dear [Dr Shirley]148-dr shirley , and of dear , good [Dr Shirley]148-dr shirley ’s being relieved from the duty which [he]112-captain wentworth could no longer get through without most injurious fatigue , had been a great deal , even to [Louisa]118-louisa , but had been almost everything to [Henrietta]117-henrietta . When [he]112-captain wentworth came back , alas ! the zeal of the business was gone by . [Louisa]118-louisa could not listen at all to [his]112-captain wentworth account of a conversation which [he]112-captain wentworth had just held with [Dr Shirley]148-dr shirley : [she]118-louisa was at a window , looking out for [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth ; and even [Henrietta]117-henrietta had at best only a divided attention to give , and seemed to have forgotten all the former doubt and solicitude of the negotiation . “[689-you] Well , [I]0-i am very glad indeed : but [I]0-i always thought [you]691-you would have it ; [I]0-i always thought [you]691-you sure . It did not appear to [me]0-i that — in short , [you]691-you know , [Dr Shirley]148-dr shirley must have [a curate]2383-a curate , and [you]691-you had secured [his]148-dr shirley promise . Is [he]148-dr shirley coming , [Louisa]118-louisa ? ” One morning , very soon after the dinner at [the Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves , at which [Anne]89-anne had not been present , [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth walked into [the drawing - room at [the Cottage]2078-the cottage]2385-the drawing - room at the cottage , where were only [herself]89-anne and [the little invalid [Charles]91-charles , who was lying on the sofa]2387-the little invalid charles , who was lying on the sofa . The surprise of finding [himself]0-i almost alone with [Anne Elliot]89-anne , deprived [his]0-i manners of [their]2388-their usual composure : [he]0-i started , and could only say , “[0-i] [I]0-i thought [the Miss Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves had been [here]376-here : [Mrs Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove told [me]0-i [I]0-i should find [them]694-they here , ” before [he]0-i walked to the window to recollect [himself]0-i , and feel how [he]0-i ought to behave . “[114-mrs musgrove] [They]694-they are up [stairs]2225-stairs with [[my]0-i sister]424-my sister : [they]694-they will be down in a few moments , [I]0-i dare say , ” had been [Anne]89-anne ’s reply , in all the confusion that was natural ; and if [the child]2181-the child had not called [her]89-anne to come and do something for [him]0-i , [she]89-anne would have been out of [the room]1874-the room the next moment , and released [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth as well as [herself]89-anne . [He]0-i continued at the window ; and after calmly and politely saying , “[0-i] [I]0-i hope [the little boy]2209-the little boy is better , ” was silent . [She]89-anne was obliged to kneel down by the sofa , and remain there to satisfy [[her]89-anne patient]2391-her patient ; and thus [they]2392-they continued a few minutes , when , to [her]89-anne very great satisfaction , [she]89-anne heard [some other person crossing the little vestibule]2393-some other person crossing the little vestibule . [She]89-anne hoped , on turning [her]89-anne head , to see [the master of [the house]1780-the house]2130-the master of the house ; but it proved to be one much less calculated for making matters easy — [Charles Hayter]91-charles , probably not at all better pleased by the sight of [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth than [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth had been by the sight of [Anne]89-anne . [She]89-anne only attempted to say , “[0-i] How do [you]2209-the little boy do ? Will [you]2209-the little boy not sit down ? [The others]1828-the others will be here presently . ” [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth , however , came from [his]112-captain wentworth window , apparently not ill - disposed for conversation ; but [Charles Hayter]91-charles soon put an end to [his]91-charles attempts by seating [himself]91-charles near the table , and taking up the newspaper ; and [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth returned to [his]112-captain wentworth window . Another minute brought another addition . [The younger boy]2396-the younger boy , [a remarkable stout , forward child , of two years old]2397-a remarkable stout , forward child , of two years old , having got the door opened for [him]2396-the younger boy by [some one without]2398-some one without , made [his]2396-the younger boy determined appearance among [them]1828-the others , and went straight to the sofa to see what was going on , and put in [his]2396-the younger boy claim to anything good that might be giving away . There being nothing to eat , [he]2396-the younger boy could only have some play ; and as [[his]2396-the younger boy aunt]2269-his aunt would not let [him]2396-the younger boy tease [[his]2396-the younger boy sick brother]2400-his sick brother , [he]2396-the younger boy began to fasten [himself]2396-the younger boy upon [her]2269-his aunt , as [she]2269-his aunt knelt , in such a way that , busy as [she]2269-his aunt was about [Charles]91-charles , [she]2269-his aunt could not shake [him]2396-the younger boy off . [She]2269-his aunt spoke to [him]2396-the younger boy , ordered , entreated , and insisted in vain . Once [she]2269-his aunt did contrive to push [him]2396-the younger boy away , but [the boy]2401-the boy had the greater pleasure in getting upon [her]2269-his aunt back again directly . “[86-sir walter] [Walter]86-sir walter , ” said [she]2269-his aunt , “[86-sir walter] get down this moment . [You]86-sir walter are extremely troublesome . [I]0-i am very angry with [you]86-sir walter . ” “[86-sir walter] [Walter]86-sir walter , ” cried [Charles Hayter]91-charles , “[86-sir walter] why do [you]86-sir walter not do as [you]86-sir walter are bid ? Do not [you]86-sir walter hear [[your]86-sir walter aunt]699-your aunt speak ? Come to [me]0-i , [Walter]86-sir walter , come to [cousin Charles]91-charles . ” But not a bit did [Walter]86-sir walter stir . In another moment , however , [she]2269-his aunt found [herself]2269-his aunt in the state of being released from [him]86-sir walter ; [some one]2402-some one was taking [him]86-sir walter from [her]2269-his aunt , though [he]86-sir walter had bent down [her]2269-his aunt head so much , that [his]86-sir walter little sturdy hands were unfastened from around [her]2269-his aunt neck , and [he]86-sir walter was resolutely borne away , before [she]2269-his aunt knew that [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth had done it . [Her]2269-his aunt sensations on the discovery made [her]2269-his aunt perfectly speechless . [She]2269-his aunt could not even thank [him]86-sir walter . [She]2269-his aunt could only hang over [little Charles]91-charles , with most disordered feelings . [His]86-sir walter kindness in stepping forward to [her]2269-his aunt relief , the manner , the silence in which it had passed , the little particulars of the circumstance , with the conviction soon forced on [her]2269-his aunt by the noise [he]86-sir walter was studiously making with [the child]2181-the child , that [he]86-sir walter meant to avoid hearing [her]2269-his aunt thanks , and rather sought to testify that [her]2269-his aunt conversation was the last of [his]86-sir walter wants , produced such a confusion of varying , but very painful agitation , as [she]2269-his aunt could not recover from , till enabled by the entrance of [Mary]90-mary and [the Miss Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves to make over [[her]2269-his aunt little patient]2404-her little patient to [their]2405-their cares , and leave [the room]1874-the room . [She]2269-his aunt could not stay . It might have been an opportunity of watching the loves and jealousies of [the four]2407-the four — [they]2407-the four were now altogether ; but [she]2269-his aunt could stay for none of it . It was evident that [Charles Hayter]91-charles was not well inclined towards [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth . [She]2269-his aunt had a strong impression of [his]91-charles having said , in a vext tone of voice , after [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth ’s interference , “[86-sir walter] [You]700-you ought to have minded [me]0-i , [Walter]86-sir walter ; [I]0-i told [you]86-sir walter not to teaze [[your]86-sir walter aunt]699-your aunt ; ” and could comprehend [his]91-charles regretting that [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth should do what [he]112-captain wentworth ought to have done [himself]112-captain wentworth . But neither [Charles Hayter]91-charles ’s feelings , nor [anybody]462-anybody ’s feelings , could interest [her]2269-his aunt , till [she]2269-his aunt had a little better arranged [her]2269-his aunt own . [She]2269-his aunt was ashamed of [herself]2269-his aunt , quite ashamed of being so nervous , so overcome by such a trifle ; but so it was , and it required a long application of solitude and reflection to recover [her]2269-his aunt . [CHAPTER X.]149-chapter x. Other opportunities of making [her]2269-his aunt observations could not fail to occur . [Anne]89-anne had soon been in company with [all the four together]2409-all the four together often enough to have an opinion , though too wise to acknowledge as much at [home]1756-home , where [she]2269-his aunt knew it would have satisfied neither [husband]2411-husband nor [wife]2412-wife ; for while [she]2269-his aunt considered [Louisa]118-louisa to be rather the favourite , [she]2269-his aunt could not but think , as far as [she]2269-his aunt might dare to judge from memory and experience , that [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth was not in love with either . [They]2409-all the four together were more in love with [him]112-captain wentworth ; yet there it was not love . It was a little fever of admiration ; but it might , probably must , end in love with some . [Charles Hayter]91-charles seemed aware of being slighted , and yet [Henrietta]117-henrietta had sometimes the air of being divided between [them]2409-all the four together . [Anne]89-anne longed for the power of representing to [them]2409-all the four together all what [they]2409-all the four together were about , and of pointing out some of the evils [they]2409-all the four together were exposing [themselves]2409-all the four together to . [She]2269-his aunt did not attribute guile to any . It was the highest satisfaction to [her]2269-his aunt to believe [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth not in the least aware of the pain [he]112-captain wentworth was occasioning . There was no triumph , no pitiful triumph in [his]112-captain wentworth manner . [He]112-captain wentworth had , probably , never heard , and never thought of any claims of [Charles Hayter]91-charles . [He]112-captain wentworth was only wrong in accepting the attentions ( for accepting must be the word ) of [two young women]2413-two young women at once . After a short struggle , however , [Charles Hayter]91-charles seemed to quit [the field]2414-the field . Three days had passed without [his]91-charles coming once to [Uppercross]3-uppercross ; a most decided change . [He]91-charles had even refused one regular invitation to dinner ; and having been found on the occasion by [Mr Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove with some large books before [him]91-charles , [Mr]2415-mr and [Mrs Musgrove]114-mrs musgrove were sure all could not be right , and talked , with grave faces , of [his]91-charles studying [himself]91-charles to death . It was [Mary]90-mary ’s hope and belief that [he]91-charles had received a positive dismissal from [Henrietta]117-henrietta , and [[her]90-mary husband]347-her husband lived under the constant dependence of seeing [him]91-charles to - morrow . [Anne]89-anne could only feel that [Charles Hayter]91-charles was wise . One morning , about this time [Charles Musgrove]92-charles and [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth being gone a - shooting together , as [the sisters in [the Cottage]2078-the cottage]2417-the sisters in the cottage were sitting quietly at work , [they]2417-the sisters in the cottage were visited at the window by [the sisters from [the Mansion - house]2361-the mansion - house]2419-the sisters from the mansion - house . It was a very fine November day , and [the Miss Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves came through [the little grounds]2421-the little grounds , and stopped for no other purpose than to say , that [they]2417-the sisters in the cottage were going to take a long walk , and , therefore , concluded [Mary]90-mary could not like to go with [them]2417-the sisters in the cottage ; and when [Mary]90-mary immediately replied , with some jealousy at not being supposed [a good walker]2422-a good walker , “[0-i] Oh , yes , [I]0-i should like to join [you]702-you very much , [I]0-i am very fond of a long walk ; ” [Anne]89-anne felt persuaded , by the looks of [the two girls]2205-the two girls , that it was precisely what [they]2205-the two girls did not wish , and admired again the sort of necessity which the family habits seemed to produce , of everything being to be communicated , and everything being to be done together , however undesired and inconvenient . [She]89-anne tried to dissuade [Mary]90-mary from going , but in vain ; and that being the case , thought it best to accept [the Miss Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves ’ much more cordial invitation to [herself]90-mary to go likewise , as [she]90-mary might be useful in turning back with [[her]90-mary sister]1946-her sister , and lessening the interference in any plan of [their]2205-the two girls own . “[0-i] [I]0-i can not imagine why [they]703-they should suppose [I]0-i should not like a long walk , ” said [Mary]90-mary , as [she]90-mary went up [stairs]2225-stairs . “[0-i] [Everybody]2119-everybody is always supposing that [I]0-i am not [a good walker]2422-a good walker ; and yet [they]703-they would not have been pleased , if [we]706-we had refused to join [them]703-they . When [people]422-people come in this manner on purpose to ask [us]706-we , how can [one]1726-one say no ? ” Just as [they]2205-the two girls were setting off , [the gentlemen]1985-the gentlemen returned . [They]1985-the gentlemen had taken out a young dog , who had spoilt [their]1985-the gentlemen sport , and sent [them]1985-the gentlemen back early . [Their]1985-the gentlemen time and strength , and spirits , were , therefore , exactly ready for this walk , and [they]1985-the gentlemen entered into it with pleasure . Could [Anne]89-anne have foreseen such a junction , [she]89-anne would have staid at [home]1756-home ; but , from some feelings of interest and curiosity , [she]89-anne fancied now that it was too late to retract , and [the whole six]2428-the whole six set forward together in the direction chosen by [the Miss Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves , who evidently considered the walk as under [their]1985-the gentlemen guidance . [Anne]89-anne ’s object was , not to be in the way of [anybody]462-anybody ; and where the narrow paths across [the fields]2430-the fields made many separations necessary , to keep with [[her]89-anne brother]481-her brother and [sister]1740-sister . [Her]89-anne pleasure in the walk must arise from the exercise and the day , from the view of the last smiles of the year upon the tawny leaves , and withered hedges , and from repeating to [herself]89-anne some few of the thousand poetical descriptions extant of autumn , that season of peculiar and inexhaustible influence on the mind of taste and tenderness , that season which had drawn from [every poet , worthy of being read , some attempt at description , or some lines of feeling]2433-every poet , worthy of being read , some attempt at description , or some lines of feeling . [She]89-anne occupied [her]89-anne mind as much as possible in such like musings and quotations ; but it was not possible , that when within reach of [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth ’s conversation with either of [the Miss Musgroves]115-the miss musgroves , [she]89-anne should not try to hear it ; yet [she]89-anne caught little very remarkable . It was mere lively chat , such as [any young persons , on an intimate footing]2434-any young persons , on an intimate footing , might fall into . [He]1880-the admiral was more engaged with [Louisa]118-louisa than with [Henrietta]117-henrietta . [Louisa]118-louisa certainly put more forward for [his]1880-the admiral notice than [[her]118-louisa sister]1946-her sister . This distinction appeared to increase , and there was one speech of [Louisa]118-louisa ’s which struck [her]89-anne . After one of the many praises of the day , which were continually bursting forth , [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth added : — “[1726-one] What glorious weather for [the Admiral]1880-the admiral and [[my]0-i sister]424-my sister ! [They]711-they meant to take a long drive this morning ; perhaps [we]712-we may hail [them]711-they from [some of [these hills]714-these hills]713-some of these hills . [They]711-they talked of coming into [this side of [the country]1758-the country]715-this side of the country . [I]0-i wonder whereabouts [they]711-they will upset to - day . Oh ! it does happen very often , [I]0-i assure [you]717-you ; but [[my]0-i sister]424-my sister makes nothing of it ; [she]424-my sister would as lieve be tossed out as not . ” “[424-my sister] Ah ! [You]717-you make the most of it , [I]0-i know , ” cried [Louisa]118-louisa , “[717-you] but if it were really so , [I]0-i should do just the same in [her]424-my sister place . If [I]0-i loved [a man]307-a man , as [she]424-my sister loves [the Admiral]1880-the admiral , [I]0-i would always be with [him]1880-the admiral , nothing should ever separate [us]721-them , and [I]0-i would rather be overturned by [him]1880-the admiral , than driven safely by [anybody else]1811-anybody else . ” It was spoken with enthusiasm . “[0-i] Had [you]0-i ? ” cried [he]0-i , catching the same tone ; “[0-i] [I]0-i honour [you]0-i ! ” And there was silence between [them]721-them for a little while . [Anne]89-anne could not immediately fall into a quotation again . The sweet scenes of autumn were for a while put by , unless some tender sonnet , fraught with the apt analogy of the declining year , with declining happiness , and the images of youth and hope , and spring , all gone together , blessed [her]89-anne memory . [She]89-anne roused [herself]89-anne to say , as [they]721-them struck by order into another path , “[0-i] Is not [this one of the ways to [Winthrop]40-winthrop]723-this one of the ways to winthrop ? ” But [nobody]271-nobody heard , or , at least , [nobody]271-nobody answered [her]89-anne . [Winthrop]40-winthrop , however , or [[its]40-winthrop environs]2438-its environs — for [young men]2439-young men are , sometimes to be met with , strolling about near [home]1756-home — was [their]721-them destination ; and after another half mile of gradual ascent through [large enclosures , where the ploughs at work]2441-large enclosures , where the ploughs at work , and [the fresh made path]2442-the fresh made path spoke [the farmer]2443-the farmer counteracting the sweets of poetical despondence , and meaning to have spring again , [they]721-them gained [the summit of [the most considerable hill]2445-the most considerable hill , which parted [Uppercross]139-uppercross and [Winthrop]40-winthrop]2444-the summit of the most considerable hill , which parted uppercross and winthrop , and soon commanded a full view of the latter , at [the foot of [the hill on the other side]2447-the hill on the other side]2446-the foot of the hill on the other side . [Winthrop]40-winthrop , without beauty and without dignity , was stretched before [them]721-them ; [an indifferent house , standing low , and hemmed in by the barns and buildings of [a farm - yard]2449-a farm - yard]2448-an indifferent house , standing low , and hemmed in by the barns and buildings of a farm - yard . [Mary]90-mary exclaimed , “[0-i] Bless [me]0-i ! here is [Winthrop]40-winthrop . [I]0-i declare [I]0-i had no idea ! Well now , [I]0-i think [we]724-we had better turn back ; [I]0-i am excessively tired . ” [Henrietta]117-henrietta , conscious and ashamed , and seeing [no cousin]2450-no cousin [Charles]91-charles walking along any path , or leaning against any gate , was ready to do as [Mary]90-mary wished ; but “[0-i] No ! ” said [Charles Musgrove]92-charles , and “[0-i] No , no ! ” cried [Louisa]118-louisa more eagerly , and taking [[her]118-louisa sister]1946-her sister aside , seemed to be arguing the matter warmly . [Charles]91-charles , in the meanwhile , was very decidedly declaring [his]91-charles resolution of calling on [[his]91-charles aunt]2269-his aunt , now that [he]91-charles was so near ; and very evidently , though more fearfully , trying to induce [[his]91-charles wife]1699-his wife to go too . But this was one of the points on which [the lady]2454-the lady shewed [her]2454-the lady strength ; and when [he]91-charles recommended the advantage of resting [herself]2454-the lady a quarter of an hour at [Winthrop]40-winthrop , as [she]2454-the lady felt so tired , [she]2454-the lady resolutely answered , “[0-i] Oh ! no , indeed ! walking up [that hill]725-that hill again would do [her]726-her more harm than any sitting down could do [her]726-her good ; ” and , in short , [her]2454-the lady look and manner declared , that go [she]2454-the lady would not . After a little succession of these sort of debates and consultations , it was settled between [Charles]91-charles and [[his]91-charles two sisters]2455-his two sisters , that [he]91-charles and [Henrietta]117-henrietta should just run down for a few minutes , to see [[their]2455-his two sisters aunt]2456-their aunt and [cousins]2125-cousins , while [the rest of the party]2458-the rest of the party waited for [them]2455-his two sisters at [the top of [the hill]2460-the hill]2459-the top of the hill . [Louisa]118-louisa seemed [the principal arranger of the plan]2461-the principal arranger of the plan ; and , as [she]118-louisa went a little way with [them]2455-his two sisters , down [the hill]2460-the hill , still talking to [Henrietta]117-henrietta , [Mary]90-mary took the opportunity of looking scornfully around [her]90-mary , and saying to [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth — “[0-i] It is very unpleasant , having such connexions ! But , [I]0-i assure [you]727-you , [I]0-i have never been in [the house]1780-the house above twice in [my]0-i life . ” [She]90-mary received no other answer , than an artificial , assenting smile , followed by a contemptuous glance , as [he]112-captain wentworth turned away , which [Anne]89-anne perfectly knew the meaning of . [The brow of [the hill]2460-the hill]2463-the brow of the hill , where [they]2455-his two sisters remained , was [a cheerful spot]2465-a cheerful spot : [Louisa]118-louisa returned ; and [Mary]90-mary , finding a comfortable seat for [herself]90-mary on the step of a stile , was very well satisfied so long as [the others]1828-the others all stood about [her]90-mary ; but when [Louisa]118-louisa drew [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth away , to try for a gleaning of nuts in [an adjoining hedge - row]2467-an adjoining hedge - row , and [they]2455-his two sisters were gone by degrees quite out of sight and sound , [Mary]90-mary was happy no longer ; [she]90-mary quarrelled with [her]90-mary own seat , was sure [Louisa]118-louisa had got a much better somewhere , and nothing could prevent [her]90-mary from going to look for [a better also]2468-a better also . [She]89-anne turned through the same gate , but could not see [them]2455-his two sisters . [Anne]89-anne found a nice seat for [her]89-anne , on a dry sunny bank , under the hedge - row , in which [she]89-anne had no doubt of [their]2455-his two sisters still being , in some spot or other . [Mary]90-mary sat down for a moment , but it would not do ; [she]90-mary was sure [Louisa]118-louisa had found a better seat somewhere else , and [she]90-mary would go on till [she]118-louisa overtook [her]90-mary . [Anne]89-anne , really tired [herself]89-anne , was glad to sit down ; and [she]89-anne very soon heard [Captain Wentworth]112-captain wentworth and [Louisa]118-louisa in the hedge - row , behind [her]89-anne , as if making [their]2455-his two sisters way back along [the rough , wild sort of channel]2469-the rough , wild sort of channel , down the centre . [They]2455-his two sisters were speaking as [they]2455-his two sisters drew near . [Louisa]118-louisa ’s voice was the first distinguished . [She]118-louisa seemed to be in the middle of some eager speech . What [Anne]89-anne first heard was — “[0-i] And so , [I]0-i made [her]729-her go . [I]0-i could not bear that [she]729-her should be frightened from the visit by such nonsense . What ! would [I]0-i be turned back from doing a thing that [I]0-i had determined to do , and that [I]0-i knew to be right , by the airs and interference of [such a person]730-such a person , or of [any person]731-any person [I]0-i may say ? No , [I]0-i have no idea of being so easily persuaded . When [I]0-i have made up [my]0-i mind , [I]0-i have made it ; and [Henrietta]117-henrietta seemed entirely to have made up [hers]117-henrietta to call at Winthrop to - day ; and yet , [she]117-henrietta was as near giving it up , out of nonsensical complaisance ! ” “[117-henrietta] [She]117-henrietta would have turned back then , but for [you]0-i ? ” “[117-henrietta] [She]117-henrietta would indeed . [I]0-i am almost ashamed to say it . ” “[117-henrietta] Happy for [her]729-her , to have such a mind as [yours]0-i at hand ! After the hints [you]0-i gave just now , which did but confirm [my]0-i own observations , the last time [I]0-i was in company with [him]729-her , [I]0-i need not affect to have no comprehension of what is going on . [I]0-i see that more than a mere dutiful morning visit to [[your]0-i aunt]699-your aunt was in question ; and woe betide [him]729-her , and [her]729-her too , when it comes to things of consequence , when they are placed in circumstances requiring fortitude and strength of mind , if [she]729-her have not resolution enough to resist idle interference in such a trifle as this .
